headline: Teachers Buys Glass Lewis for $46 Million
abstract: The Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan has bought Glass Lewis, a San Francisco-based investment research, proxy advisory and voting services firm, for $46 million from its Chinese owner, Xinhua Finance of Shanghai.

headline: A Different Formula for a Biogen Deal
abstract: Will DNA get mixed up in a sale of Biogen Idec?

headline: A Toast to the Top Women in Banking
abstract: At a gathering to toast the most powerful women in banking, there was a generally sense that despite some important inroads, more work was to be done.

headline: Schlumberger Offers $679 Million for Eastern Echo
abstract: Schlumberger, the oil-field services company, bid up to $679 million for a Norwegian-listed company, Eastern Echo, on Tuesday to expand its seismic operations at a time when record oil prices are driving demand.

headline: Ex-Chief Considers Bid for Children’s Place
abstract: Shares of Children’s Place rose 6 percent Monday after the company’s recently ousted chief executive and its largest shareholder, said he might put together an offer to buy the retailer.

headline: Perelman Seeks $500 Million ‘Blank Check’
abstract: MAFS Acquisition, a blank-check company led by billionaire financier Ronald O. Perelman, filed with regulators to raise as much as $500 million to fund an acquisition.

headline: Wary of Risk, Bankers Sold Shaky Mortgage Debt
abstract: As the subprime loan crisis deepens, Wall Street firms are increasingly coming under scrutiny for their role in selling risky mortgage-related securities to investors.

headline: A Dark-Horse Candidate for Citi’s Top Job?
abstract: Since last month, Citigroup has struggled to find a replacement for Charles O. Prince III, its recently resigned chief executive. It has looked inside the sprawling financial giant; it has examined the firm’s alumni (some of whom left the firm unwillingly); it has cast its eyes on the top executives of its rivals.

headline: Female Directors Earn More Than Men, Study Finds
abstract: A new survey on corporate board pay has come up with a surprising find: The median compensation for female directors is actually higher than that for male directors.

headline: They Told You So
abstract: By PETER EDMONSTON

headline: J.P. Morgan Sued Over Role in Dow Talks
abstract: James Dimon just got pulled deeper into the legal morass surrounding this year’s secret talks to buy out Dow Chemical.

headline: Strike Postpones ’24’ Premiere; Fox Revises Schedule
abstract: Three days into the writers’ strike, Fox has become the first broadcast network to announce revisions to its prime time schedule.

headline: Paris to Lighten Regulations to Poach London’s Listings
abstract: Plans to make Paris a more attractive financial center and draw capital away from the City of London were announced Friday as part of a drive to promote business-friendly policies in France.

headline: Citadel Not in Talks for BofA’s Prime Broker Unit, Report Says
abstract: Citadel Investment Group is not negotiating to buy Bank of America‘s prime brokerage unit, Reuters reported citing an unnamed source, throwing cold water on a media report the hedge fund firm has inspected the bank’s books.

headline: Your Tax Dollars at Work
abstract: Would you pay kickbacks to a supposed hedge fund manager whose fund bought shares through an E*Trade account?

headline: Feresten Returns To Fox Sketch Show
abstract: After a two-month pause because of the writers’ strike, Fox will begin taping episodes of the Saturday night series “Talkshow with Spike Feresten” early next month.

headline: Cantor Fitzgerald Executive Is Out
abstract: A Cantor Fitzgerald executive in charge of capital markets has left as the firm copes with sharp losses from this summer’s crash of the mortgage- and asset-backed securities markets, The New York Post reported.

headline: Pelikan Flies Off With $69 Million
abstract: Pelikan Technologies, which makes a device for electronically extracting blood samples for glucose monitoring in diabetics, raised $69 million in venture funding. Clarus Ventures was the lead investor in the round, which also included new investors Bio*One Capital and Global Life Science Ventures.

headline: Psssst: “Gossip Girl” Is a Keeper
abstract: “Gossip Girl,” along with its Wednesday night lead-in “America’s Next Top Model,” are helping cement the CW’s position as a fresh and female-friendly channel. So it comes as no surprise that “Gossip Girl” has become the first fall series picked up for a full season of episodes.

headline: The Bubble in Tom Perkins’s Sails
abstract: Tom Perkins, the venture capitalist, says bubbles aren’t so bad.

headline: AOL to Lay Off 20 Percent of Its Workers
abstract: Randy Falco, the chief executive of AOL, announced that the company would eliminate 2,000 of its 10,000 jobs.

headline: Third Point Sells PDL Stake
abstract: Third Point chief Daniel S. Loeb has officially washed his hands of PDL BioPharma. Third Point liquidated its remaining stake in the biotechnology company as a result of being denied a seat on its board.

headline: Some Wonder if Banks’ Stabilization Fund Will Work
abstract: When the country’s three largest banks reached agreement on Friday on how to structure a $75 billion fund to prop up distressed securities, an exhausted group of its top planners reportedly gathered in a Bank of America conference room to toast their success with 12-packs of Bud Light.

headline: Gabelli Says He Will Reject Cablevision Buyout
abstract: A major shareholder is giving bad reviews to a plan to take Cablevision private.

headline: K.K.R. Launches $1.2 Billion Bid for U.K. Software Maker
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts on Friday unveiled a 593 million pound ($1.2 billion) offer for British human resources software maker Northgate Information Solutions despite recent concerns about its debt.

headline: Deal for Canadian Shoe Retailer Collapses
abstract: The sole remaining Canadian retail business in the Bata shoe empire has quietly slipped into bankruptcy protection after a deal with a would-be buyer, Michael Gold, fell apart over a tax dispute.

headline: More Withdrawals at Florida Investment Fund
abstract: The Florida investment fund for local governments that lost half its assets to redemptions last month has been reduced by an additional $1.9 billion since the pool was opened following a freeze on accounts, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Lagardere Denies EADS Insider Trading
abstract: Arnaud Lagardere, chief executive of Lagardere, the French publishing company, denied allegations of insider trading in the company’s sale of shares in European Aeronautic, Defence & Space, the parent of Airbus, two months before production delays in the Airbus A380 were disclosed.

headline: Stephen Schwarzman Speaks
abstract: From a DealBook colleague, Jenny Anderson:

headline: British Treasury Said to Approve Northern Rock Talks
abstract: The British Treasury has given two private equity firms in the United States permission to start takeover talks with beleaguered British mortgage lender Northern Rock, the Sunday Telegraph newspaper reported.

headline: Atlantic Bridge Locates Exit for GloNav
abstract: European venture firm Atlantic Bridge Ventures will have some extra money for Christmas shopping as it notched its second exit of the year, selling portfolio company GloNav to chipmaker NXP Semiconductors for $110 million.

headline: NeuroVasx Takes $8.5 Million in New Funding
abstract: A medical device developer, NeuroVasx, raised $8.5 million in follow-on investment from previous backers to support completion of regulatory trials and a commercial introduction of implant technology to treat strokes in patients with brain aneurysms.

headline: Tokyo Seeking a Top Niche in Global Finance
abstract: Years ago, Japan rose to economic prominence by taking apart American products like cars and television sets to learn how to make them better.

headline: Understanding The Writers’ Complaint To The Labor Board
abstract: Almost one week after negotiations broke down between the writers’ guild and the studios’ alliance, the feud deepened on Thursday with the filing of an unfair labor practices complaint with the National Labor Relations Board.

headline: Bear Stearns’s Not-So-Grim Compensation Math
abstract: As penance for presiding over the first quarterly loss in Bear Stearns‘ history, the firm’s executive committee won’t be getting any bonuses this year. “In a year in which we produced unacceptable results, the [executive compensation] plans are working as they were designed,” the firm said Thursday.

headline: Tired of Corruption but Afraid of the Crackdown
abstract: South Koreans have grown tired of the corrupt ways of their big businesses. But because the economy depends so heavily on a handful of them, Koreans fear striking too hard a blow against them. That appears to be the case with the bribery scandal that has rocked manufacturing giant  Samsung.

headline: Carlyle-Backed China Pacific Insurance Eyes $4 Billion I.P.O.
abstract: The China Pacific Insurance (Group), the nation’s third-largest insurer, may raise as much as 30 billion yuan ($4.07 billion) in the biggest initial public offering ever by a Chinese insurer.

headline: Spanish Bank Boosts Stake in Iberia Airline
abstract: An unlisted savings bank Caja Madrid has built a stake of more than 23 percent in the Spanish flagship airline Iberia in a move that could disrupt a potential bidding war for the airline, Europe’s fourth-largest carrier.

headline: Memsic Flat in Debut
abstract: Shares of Memsic, a maker of sensors used to add touch, pedometer, or light-show functions to mobile phones, edged up 20 cents, or 2 percent, to $10.20 in the company’s debut on the Nasdaq Global Market Friday afternoon.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Wall Street Windfall
abstract: In the halls of high finance, Hillary Clinton’s stock seems to be rising.

headline: Fraud Trial of Former Brocade Executive Begins
abstract: Prosecutors argued Monday that a former Brocade Communications Systems executive was a key enforcer in an illegal accounting scheme, while her attorney said she was just following instructions when she backdated stock options.

headline: SK Telecom Buys Hanaro fo $1.2 Billion
abstract: SK Telecom, South Korea’s largest cellular carrier, said Monday it has agreed to buy a controlling 38.89 percent stake in broadband and telephone service provider Hanarotelecom for 1.09 trillion won ($1.2 billion), equipping itself to challenge the country’s biggest fixed-line operator, KT, following deregulation next year that will allow telecom companies to offer bundled services.

headline: Joy of Failure
abstract: Do you think financiers should be embarrassed and repentant as the financial system erodes? Or do you see an opportunity for a party?

headline: What ‘Should’ You Do in Your Career?
abstract: Some advice for those who make career decisions based on what they think they should be doing rather than what they want to be doing.

headline: Upbeat Report Sends XM’s Stock Into Orbit
abstract: No one — with the possible exception of a few highly placed folks at the Federal Communications Commission and the Justice Department — can be sure if regulators will approve the proposed hook-up between XM Satellite Radio and Sirius Satellite Radio. But at least one analyst thinks investors have been far too pessimistic about the merger’s chances.

headline: ‘TMZ’ Plays Well on Television
abstract: “There have been a lot of attempts to latch onto something that was popular on the Internet and transfer it to television. They generally haven’t been successful,” Ken Werner, the president of Warner Brothers Domestic Television Distribution, said in a phone interview last week.

headline: Sallie Mae Sues Buyers Over Deal
abstract: The gloves have come off.

headline: Shares of Alibaba.com Climb on First Day of Trading
abstract: Shares of Alibaba.com, one of China’s biggest Internet companies, soared in early trading on Tuesday in China’s latest hot initial public stock offering.

headline: Harmony Gold Sells $252 Milion in Assets
abstract: Harmony Gold Mining, Africa’s third-largest gold producer, agreed to form a venture and sell a stake in assets including its Cooke uranium ore dump in South Africa to Pamodzi Resources Fund for $252 million.

headline: Petrobas to Take Exxon’s Stake in Japanese Refinery
abstract: Brazil’s state-run Petroleo Brasileiro, or Petrobras, will acquire Exxon Mobil‘s majority stake in a Japan-based refinery, Nansei Sekiyu, MarketWatch reported, citing a story in Nikkei News.

headline: For Capital, Merrill Looks East and West
abstract: The major source of Merrill Lynch‘s $6.2 billion cash infusion, announced Monday, was fairly unsurprising: Singapore. It is just the latest Asian country to invest in a troubled financial firm, following China’s decision to pour $5 billion into Morgan Stanley.

headline: Looking at the Lawyers in O’Neal’s Exit
abstract: The departure of E. Stanley O’Neal from Merrill Lynch can be read as a deal story of sorts. And as with any major negotiation, both sides have hired high-powered lawyers to do the talking for them.

headline: Countdown to a Writers’ Strike
abstract: The impending writers’ strike would obviously be bad news for viewers, who would likely see repeats and reality shows start to crowd out scripted shows during prime time. In the wee hours, late-night hosts would probably have to spend a lot of time winging it.

headline: Is the Exaflood Coming?
abstract: A new study says we may be facing an “exaflood” of higher demand for broadbaand. The telecom industry is behind the study, which doesn’t mean it is wrong. But a prominent researcher who called the telecom bubble in 1998 says it isn’t as bad as some people want you to think it will be.

headline: Wall Street Research, Made in India
abstract: Wall Street firms are cutting costs and tightening belts these days — just try ordering a new BlackBerry at Bank of America. This could accelerate a cost-cutting trend that was already gaining momentum: The outsourcing of junior research and investment banking activities to India, where analysis and pitchbooks come far more cheaply than in the United States.

headline: Viacom Dumps DoubleClick for Microsoft
abstract: Microsoft and Viacom team up on ads and content, and Google quickly points to the deal as evidence that the online ad market is plenty competitive.

headline: Hacking Rings Take Advantage of Death in Boston
abstract: When friends and family of Ann Marie McNally search for the deceased woman’s name in Google, they come across several distasteful posts — all exemplary of the spam that some fear is taking over search engine results.

headline: Do We Need an Internet TV Network?
abstract: Web TV network Joost is opening its service to the online public. Will anyone want to watch? The biggest challenge for the London-based company: convincing people to put their Web browsing on hold, lean back in their computer desk chairs and tune in.

headline: Deal Is Struck to End Harman Buyout
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Goldman Sachs agreed to terminate their merger agreement with Harman International Industries on Monday and reinvest in the audio speaker company.

headline: Former Brocade Executive Convicted of Options Fraud
abstract: A federal jury on Wednesday convicted Stephanie Jensen, the former personnel director of Brocade Communications Systems, on charges of conspiracy and falsifying records.

headline: Qatari Fund Withdraws Sainsbury Offer
abstract: The British supermarkets group J Sainsbury will remain independent after the Qatari-based investment fund Delta Two on Monday abandoned its 10.6 billion pound bid ($22.1 billion).

headline: Apax Is Said to Join Guardian in Bid for Emap Unit
abstract: Apax, the British private equity firm, has reportedly teamed up with the Guardian Media Group, publisher of The Guardian newspaper, to mount a joint 1.2 billion pound ($2.4 billion) bid for Emap‘s business publishing division.

headline: The Search for Merrill’s New C.E.O.
abstract: Could a love of southern Italian cuisine play a part in who succeeds E. Stanley O’Neal, the former chief executive and chairman of Merrill Lynch who retired Tuesday after losing the support of his board?

headline: Former Royal Ahold Chief Pays $7.1 Million in Settlement
abstract: A former chief executive of Royal Ahold, Cees van der Hoeven, will pay the retailer 5 million euros ($7.1 million) to settle a dispute over severance, four years after he was ousted and then charged with fraud.

headline: ‘Predator’ Makes a Cameo Return
abstract: “To Catch a Predator,” the controversial series on NBC that aims to expose sex predators, will return on Friday, Dec. 28 with a segment filmed earlier this year in Bowling Green, Ky.

headline: Early Victim of Strike: ‘Office’ Originals End Next Week
abstract: Television viewers are beginning to get a better sense of how the writers’ strike will affect their favorite shows. Original half-hour episodes of NBC’s hit half-hour comedy “The Office” will stop being shown after next week.

headline: Tribune Deal Gets F.C.C. Nod
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission late Friday approved real estate magnate Samuel Zell’s $8.2 billion buyout of Tribune, with conditions, giving the company just enough time to close the deal by the end of the year as it had promised investors.

headline: Walid’s New Rival for Citi’s Deference
abstract: He isn’t a Citigroup executive or director. But for more than a decade, Prince Walid bin Talal has been an unofficial godfather at the firm by dint of his stake in the financial giant. Securing his blessing was often necessary to introduce new initiatives at the bank. Conversely, the withholding of his backing was a damaging, if not fatal, blow. Just ask Charles O. Prince III.

headline: Blackstone Joins Bid for Nufarm, Sources Say
abstract: China National Chemical offered $2.96 billion Australian dollars ($2.7 billion) for farm-chemical maker Nufarm, inviting the Blackstone Group and Fox Paine & Company to join, Bloomberg News reported, citing people familiar with the matter. ChemChina would be the first state-owned Chinese company to team up with buyout firms for an overseas acquisition, Bloomberg wrote.

headline: Sour Grapes in Philadelphia Exchange Deal
abstract: The proposed $625 million sale of the Philadelphia Stock Exchange to the Nasdaq Stock Market has some stockholders and former members feeling bitter, according to The Philadelphia Inquirer.

headline: Teachers Buys Glass Lewis for $46 Million
abstract: The Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan has bought Glass Lewis, a San Francisco-based investment research, proxy advisory and voting services firm, for $46 million from its Chinese owner, Xinhua Finance of Shanghai.

headline: A Different Formula for a Biogen Deal
abstract: Will DNA get mixed up in a sale of Biogen Idec?

headline: A Toast to the Top Women in Banking
abstract: At a gathering to toast the most powerful women in banking, there was a generally sense that despite some important inroads, more work was to be done.

headline: Schlumberger Offers $679 Million for Eastern Echo
abstract: Schlumberger, the oil-field services company, bid up to $679 million for a Norwegian-listed company, Eastern Echo, on Tuesday to expand its seismic operations at a time when record oil prices are driving demand.

headline: Ex-Chief Considers Bid for Children’s Place
abstract: Shares of Children’s Place rose 6 percent Monday after the company’s recently ousted chief executive and its largest shareholder, said he might put together an offer to buy the retailer.

headline: Perelman Seeks $500 Million ‘Blank Check’
abstract: MAFS Acquisition, a blank-check company led by billionaire financier Ronald O. Perelman, filed with regulators to raise as much as $500 million to fund an acquisition.

headline: Wary of Risk, Bankers Sold Shaky Mortgage Debt
abstract: As the subprime loan crisis deepens, Wall Street firms are increasingly coming under scrutiny for their role in selling risky mortgage-related securities to investors.

headline: A Dark-Horse Candidate for Citi’s Top Job?
abstract: Since last month, Citigroup has struggled to find a replacement for Charles O. Prince III, its recently resigned chief executive. It has looked inside the sprawling financial giant; it has examined the firm’s alumni (some of whom left the firm unwillingly); it has cast its eyes on the top executives of its rivals.

headline: Female Directors Earn More Than Men, Study Finds
abstract: A new survey on corporate board pay has come up with a surprising find: The median compensation for female directors is actually higher than that for male directors.

headline: They Told You So
abstract: By PETER EDMONSTON

headline: Apple Notes: Another iPhone Jailbreak
abstract: Apple locks the iPhone, and hackers release it. Again.

headline: Strikers Picket ‘The View’
abstract: Striking members of the Writers Guild of America East picketed outside of the ABC Daytime studios on the Upper West Side of Manhattan today beginning at 9:15 a.m. (almost an hour earlier than most days) in order to catch audience members who were arriving to see the popular morning talk show “The View.”

headline: Sweden’s Investor Mulls Absolut Bid
abstract: The auction for Sweden’s Vin & Sprit kicked into higher gear on Thursday when the country’s powerful Wallenberg family said it was considering a bid for the maker of Absolut vodka.

headline: E.U. Lawmakers Urge Greater Scrutiny of Google Deal
abstract: European lawmakers say they will press the bloc’s fiercely independent antitrust regulators next month to look at data privacy issues surrounding Google‘s proposed takeover of the online ad tracker DoubleClick.

headline: Fewer Births, Fewer Deaths for 2007
abstract: Fewer hedge funds are opening, and fewer are closing, as the hedge fund industry is set for multi-year lows in both categories in 2007.

headline: Behringer Harvard Signs for Chicago Office Towers
abstract: Behringer Harvard closed on its $832.5 million purchase of four downtown Chicago office towers from affiliates of Beacon Capital Partners, Behringer announced Monday.

headline: McCormick Adds Lawry’s to Its Spice Rack
abstract: McCormick agreed Wednesday to buy the Lawry’s business from Unilever Group for $605 million in cash, adding wet marinades to its selection of dry spices.

headline: Citigroup’s Risky Business Comes Back to Haunt It
abstract: Citigroup acknowledged on Monday that its risk management models did not function properly during this summer’s credit crisis, contributing to the company’s 57 percent drop in third-quarter profit.

headline: Venture Cash Puts L.A. in Party Mood
abstract: With high-tech-focused venture capital pouring into Southern California, the party scene is apparently heating up among the region’s entrepreneurs. Late last year, the region bypassed New England to rank second in the United States — after Silicon Valley — for tech investment.

headline: Portugal’s BPI Turns Table on Rival With Merger Proposal
abstract: Banco BPI of Portugal proposed a merger with Millennium BCP, the country’s biggest listed bank, on Thursday, only five months after fending off a hostile 5.32 billion euro ($7.6 billion) takeover bid from BCP.

headline: Securities Lawyer Accused of Fraud Is Forced to Resign
abstract: Martin E. Weisberg, a corporate lawyers accused of participating in a $55 million stock fraud scheme, resigned from Baker & McKenzie on Thursday after the firm asked him to.

headline: Reports Suggest Broader Losses From Mortgages
abstract: Every time economists and Wall Street executives think they have acknowledged the full extent of the losses from the meltdown in real estate mortgages, more bad news turns up.

headline: “Dexter” Scores Big for Showtime
abstract: Was it those ubiquitous blood-spattered ads featuring the smiling face of clean-cut Dexter Morgan? Or maybe those viral videos spoofing a news report about a serial killer?

headline: Taking Stock of Cognos’ Potential Suitors
abstract: SAP‘s acquisition of Business Objects has ignited speculation about what enterprise software maker could be next. Now, according to the 451 Group, the most likely takeover target is Cognos, another maker of business-intelligence software.

headline: Ellington Capital Said to Freeze Funds
abstract: Ellington Capital Management, the country’s largest mortgage-backed securities hedge fund, sent a letter to investors notifying them that redemptions and withdrawals in two of its funds would be suspended because of a sharp decline in the liquidity of certain mortgage- and asset-backed markets, The New York Post reported.

headline: Are Hedge Fund Indexes the Answer?
abstract: Indexes have long been used as a gauge of performance for stock and bond investors, but, Investment Dealers’ Digest wonders, can they be used within the hedge fund industry, and could they supplant the role of funds-of-funds that many institutional investors have come to rely on?

headline: Biggest Time-Shift Winners: ‘Heroes,’ ‘The Office,’ ‘Grey’s Anatomy’
abstract: Michael Scott’s employees in “The Office” and Hiro Nakamura’s super friends in “Heroes” were the biggest percentage beneficiaries of time-shifted television viewing in the first week of the fall season, according to Nielsen data released on Monday.

headline: Wall Street at Play (for Charity)
abstract: On Wednesday night, it felt like a sizable portion of Wall Street had moved uptown.

headline: Sallie Mae, Buyers Strike Deal on Waivers
abstract: The SLM Corporation, parent of the student lender Sallie Mae, and an investor group led by J. C. Flowers & Company agreed Wednesday to language enabling the company to operate without the oversight of investors while they battle in court over their collapsed $25 billion buyout.

headline: G.E. Sells $100 Million Stake in Genpact
abstract: General Electric, as part of its regular review of its portfolios, agreed to sell $100 million of Genpact shares in a private deal, the companies said late on Friday.

headline: Bain Taps New Chief for Yacht Builder
abstract: Bain Capital has appointed the former chief operating officer of Arcor, a German fixed-line telecommunications provider to run one of its portfolio companies.

headline: The Woman Who Shook Up Citi
abstract: Citigroup‘s stock closed Thursday down almost 7 percent, its lowest close in four years and about $15 billion of market value wiped out. And the primary driver was a report by CIBC analyst Meredith Whitney, who wrote in a report that the financial giant may need to cut its dividend or sell off assets to avoid a much larger loss.

headline: One Other Little Dance
abstract: With Google’s introduction of a cellphone operating system, it adds another front of competition with Apple, even though Eric Schmidt, Google’s chief executive, serves on Apple’s board.

headline: Tax-Bill Delay Cheers Venture Firms
abstract: Venture capitalists who feared getting caught up in a proposal to raise taxes on “carried interest” breathed a sigh of relief as the bill appeared to stall in Congress.

headline: Who Would Feel the Pain in a Buyout Slump
abstract: The Royal Bank of Scotland is the investment bank that is most heavily exposed to a potential downturn in the private equity industry, according to an analysis by Financial News.

headline: Investors Shrug Off Global Cash Injection
abstract: Market euphoria over trans-Atlantic action by central banks to fix the global credit crisis wore off quickly Thursday, with investors saying they expect the injection of cash to do little to solve long-term problems.

headline: Fraud-Buster Iovation Secures $10 Million from Intel Capital
abstract: Intel Capital, the venture capital arm of chip giant Intel, announced Thursday that it has injected $10 million into security company Iovation, which targets online fraud and abuse based on the identification and “reputation” of Net-enabled devices.

headline: Leno’s Producer: “It’s Going To Be Hard”
abstract: The shows are not certain what kinds of rules the Writers Guild might try to impose on the hosts, both of whom are members of the union.

headline: ArcelorMittal Buys Argentina’s Largest Steel Distributor
abstract: The steelmaker ArcelorMittal added another purchase to its South American buying spree on Tuesday, acquiring Argentina’s largest steel distributor M.T. Majdalani.

headline: Google’s Market Share Grows and Grows and Grows
abstract: Google’s share of the search market keeps growing, and no one seems willing to bet that will change soon.

headline: Appaloosa Continues to Fight Dana’s Centerbridge Deal
abstract: Appaloosa Management, the hedge fund, is willing to raise its offer for Dana, the auto parts maker going through bankruptcy proceedings, in the hopes of getting Dana to abandon a deal with a rival hedge fund, Centerbridge Capital Partners, and consider its alternate restructuring proposal, according to filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Indie Shorts on Channel 13
abstract: WNET — Channel 13, the public television station in New York City — will add independent and short films to its popular Saturday movie night beginning next week, Elizabeth Jensen reports.

headline: Morgan Stanley Said to Ready Sale of Spanish Unit
abstract: Morgan Stanley has put its private banking business in Spain up for sale with a price tag of up to 800 million euros ($1.2 billion), The Financial Times reported. The move is the latest sign that the investment bank is concentrating on super-wealthy clients.

headline: Why Merrill Will Ride Solo for Now
abstract: Though the news cycle now appears to have shifted to an E. Stanley O’Neal corporate death watch, some market observers are still parsing whether his firm, Merrill Lynch, makes for an attractive takeout target.

headline: Citi Warns of Big Drop in Earnings
abstract: Citigroup said Monday that it expects to report a 60 percent decline in third-quarter net income, as the giant bank was stung by turmoil in the mortgage-backed securities markets as well as a weakening consumer credit environment. Charles Prince, Citi’s chief executive, called the results a “clear disappointment.”

headline: Imeem Q&A: Competing in Music Through Community
abstract: Answering questions from Bits readers, Dalton Caldwell, the chief executive of Imeem, explains how the music-oriented social network plans to compete with MySpace, Facebook, and Apple.

headline: Countrywide Chief Is Said to Face S.E.C. Inquiry
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission has opened an informal investigation into the stock sales of the chief executive of Countrywide Financial, The New York Times reported, the latest problem to hit the struggling mortgage lender.

headline: Filling in the Leadership Gaps at Merrill and Citi
abstract: Citigroup and Merrill Lynch are in uneviable positions right now, scrambling to find new leaders at the same time.

headline: French racing car drivers and the number four
abstract: Alain Prost was the first French world champion Formula One driver – and then he won four titles….

headline: ‘Moonlight,’ ‘Gossip Girl,’ ‘Big Bang Theory’ Show Momentum
abstract: In a press release from CBS projecting that it would finish in first place among total viewers for the November ratings “sweeps” period, this sentence stands out:

headline: Prince Walid: Citi’s Surprise Losses Were ‘Unacceptable’
abstract: A major player in the Shakespearean fall of Charles O. Prince III has gone public with his view of the saga.

headline: UBS Begins Legal Advisory League Table
abstract: The banking giant UBS has started a radical review of its global legal advisers in an attempt to slash costs and become one of the first top financial institutions to formally grade law firm performance.

headline: Law Firm Bonuses: The Last Hurrah?
abstract: It’s a great time to be a young lawyer at a top firm. Or is it?

headline: The Year in Technology M&A
abstract: Microsoft, Oracle, I.B.M. and a host of private equity firms helped drive technology mergers and acquisitions to a fourth consecutive record year in 2007. The introduction to The 451 Group’s Technology M&A Outlook report lists the year’s significant deals, identifies M&A drivers and looks at the outlook for 2008.

headline: Fed to Inject $8 Billion to Lubricate Economy
abstract: Seeking to reassure banks amid the continuing credit crisis, the Federal Reserve said Monday that it would provide $8 billion in funds to ease concerns about lending during the holiday season.

headline: Latest Salvo from the Studios: Strike Is ‘Beginning To Cause Serious Economic Damage’
abstract: The Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers wants to take the high road, at least in public, in its continuing dispute with the Writers Guild of America.

headline: Eton Park Buys Stake in $20 Billion Indian Mutual Fund
abstract: Eton Park Capital Management , a hedge fund founded by Eric Mindich, a former partner at Goldman Sachs, has agreed to buy a 5 percent stake in Reliance Capital Asset Management, in a deal that for the first time puts a value on India’s largest mutual fund.

headline: Thain Plans Cultural Changes at Merrill
abstract: John Thain, who begins his new job as Merrill Lynch‘s chief executive on Monday, told The Financial Times that he wants to remake Merrill’s management culture to look more like that of Goldman Sachs, where he once worked.

headline: Harbinger Takes Stake in U.S. Steel
abstract: An activist hedge fund firm, Harbinger Capital, which has about $12 billion in assets under management, has taken a sizable stake in U.S. Steel. According to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Harbinger now owns 6.75 million shares of U.S. Steel. That comes to about 5.7 percent of the company.

headline: Dimon and Prince: Who’s Laughing Now?
abstract: It is one of Wall Street’s most closely scrutinized — and perhaps most Shakespearean — rivalries. The two men run two of the biggest banks in the United States, each presiding over a vast financial empire of consumer banking, investment banking, credit card services and asset management.

headline: Carried-Interest Tax Provision Defeated
abstract: House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Charles Rangel agreed to drop a proposed tax increase on “carried interest,” a measure bitterly opposed by the private equity and hedge fund industries, from hotly disputed tax legislation. “Score one for the barbarians,” The New York Post wrote, noting the intense lobbying from the largest buyout firms that helped defeat the measure, at least for now.

headline: Opponents Of Google’s DoubleClick Deal Threaten Lawsuit
abstract: A coalition opposing Google‘s $3.1 billion merger with DoubleClick renewed charges of conflicts and threatened possible legal action over a decision by a regulatory chairman not to recuse herself from reviewing the merger.

headline: Consortium Wins Control of ABN Amro
abstract: The Royal Bank of Scotland Group, Banco Santander and Fortis won control of ABN Amro, the biggest Dutch bank, after its shareholders backed a buyout bid valued at 71.9 billion euros ($101 billion).

headline: Macquarie Adds More Honey to Its Techem Bid
abstract: Australia’s Macquarie Bank has again raised its offer for Techem, the German-listed provider of utility metering services that it has been trying to acquire for a year.

headline: Strike Makes Networks Rethink Programming
abstract: “Now in its seventh week, the Writers Guild of America walkout has forced producers to reconsider how shows are developed, the type of shows produced and how they’re sold to advertisers,” the Associated Press reports.

headline: Evercore’s Adjusted Profits Rose in 3rd Quarter
abstract: Evercore Partners, the boutique investment bank, said Thursday that its adjusted pro forma net income was $9.8 million in the quarter ended Sept. 30, up from $8.8 million a year earlier.

headline: ‘Today’ at the Ends of the Earth
abstract: Ann Curry, the news anchor for NBC’s “Today” show, donned a red parka and sunglasses early this morning and prepared for a highly unusual live shot.

headline: SABMiller Taps Grolsch in $1.2 Billion Deal
abstract: SABMiller, the world’s second-biggest brewer, has agreed to buy a Dutch rival, Grolsch, for 816 million euros ($1.2 billion) to strengthen its position in the fast-growing premium beer market.

headline: Hedge Fund Counter-Sues Fairfax Financial
abstract: A hedge fund has filed a counter-claim against an insurer, Fairfax Financial Holdings, and its law firm for defamation and using private investigators to harass its employees.

headline: Ratings: ‘House,’ ‘Dancing’ And The Bachelor’s Final Rose
abstract: Charlie Brown and the semifinal results on “Dancing With the Stars” delivered solid ratings for ABC on Tuesday, but the shows were no match for the eccentric doctor on Fox. “House” earned the night’s top ratings among adults 18 to 49, according to Nielsen’s estimates, making Fox first for the night in that demographic.

headline: Teachers Buys Glass Lewis for $46 Million
abstract: The Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan has bought Glass Lewis, a San Francisco-based investment research, proxy advisory and voting services firm, for $46 million from its Chinese owner, Xinhua Finance of Shanghai.

headline: A Different Formula for a Biogen Deal
abstract: Will DNA get mixed up in a sale of Biogen Idec?

headline: A Toast to the Top Women in Banking
abstract: At a gathering to toast the most powerful women in banking, there was a generally sense that despite some important inroads, more work was to be done.

headline: Schlumberger Offers $679 Million for Eastern Echo
abstract: Schlumberger, the oil-field services company, bid up to $679 million for a Norwegian-listed company, Eastern Echo, on Tuesday to expand its seismic operations at a time when record oil prices are driving demand.

headline: Ex-Chief Considers Bid for Children’s Place
abstract: Shares of Children’s Place rose 6 percent Monday after the company’s recently ousted chief executive and its largest shareholder, said he might put together an offer to buy the retailer.

headline: Perelman Seeks $500 Million ‘Blank Check’
abstract: MAFS Acquisition, a blank-check company led by billionaire financier Ronald O. Perelman, filed with regulators to raise as much as $500 million to fund an acquisition.

headline: Wary of Risk, Bankers Sold Shaky Mortgage Debt
abstract: As the subprime loan crisis deepens, Wall Street firms are increasingly coming under scrutiny for their role in selling risky mortgage-related securities to investors.

headline: A Dark-Horse Candidate for Citi’s Top Job?
abstract: Since last month, Citigroup has struggled to find a replacement for Charles O. Prince III, its recently resigned chief executive. It has looked inside the sprawling financial giant; it has examined the firm’s alumni (some of whom left the firm unwillingly); it has cast its eyes on the top executives of its rivals.

headline: Female Directors Earn More Than Men, Study Finds
abstract: A new survey on corporate board pay has come up with a surprising find: The median compensation for female directors is actually higher than that for male directors.

headline: They Told You So
abstract: By PETER EDMONSTON

headline: For Angels, the ‘Sidecar’ Gains Prominence
abstract: Until recently, “angel” investors were regarded as detached from the companies they backed, wealthy amateurs who dropped in between rounds of golf to cut checks and rub elbows with entrepreneurs.

headline: CBS Announces Revised Schedule, Including Winter Edition of ‘Big Brother’
abstract: On Monday, two broadcast networks, CBS and NBC, gave the clearest indication to date of how their programming schedules were being affected by the four-week writers’ strike. CBS said it would introduce several new reality shows and midseason replacements beginning in January, including the first winter season ever of the reality show “Big Brother.”

headline: Kerkorian Decries Tesoro’s ‘Poison Pill’
abstract: Tracinda, Kirk Kerkorian’s investment company, said Monday that a decision by the refiner Tesoro to adopt a “poison pill” shareholder rights plan could jeopardize its offer to buy 16 percent of Tesoro’s shares.

headline: The ‘Lucky Strike Extra’ Hits the Modern Era
abstract: The efforts by Madison Avenue to counter ad-skipping has revived a pervasive ploy from the early days of the medium as well as from the “golden age” of radio: integrating products into the plots of programs, a practice known as branded entertainment.

headline: Approaching Panic
abstract: The financial guarantors are the latest object of fear and loathing on Wall Street. They have guaranteed zillions of dollars of obligations, and some of them are not going to work out well.

headline: Vivendi to Acquire Activision
abstract: Vivendi said Sunday that it planned to acquire a controlling stake in Activision in a deal that creates a rival to Electronic Arts as the world’s largest independent video game publisher.

headline: Odyssey Runs Aground With Spanish Authorities
abstract: Odyssey Marine Exploration, whose largest shareholders include the hedge funds GLG Partners and the Fortress Investment Group, is once again confronting some stormy seas. On Tuesday a Spanish military vessel intercepted one of the Florida treasure hunter’s ships as it was trying to leave the port city of Algeciras, forced it back into port, and arrested its captain, Sterling Vorgus.

headline: Multitasking We Don’t Want to Know About
abstract: A new survey reveals how often professionals working at home are multitasking.

headline: SMG to Raise $200 Million in Rights Issue
abstract: SMG, a Scottish broadcasting company, will raise 95.1 million pounds ($200 million) in an attempt to lower its debt load and avert a fire sale of Virgin Radio.

headline: A Day of Robots, Rocket Cycles and Lasers
abstract: Gadgetoff was the festival of the future that never was.

headline: The Dangers of Generalizing About the Generations
abstract: A look at the problem of generalizing about the generations.

headline: Wall Street TV Is Primed for Another Season
abstract: A cable reality show celebrating the lives and lifestyles of Wall Street is coming back for more.

headline: Deal Chatter 2007: What Got You Talking
abstract: DealBook will be publishing only intermittently throughout the holidays. We’ll be up and running on our normal schedule beginning Jan. 2.

headline: Helixis Nabs $10 Million
abstract: Molecular diagnostic equipment developer Helixis completed a $10 million Series A funding round from Advanced Technology Ventures, Okapi Venture Capital and Domain Associates that will allow the new company to move technology developed at the California Institute of Technology into the market as early as 2009.

headline: Ratings: Democratic Debate v. ‘Supernatural’
abstract: For the second consecutive week, CBS edged past ABC on Thursday to lead the night’s ratings in both total viewers and among adults 18 to 49. Although “Grey’s Anatomy” remained No. 1 in that demographic, giving ABC a strong second place finish overall, CBS proved more consistent throughout the night.

headline: UBS Shares Rise on Speculation of Stake Sale
abstract: Shares in UBS powered higher on Wednesday on speculation that Asian or Gulf-based investors might target European banks whose stock has weakened in the wake of the subprime crisis. The speculation was prompted by Citigroup‘s $7.5 billion stake sale to Abu Dhabi’s sovereign wealth fund.

headline: A Thanksgiving Blessing
abstract: Happy Thanksgiving. Now put down those Blackberries.

headline: Analyst Predicts More Write-Downs for Merrill
abstract: After reporting a whopping $8.4 billion write-down in the third quarter that led to the ouster of its chief executive, one analyst is predicting more pain for Merrill Lynch.

headline: V.C.’s See More Consolidation Ahead
abstract: The venture capital industry will consolidate in 2008.

headline: Sour Ratings Sink CW’s ‘Online Nation’
abstract: In Nielsen’s most recent weekly ranking of broadcast television programs, the CW’s “Online Nation” is firmly positioned at the bottom.

headline: Fannie Mae Seeks to Raise $7 Billion in Stock Sale
abstract: Like her brother Freddie Mac, Fannie Mae, the mortgage finance company, said Tuesday that it would sell $7 billion of preferred stock and cut its dividend 30 percent to shore up its capital base through 2008 as the housing slump worsens.

headline: Beyond Sheep-Throwing: Rhapsody on Facebook
abstract: The new Facebook application for the Rhapsody music service shows some of the advantages of integrating powerful applications into Facebook’s environment.

headline: Lone Star’s Del Frisco to Tap Public Markets
abstract: Del Frisco’s Restaurant Group has filed for an initial public offering worth up to $100 million, providing liquidity for its current owner, Lone Star Funds of Dallas.

headline: $75 Billion SIV Is Seen as Stopgap
abstract: Nearly three weeks after the country’s biggest banks announced a $75 billion fund to help stabilize the credit markets, the reality is sinking in that the plan will provide hospice care to troubled investment funds, not resuscitate them.

headline: Lufthansa to Buy 19% Stake in JetBlue
abstract: Update: Lufthansa will pay about $305 million for a stake of up to 19 percent in JetBlue, the two companies announced Thursday afternoon. Lufthansa will buy 42 million newly issued shares at $7.27 each. It will also name a director to JetBlue’s board, who will be up for reelection next year.

headline: Rockies Rebound After Virtual Pummeling
abstract: The Colorado Rockies take two days to revive their ticket-sales Web site after it crashes from the weight of fans and potential scalpers.

headline: Agrium and UAP to Merge in $2.16 Billion Deal
abstract: Agrium, the third-largest fertilizer producer in Canada and the United States, agreed to buy UAP for about $2.16 billion to boost sales of crop products as demand rises.

headline: Ratings: Game Two? Not So Much.
abstract: Fox’s coverage of Game 2 of the World Series on Thursday attracted fewer viewers than Wednesday’s opening game, but the network still led the night’s ratings overall. Although exact figures for the live broadcast’s audience could not be derived from Nielsen’s overnight estimates, the data suggested that Boston’s second win in the series earned ratings about 10 percent below those for Game 1, which attracted 16.9 million viewers in Nielsen’s final tally.

headline: Overstock Tumbles
abstract: If you’re a retailer, Christmas is when you clean up. If not, you may need a new business model.

headline: Which Virtualization Deals May Be Next
abstract: Virtualization is hot, as shown by VMware‘s impressive I.P.O. in August. The 451 Group is following four vendors of second-generation virtualization technology that could become takeover targets for big vendors wanting to stake their turf in this area.

headline: AOL to Buy Israeli Start-Up, Report Says
abstract: Time Warner‘s AOL unit plans to pay $300 million for an Israeli advertising start-up, Quigo, in a move to compete better with Google and Yahoo, an Israeli newspaper report said.

headline: The People Inside Google’s Black Box
abstract: A top Google scientist confirms what has been rumored for years: the company improves its search engine by asking thousands of part-time workers to rate Web sites.

headline: Images From the Picket Lines
Stuff I’m Reading and Liking
abstract: This week’s reading roundup includes Senator John Kerry on small business, the economics of strikes and a love story that’s affecting a career.

headline: The Pros and Cons of the LG8700 Cellphone
abstract: Well, it’s finally happened: I’ve run out of things to review. Yes, every computer, camera, camcorder, Web site, music player and phone—done.

headline: Buffett and CarMax: Less Than Meets the Eye?
abstract: Four times a year, fans of Warren Buffett — and there are a lot of them — rush to see which stocks his Berkshire Hathaway has bought in the latest quarter, in hopes of getting a good investment tip or two. Last week, there was a flurry of excitement about CarMax, the seller of used cars, because it appeared that the legendary investor had added nearly 14 million CarMax shares to his portfolio. That was enough to send CarMax’s stock price soaring 7.5 percent in much heavier-than-normal trading.

headline: Convicted Bayou Executive in Fight Over Sentencing
abstract: Federal prosecutors and defense attorneys for one of the men involved in the notorious $450 million Bayou hedge fund swindle are locked in a bitter pre-sentencing battle of claims and motions over how much time he should spend in prison.

headline: Merrill’s Chief Is Said to Consider a Bid to Merge
abstract: Facing billions of dollars in losses from the subprime mortgage crisis, Merrill Lynch chairman and chief executive, E. Stanley O’Neal, floated the idea of a merger with a large bank, a foray that angered Merrill’s board and could cost him his job, according to The New York Times.

headline: Ventana Opens Its Books to Roche
abstract: Roche‘s $3 billion bid to acquire Ventana Medical Systems seemed to take a friendlier turn on Tuesday when the two sides struck a confidentiality agreement.

headline: Spain’s Colonial Says It Held Merger Talks With French Rival
abstract: Spanish property company Inmobiliaria Colonial has held preliminary merger talks with French real estate firm Gecina, but no formal deal is on the table, it said on Friday.

headline: Rubenstein Buys Copy of Magna Carta
abstract: David M. Rubenstein, chief of the private equity firm Carlyle Group, did some serious holiday shopping on Tuesday — but he won’t be taking his purchase, a 710-year-old copy of the Magna Carta, home with him. Though Mr. Rubenstein won the auction for the document with a $19 million bid ($21.3 million with fees and commissions), he told reporters he was just a “temporary custodian” of the historic piece of parchment, which David Redden, Sotheby’s vice chairman, called “the most important document in the world, the birth certificate of freedom.”

headline: Singapore Sets Out to Lure Hedge Funds
abstract: Singapore, striving to become the Switzerland of Asia, is gung-ho on hedge funds, The Deal.com reports. Leading the charge is the Singapore government, which has crafted regulations that both streamline the process for establishing funds and give fund managers some juicy tax breaks when they’re up and running. It’s now possible to open a fund in just weeks.

headline: Citi Lays Off 30 C.D.O. Bankers: The Internal Memo
abstract: From Eric Dash, a DealBook colleague

headline: Oh, Lord: Sallie Mae’s Conference Call
abstract: Albert L. Lord may have just learned a nearly $3 billion lesson.

headline: Verizon to Put Executive Pay to Shareholder Vote
abstract: Directors at Verizon Communications, under fire from shareholders over executive pay practices, said Thursday that they would put the company’s compensation plans to an annual vote by investors beginning at its general meeting in 2009.

headline: Shoe Seller Steven Madden to Review Options
abstract: Steven Madden Ltd., a designer and seller of trendy footwear, said Friday it would review its strategic alternatives after receiving “inquiries from third parties with respect to an acquisition of the company.”

headline: Cheatsheet: Online Ad Spending to Slow
abstract: By 2011, eMarketer predicts, $42 billion will be spent in advertising online. That will only be a 12 percent increase from 2010, compared to a growth rate next year of 29 percent. Social networks won’t get much of that money, but video sites and mobile phones will.

headline: Pearl to Buy Resolution in British Insurance Merger
abstract: Pearl Assurance, the British closed-life fund manager, on Friday agreed to acquire a rival, Resolution, for 4.98 billion pounds ($10.21 billion), after a competing bid from a traditional insurer, Standard Life, collapsed the previous weekend.

headline: Universal’s Imeem Deal May Unlock More Free Music
abstract: With the addition of Universal Music Group, Imeem, a social network, can now let users listen to nearly any song they want on their computers. This may be the breakthrough the music industry needs: Streaming songs will be free with advertising, but downloading to keep will require payment.

headline: Google’s DoubleClick Deal Expected to Win Approval
abstract: Antitrust experts predict that Google‘s purchase of the advertising company DoubleClick for $3.1 billion will be approved by regulators despite vehement opposition from competitors Microsoft and Yahoo, Reuters reported.

headline: Consorte Media Gets $7 Million Round
abstract: Consorte Media, a Hispanic online media company, said Monday that it received $7 million in a round of venture investment led by Sutter Hill Ventures. The Series B round also included the Mayfield Fund, a return investor.

headline: I’ve Got Ads that Jingle, Jangle, Jingle
abstract: For some years, jingles — original music written for television (and radio) commercials — have been out of favor. Madison Avenue has preferred to use or adapt hit rock or pop songs that consumers already know, particularly if they appeal to certain generations like baby boomers.

headline: BHP Considers Next Move in Rio Tinto Bid
abstract: BHP Billiton said on Wednesday it was considering possible next moves in its attempt to open takeover talks with a rival mining company, Rio Tinto, which has so far rebuffed its overtures.

headline: 3 Buyout Firms Said to Hold Sales Talks with China
abstract: The race for the next big Chinese investment in private equity is on.

headline: Morgan Stanley Settlement Is Approved
abstract: A federal judge on Thursday approved a $46 million settlement of a class-action lawsuit filed by a group of women alleging gender discrimination by their employer, the investment bank Morgan Stanley.

headline: The Web Is Overrun With Elves
abstract: OfficeMax has a holiday hit on its hands once again with ElfYourself.com.

headline: Behind Lehman’s Asian Expansion
abstract: Analysts looking for signs of how Asia’s business landscape is developing need look no further than the changes afoot at Lehman Brothers‘ operations in the region, according to The Financial Times.

headline: Will IAC Breakup Bring Peace Between Moguls?
abstract: Barry Diller is splitting IAC/InterActiveCorp into five parts, but will that be enough to end the tensions between Mr. Diller and his old partner, John C. Malone?

headline: On Bonuses, Banks Face a Balancing Act
abstract: For an object lesson in the dilemma facing investment banks these days, consider Cowen Group. Late Monday, the boutique investment bank said it had decided to raise the amount of its revenue set aside for compensation and benefits to 65 percent from 60 percent. On Tuesday, Cowen’s stock slumped more than 10 percent.

headline: Hilfiger Investors Plan ‘Blank-Check’ I.P.O.
abstract: Lawrence Stroll and Joel Horowitz, two early investors in the Tommy Hilfiger fashion empire, want to raise $250 million to go shopping for acquisitions.

headline: Teachers Buys Glass Lewis for $46 Million
abstract: The Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan has bought Glass Lewis, a San Francisco-based investment research, proxy advisory and voting services firm, for $46 million from its Chinese owner, Xinhua Finance of Shanghai.

headline: A Different Formula for a Biogen Deal
abstract: Will DNA get mixed up in a sale of Biogen Idec?

headline: A Toast to the Top Women in Banking
abstract: At a gathering to toast the most powerful women in banking, there was a generally sense that despite some important inroads, more work was to be done.

headline: Schlumberger Offers $679 Million for Eastern Echo
abstract: Schlumberger, the oil-field services company, bid up to $679 million for a Norwegian-listed company, Eastern Echo, on Tuesday to expand its seismic operations at a time when record oil prices are driving demand.

headline: Ex-Chief Considers Bid for Children’s Place
abstract: Shares of Children’s Place rose 6 percent Monday after the company’s recently ousted chief executive and its largest shareholder, said he might put together an offer to buy the retailer.

headline: Perelman Seeks $500 Million ‘Blank Check’
abstract: MAFS Acquisition, a blank-check company led by billionaire financier Ronald O. Perelman, filed with regulators to raise as much as $500 million to fund an acquisition.

headline: Wary of Risk, Bankers Sold Shaky Mortgage Debt
abstract: As the subprime loan crisis deepens, Wall Street firms are increasingly coming under scrutiny for their role in selling risky mortgage-related securities to investors.

headline: A Dark-Horse Candidate for Citi’s Top Job?
abstract: Since last month, Citigroup has struggled to find a replacement for Charles O. Prince III, its recently resigned chief executive. It has looked inside the sprawling financial giant; it has examined the firm’s alumni (some of whom left the firm unwillingly); it has cast its eyes on the top executives of its rivals.

headline: Female Directors Earn More Than Men, Study Finds
abstract: A new survey on corporate board pay has come up with a surprising find: The median compensation for female directors is actually higher than that for male directors.

headline: They Told You So
abstract: By PETER EDMONSTON

headline: The Year of Puncturing Wall Street Orthodoxy
abstract: Never in the history of Wall Street have so many who are so senior fallen so fast.

headline: Bear Stearns to Take $1.2 Billion Write-Down
abstract: Bear Stearns will write down the value of its subprime-related assets by $1.2 billion in the fourth quarter, Chief Financial Officer Sam Molinaro said at a Merrill Lynch conference on Wednesday.

headline: A New Nielsen Rule Boosts NBC’s ‘Heroes’
abstract: Thanks to a change in the Nielsen ratings system that worked to the benefit of “Heroes,” NBC was able to share a premiere week win with ABC in the coveted demographic of 18- to 49-year-old viewers.Using a new Nielsen ratings rule, NBC combined the Monday debut and the Saturday repeat of “Heroes,” thus allowing it to eliminate the low-rated Saturday hour from the weekly averages. As a result, NBC and ABC both averaged 5.1 million viewers in the demographic last week.

headline: Sirius Optimistic About XM Deal
abstract: Sirius Satellite Radio remains hopeful that it can close its acquisition of XM Satellite Radio by the end of the year, as the Department of Justice has “little left to do” to complete its review of the proposed transaction, Sirius Chief Financial Officer David Frear told investors on Tuesday.

headline: Deputy Mayor to Head to Bloomberg L.P.
abstract: From our colleagues at City Room:

headline: Close Brothers Spurns $2.9 Billion Buyout Offer
abstract: The Close Brothers Group, a 129-year-old British investment bank, rejected a 1.4 billion pound ($2.9 billion) cash offer from Cenkos Securities and a partner, Landsbanki Islands.

headline: Wave of Pink Slips Expected in London’s City
abstract: Thousands of financial professionals in London are likely to lose their jobs over the next year as a result of the credit crunch, and many of them may face a jobless Christmas, experts say.

headline: Sallie Mae Executive Chairman to Resume C.E.O. Role
abstract: Sallie Mae, the giant student lender whose $25 billion buyout is all but dead, said after the market closed on Friday that its executive chairman would again take up the role of chief executive.

headline: Questions We Thought, But Didn’t Ask, in 2007
abstract: As the year ends, we ask the questions that perplex us the most.

headline: Hearst Takes Stake in MediaNews in Newspaper Swap
abstract: MediaNews Groupsaid Monday that Hearst had bought a stake in the company for $317 million as part of a complex deal between the two privately held publishers involving several San Francisco-area newspapers.

headline: Lehman’s 4th-Quarter Profit Falls but Beats Expectations
abstract: Lehman Brothers reported a decline in fourth-quarter profit on Thursday, the first sign of the toll that subprime mortgages will take on investment banks for the quarter. But the firm still managed to beat analysts’ expectations.

headline: Och-Ziff Sets I.P.O. Price Range
abstract: Och-Ziff Capital Management, the hedge-fund firm with nearly $30 billion in assets under management, set a price range of $30 to $33 a share for its proposed initial public offering of 36 million shares.

headline: For Thain, a Big Raise in Store
abstract: John Thain isn’t just moving to a new company. He’s moving to a whole new pay scale.

headline: Citi to Buy Rest of Nikko for $4.6 Billion
abstract: Citigroup has signed an agreement to acquire all of Nikko Cordial, Japan’s third-largest brokerage, paying about $4.6 billion for the 32 percent it does not already own.

headline: Fortis Plans $3.7 Billion Bond Sale to Fund ABN Deal
abstract: Fortis, part of the group that bought ABN Amro in Europe’s biggest-ever banking takeover, is raising 2.5 billion euros ($3.7 billion) by selling bonds convertible into shares to help pay for the purchase.

headline: Merging Law Firms Unveil Executive Board
abstract: LeBoeuf Lamb Greene & MacRae and Dewey Ballantine unveilezd last week the makeup of the 22-member executive board that will oversee the running of the combined firm when their merger becomes effective Monday.

headline: One Reason We Need a Google Phone: Free GPS
abstract: Consumers spent $60 million in the second quarter to use navigation features built into their cellphones. Google could offer this feature free.

headline: Black Denies Seeking Move to U.K. Prison
abstract: Conrad Black denied reports that he would seek to serve his prison sentence in a British jail, which would likely let him out on parole earlier than a U.S. facility, The New York Post reported Friday.

headline: BEA Names Its Own Price
abstract: To talk to BEA Systems about a takeover, be prepared to offer at least $21 a share.

headline: Sale of Wendy’s May Be Delayed
abstract: The auction of Wendy’s International may be in jeopardy because of continued turmoil in the credit markets, potentially forcing the company to delay its sale, The New York Times reported.

headline: Barrick Strikes Deal for Arizona Star Resource
abstract: Canada’s Barrick Gold, the world’s largest gold miner, has agreed to pay 773 million Canadian dollars ($808 million dollars) for Arizona Star Resource, which owns 51 percent of Chile’s Cerro Casale deposit, one of the world’s largest undeveloped gold and copper deposits.

headline: Capital Pours Out
abstract: If you spend the money, they will lend it.

headline: General Motors Wants Stake in Russia’s AvtoVaz
abstract: General Motors is bidding for a stake in Russia’s largest carmaker as part of an effort to expand its presence in that rapidly growing market, a G.M. spokesman confirmed Tuesday.

headline: No Buzz for Sprint After Private Equity Approach
abstract: Are potential suitors burning up the phone lines at Sprint Nextel? At least one analyst doesn’t think so, and investors seem to have their doubts as well.

headline: What’s On Tonight: “30 Rock” and “Criminal Intent”
abstract: “Fresh from winning an Emmy Award for best comedy after only one season, ‘30 Rock’ returns to NBC for its second with a slight case of opening-night jitters,” Alessandra Stanley writes in today’s Times. “The premiere tonight has many funny moments but strains too hard to meet heightened expectations: NBC even brought Jerry Seinfeld in to play himself.”

headline: Abu Dhabi to Invest $700 Million for A.M.D. Stake
abstract: A day after a report surfaced that New York hedge fund Galleon Group has purchased “several million shares” of  Advanced Micro Devices, the U.S. chipmaker looks set to get another large investor.

headline: Zucker Dismisses NBC Sale Rumors
abstract: NBC Universal‘s chief executive, Jeffrey Zucker, dismissed repeated rumors on Monday that the media company would be sold by parent, General Electric.

headline: Stuff I’m Reading Lately
abstract: This week’s reading list includes tips for answering interview questions, entrepreneurs taking kids to work and a tool for staying on top of your reading.

headline: At CW, Overbearing Mothers Share the Stage
abstract: The CW will use the finale of its top-rated show, “America’s Next Top Model,” to launch a new reality show about a mother/daughter beauty pageant competition next month, the network announced on Monday.

headline: Madison Dearborn Closes on Nuveen Deal
abstract: Nuveen Investments said Tuesday afternoon that it has formally been acquired for $5.75 billion by an investing group led by private equity firm Madison Dearborn Capital Partners.

headline: Terra Firma Recuts EMI Deal, Report Says
abstract: Terra Firma is already trying to trim its equity stake in EMI amid a major strategic review of the music company’s business that could result in big changes, including a possible sale of its physical distribution business, The New York Post reported citing unnamed sources.

headline: Conan O’Brien, Unscripted
abstract: “NBC ran a rerun of “Late Night with Conan O’Brien” on Wednesday night during the ongoing writers’ strike, but it was still possible for a select few to see the host do an original monologue,” Jacques Steinberg reports.

headline: Promethus Brakes for Porta-Jon
abstract: Prometheus Partners of Atlanta has acquired a portable restroom supplier, Porta-Jon from Piedmont as part of a rollup plan. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

headline: GainSpain Closes $20 Million Round
abstract: GainSpan, which focuses on Wi-Fi sensor network technology, said it completed a $20 million second round of funding led by Opus Capital.

headline: Should Bank Regulators Force Writedowns?
abstract: My column today offers what seemed to me — after I heard it from Bob Barbera, the economist quoted in the piece — to be an obvious explanation of why we should have been suspicious of bank profit reports before the current crisis blew up.

headline: Eaton Bulks Up with Moeller, Phoenixtec Deals
abstract: Eaton, the world’s second-largest maker of hydraulic equipment, will buy Moeller Group of Germany and Phoenixtec Power Company of Taiwan for about $2.8 billion as revenue growth in the United States slows.

headline: Vivox Scores $7.8 Million
abstract: Vivox, an online gaming and virtual community infrastructure developer, raised $7.8 million in a second round led by Benchmark Capital to accelerate expansion of sophisticated multiplayer communications services using voice-over-Internet-protocol technology.

headline: Temasek Raises Stake in Indonesia’s Sorak Financial
abstract: Temasek, the Singapore state investment agency, said Thursday that it raised its stake in Sorak Financial, the main shareholder in Bank Internasional Indonesia, from just over 50 percent to 75 percent.

headline: Google Doesn’t Know Where You Are (But It Has a Good Guess)
abstract: A new feature to Google’s cellphone mapping service can figure out more or less sort of where you are. It’s got some slick technology to help it figure that out.

headline: Australian Gaming Concern Bets $1.8 Billion on Cannery Casino
abstract: Crown, an Australian gaming group, has agreed to pay $1.8 billion in cash to acquire Cannery Casino Resorts, which operates three Las Vegas gambling halls as well as a racetrack and casino in Pennsylvania.

headline: Lagardere May Go Private, Report Says
abstract: French defense and media conglomerate Lagardere may have had enough of the life of a publicly-listed company.

headline: CBS Captures Sunday Night
abstract: The twelfth edition of “The Amazing Race” got underway to solid ratings on Sunday as CBS garnered the night’s most viewers overall.

headline: Short Answers from Facebook’s Mark Zuckerberg
abstract: Facebook C.E.O. Mark Zuckerberg answers some questions at today’s Web 2.0 conference.

headline: Sallie Mae Delays Stock Repurchase
abstract: The parent of Sallie Mae, which for years profited from placing large bets on its own stock going up, now faces a possible loss of more than $1 billion as the bet has gone drastically wrong. On Thursday it negotiated a two-month delay in the deadline for coming up with the money.

headline: Questioning Blodget’s Comeback
abstract: Henry Blodget, the former Internet analyst who was barred from the securities industry after the tech bust, is getting what MarketWatch’s David Weidner considers to be an undeserved “redemption tour” by the media, including DealBook’s special section in The New York Times.

headline: Nina
abstract: Chalk up one more term from the credit debacle.

headline: 3M Buys Aearo Technologies for $1.2 Billion
abstract: 3M said Thursday that it will acquire Aearo Technologies, a maker of personal protection like hearing and eye protectors, from British buyout firm Permira for $1.2 billion in cash. The deal will be financed by a combination of cash on hand and debt.

headline: Facebook Everywhere
abstract: Once the company gets the bugs out of its system for social ads on its own site, Facebook will likely create a network to use its data to display advertising on other sites.

headline: The Surprises Keep Coming
abstract: It was less than two weeks ago that Swiss Re reported third-quarter earnings, and gave reassuring statistics about its exposure to subprime paper.

headline: Sibir Energy to Move to L.S.E.
abstract: Sibir Energy, the Russia-focused oil and gas company and the Alternative Investment Market’s largest stock, is planning to move to the London Stock Exchange after more than doubling profits on the back of strong production from its main fields.

headline: Concern Arises Over Alibaba’s I.P.O. Pricing
abstract: Alibaba.com is seeking to raise as much as $1.49 billion in an initial public offering after raising the price range to between 12 Hong Kong dollars and 13.50 Hong Kong dollars ($1.55 to $1.74) a share.

headline: Lawyer Sues Over iPhone’s Little White List
abstract: A federal suit claims Apple’s restrictions on the iPhone violate antitrust law and its recent software update is illegal trespass.

headline: Morning Ratings: For Another $10,000, Ann Curry Won’t Use the Bungee Cord
abstract: For a few weeks in October, executives at NBC were worried about their perennially top-rated “Today” show.

headline: Hedge Fund Urges Delta-United Merger
abstract: Long-simmering talk of an inevitable round of airline industry mergers heated up again Wednesday. But by the end of the day, after a spike in their share prices, the central players in any merger talks, dismissed the rumors as just that.

headline: RWE Postpones U.S. I.P.O.
abstract: RWE, Germany’s second-largest power company, on Wednesday postponed the initial public offering of its American Water business due to market turmoil in the United States, forcing it to abandon plans for a share buyback and significant increase in its dividend.

headline: Morgan Stanley to Take Stake in Sapporo
abstract: Morgan Stanley plans to take up to a 5 percent stake in Japan’s third-biggest beer maker, Sapporo, and work with it in the real estate business.

headline: Specific Media Raises $100 Million in Second Round
abstract: In a second round of funding, Specific Media has raised $100 million from private equity firm Francisco Partners. TheDeal.com writes that the funds will be used to fuel acquisitions and an initial public offering of the online advertising agency.

headline: S.E.C. Looks Into Merrill’s Subprime Holdings
abstract: Merrill Lynch disclosed on Wednesday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had begun an inquiry into its mortgage-related holdings. It also said that its total exposure to mortgage-related securities is $27.2 billion, or $6.3 billion more than what it said last month.

headline: Delphi Gets Exit Financing From Citigroup and JPMorgan
abstract: Bankrupt Delphi has revealed the lending group that has agreed to provide close to $7 billion to help the insolvent auto parts maker emerge from court protection.

headline: Yahoo Shuffles Yet More Executives
abstract: Yahoo has consolidated its media unit under Scott Moore, who had run the news, sports and finance half of its operation in Santa Monica. Vince Brody, who ran the other half, devoted entertainment, is looking for a new role in the company.

headline: Teachers Buys Glass Lewis for $46 Million
abstract: The Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan has bought Glass Lewis, a San Francisco-based investment research, proxy advisory and voting services firm, for $46 million from its Chinese owner, Xinhua Finance of Shanghai.

headline: A Different Formula for a Biogen Deal
abstract: Will DNA get mixed up in a sale of Biogen Idec?

headline: A Toast to the Top Women in Banking
abstract: At a gathering to toast the most powerful women in banking, there was a generally sense that despite some important inroads, more work was to be done.

headline: Schlumberger Offers $679 Million for Eastern Echo
abstract: Schlumberger, the oil-field services company, bid up to $679 million for a Norwegian-listed company, Eastern Echo, on Tuesday to expand its seismic operations at a time when record oil prices are driving demand.

headline: Ex-Chief Considers Bid for Children’s Place
abstract: Shares of Children’s Place rose 6 percent Monday after the company’s recently ousted chief executive and its largest shareholder, said he might put together an offer to buy the retailer.

headline: Perelman Seeks $500 Million ‘Blank Check’
abstract: MAFS Acquisition, a blank-check company led by billionaire financier Ronald O. Perelman, filed with regulators to raise as much as $500 million to fund an acquisition.

headline: Wary of Risk, Bankers Sold Shaky Mortgage Debt
abstract: As the subprime loan crisis deepens, Wall Street firms are increasingly coming under scrutiny for their role in selling risky mortgage-related securities to investors.

headline: A Dark-Horse Candidate for Citi’s Top Job?
abstract: Since last month, Citigroup has struggled to find a replacement for Charles O. Prince III, its recently resigned chief executive. It has looked inside the sprawling financial giant; it has examined the firm’s alumni (some of whom left the firm unwillingly); it has cast its eyes on the top executives of its rivals.

headline: Female Directors Earn More Than Men, Study Finds
abstract: A new survey on corporate board pay has come up with a surprising find: The median compensation for female directors is actually higher than that for male directors.

headline: They Told You So
abstract: By PETER EDMONSTON

headline: Parsons to Step Down as Time Warner C.E.O. Next January
abstract: Richard D. Parsons is about to have a lot of time on his hands.

headline: The Mysterious Assault on Fortress
abstract: Fortress Investment Group appears to have a hole in its castle walls. At least, that is the sense you get from its tumbling stock price.

headline: Fund Manager Said to Pay $46 Million for N.Y. Co-op
abstract: Real estate may be the source of Wall Street’s woes at the moment, but the top of the market appears to be humming right along.

headline: SunTrust Bails Out 2 Funds
abstract: SunTrust Banks, the large regional bank, said Thursday that it would take up to $400 million in fourth-quarter pretax write-downs, mainly from a bailout of two money market funds.

headline: Talent Pool Dries Up Just When Wall Street Needs It
abstract: Many new words and phrases have been added this year to the everyday lexicon of finance: subprime mortgages, collateralized debt obligations, structured investment vehicles and the ABX index. More recently, “Help Wanted: Wall Street C.E.O.” has joined the list.

headline: More Cuts at Cerberus-Owned Chrysler
abstract: Chrysler announced Thursday it would eliminate 11,000 hourly and salaried jobs in the United States and Canada and cut shifts of workers at five plants. The decision comes on top of a plan, announced in February, to eliminate 13,000 jobs and close a factory in Newark, Del. Taken together, Chrysler will be reducing its 2006 work force of about 80,000 employees by 30 percent.

headline: Talks Over Sale of Mitall Steel Mill in Fourth Month
abstract: The future of the Sparrows Point steel mill remains uncertain as negotiations between the proposed buyer, an international investment group, and the seller drag on for a fourth month.

headline: Avaya Shareholders OK $8.2 Billion Buyout
abstract: Avaya shareholders voted Friday to take the company private, selling it for $8.2 billion to Silver Lake and TPG, two private equity firms.

headline: Letterman Calls Deal The ‘Right Direction’
abstract: The Associated Press has published a statement from “Late Show” host David Letterman about today’s interim agreement with the writers guild:

headline: An Overhyped Role in Overheated Art Markets?
abstract: When the credit bubble popped this summer, many believed that the art bubble would burst as well. It was feared that as hedge fund managers felt the pain, so too would the auction houses.

headline: Founders Fund Continues Shake-Up of Silicon Valley
abstract: The Young Turks who made their mark as early backers of Facebook have raised a second investment round more than four times as large as their first, a move that seems to signal their growing clout as an alternative to venture capitalists on Silicon Valley’s Sand Hill Road.

headline: Cleantech Investors Keep One Eye on Washington
abstract: It’s the latest fashion in venture capital: investing in technologies — known as “cleantech” — that aim to reduce fossil fuel emissions or provide alternative energy sources.

headline: Tallying Activists’ Victories in 2007
abstract: Shareholder activists have been unusually vocal this year. But that doesn’t mean they’ve been more successful, a new report by Thomson Financial finds.

headline: Resolution and Pearl Continue Takeover Talks
abstract: Talks continued Thursday between British insurance firm Resolution and its suitor Pearl Group to hammer out a deal that will probably not significantly exceed the 4.9 billion pound ($10.2 billion), or 720 pence per share, offer already on the table.

headline: Brazilian Stock Exchange Raises $3.6 Billion
abstract: Bovespa Holding , owner of the Sao Paulo stock exchange, raised 6.63 billion reais ($3.69 billion) in Brazil’s biggest initial public offering in at least three years.

headline: “House” Is a Ratings Winner; “Cavemen” and “Cane” Are Not
abstract: Fox’s “House” once again delivered Tuesday’s top ratings, as the medical mystery show drew 17.3 million viewers at 9 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates, outperforming all other competition by a wide margin in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic.

headline: House Passes Rangel Bill on Carried Interest
abstract: A bill that would more than double the tax that private investment firms pay on their profits passed the U.S. House of Representatives Friday.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Engineers Deal for EYP
abstract: Hewlett-Packard agreed to buy EYP Mission Critical Facilities, a data center engineering firm, for an undisclosed sum in a deal that will provide an exit for TA Associates.

headline: Full Seasons for ‘Practice’ and ‘Bang’
abstract: Two rookie renewals to report this morning: ABC has ordered a full season of the “Grey’s Anatomy” spin-off “Private Practice” and CBS has ordered a full season of the freshman comedy “The Big Bang Theory.”

headline: AOL’s New Plan: It’s Not Working
abstract: Randy Falco is betting that AOL’s advertising network will turn the company around. But ad sales are slowing and the problems will continue through next year.
