headline: Facebook’s Rapid Stock Appreciation
abstract: The share price that Facebook has used for its employee stock options rose more than 30-fold between January 2006 and August 2007. It’s likely to experience another steep jump in value after Microsoft’s investment is factored in.

headline: DreamWorks Is Said to Hold Talks With NBC Universal
abstract: Seeking a way out of an acrimonious relationship at Paramount, the DreamWorks principals – two Hollywood heavyweights, David Geffen and Steven Spielberg – have been negotiating to move their operation to NBC Universal, The New York Times reported on Saturday, citing unnamed people close to the talks. But negotiations have hit a wall over financing.

headline: Cerberus Said to Pull the Plug on Northern Rock Bid
abstract: The rivals battling for Northern Rock, the troubled British lender, have been whittled down to two after the private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management dropped out of the running, according to The Times of London.

headline: Rubenstein and the Perils of the ‘Private’ in Private Equity
abstract: Private equity firms have been asleep at the public relations switch, more interested in reaping profits than cultivating a positive public image, Carlyle Group co-founder David Rubenstein said Wednesday, according to TheDeal.com.

headline: Will H&R Block’s Shake-Up Lead to Break-Up?
abstract: Score another point for Richard Breeden, the Securities and Exchange Commission chairman turned activist investor. Two months after winning seats on the board of H&R Block, Mr. Breeden was named chairman of the tax-preparation company on Tuesday, filling a post created by the abrupt resignation of Mark Ernst.

headline: Patriots-Giant Game, On Three Networks, Averages 34.5 Million Viewers
abstract: An average of 34.5 million viewers watched the New England Patriots become the first team to go 16-0 in the regular season, the largest audience for an NFL non-playoff game in more than 12 years.

headline: M&A Deals Hit Record $1.57 Trillion in 2007
abstract: Despite a sharp decline in dealmaking at mid-year, merger volume in 2007 hit a record $1.57 trillion in the United States, up 5.5 percent from the previous year, according to research firm Thomson Financial. But, for the first time in five years, U.S. lagged deal-making in Europe, where mergers totaled $1.78 trillion.

headline: News Corp. Sells Fox Stations to Oak Hill
abstract: The News Corporation said it would sell eight of its owned-and-operated Fox network affiliated television stations to private equity investment firm Oak Hill Capital Partners for about $1.1 billion in cash.

headline: Real Estate Partnerships Said to Evade Billions in Taxes
abstract: Investors in real estate partnerships evade billions of dollars in federal taxes each year, even though detecting this type of cheating is easy, a former specialist in partnerships for the Internal Revenue Service said Thursday.

headline: Fixing Guitar Hero III’s Mono Problem
abstract: Activision says it plans to offer replacement discs to fix a glitch in the Wii version of Guitar Hero III.

headline: ‘We Could Fire You and the Entire Management Team …’
abstract: The gloves have come off in the wake of the failed buyout of Affiliated Computer Systems.

headline: Start-Ups Trace a Dog’s Life
abstract: The concept behind SNIF Labs verges on the nutty: The Boston-based start-up is developing intelligent tags for dogs to wear, so that their owners can monitor their daily activity and track the friends they’ve made at the park.

headline: Lewis Hamilton’s real trial – with Sebastian Vettel and Mark Webber
abstract: The stewards at the Chinese Grand Prix today invited Lewis Hamilton, along with Sebastian Vettel and Mark Webber, to explain their actions on track behind the safety car at the Japanese Grand Prix last weekend.

headline: A Bullish Look at JPMorgan
abstract: Barron’s apparently likes the looks of JPMorgan Chase‘s prospects. In a bullish feature on Chase, the nation’s third-largest bank, the publication noted that JPMorgan avoided most of the losses suffered by other investment banks and its growth could now “really accelerate.”

headline: Barry Diller’s Bill Gates Imitation
abstract: IAC has just introduced 236.com, a fake news site. Seen that idea before? So did Barry Diller, who, like Microsoft, is trying to profit from the ideas of others.

headline: Four Bidders Said to Consider DundeeWealth Bid
abstract: At least four of Canada’s biggest financial institutions have signed confidentiality agreements to explore a takeover of DundeeWealth, and potential bidders are expected to decide within days whether to submit offers, The Globe and Mail reported.

headline: Strike News: ‘Daily Show’ and ‘Colbert’ Ratings Decline
abstract: The tentpoles of Comedy Central have recorded ratings declines in the first two weeks of the writers’ strike.

headline: In Facebook Race, Google Said to Be Hiking Price
abstract: Microsoft and Google are each vying to take a stake of between 5 percent and 10 percent in Facebook, with a deal expected to be announced in the next 24 to 48 hours, according to The New York Post.

headline: Kirin Said to Be in Talks for Stake in Kyowa
abstract: Japanese brewer Kirin is in talks to buy a majority stake in drug maker Kyowa Hakko Kogyo in a deal that could top 300 billion yen ($2.6 billion), Reuters reported citing an unnamed source.

headline: Al Lord Finds: You Can’t Go Home Again
abstract: Al Lord is in his second term as chief executive of Sallie Mae, having had to return to the helm thanks to the credit crunch killing the takeover deal (at $60 a share) that would have left him set for life.

headline: Restoration Names Terms for Sears Talks
abstract: Restoration Hardware said on Tuesday that it’s ready to open its books for Sears — on certain terms.

headline: UBS Posts Loss After Writedown, Cuts Jobs
abstract: UBS said Monday it would take a 4 billion Swiss franc ($3.42 billion) writedown in its fixed income portfolio and elsewhere, largely because of the summer’s slump in the value of mortgage-related securities, resulting in its first quarterly loss in nine years.

headline: Senior Executive Is Leaving Cisco Systems
abstract: Cisco Systems‘ chief development officer, Charles H. Giancarlo, widely seen as a top candidate for chief executive, announced on Thursday that he was quitting the company, leaving the race for leadership wide open.

headline: Would You Like a $1 House?
abstract: Countrywide Financial is one of the downtrodden stocks that rallied today on the government’s plan to push creditors to give some subprime homeowners a break in order to let them keep their homes. Why is it good for a lender to be forced to make concessions to borrowers? Beats me. Perhaps the theory is that this will make investors in mortgage securities more willing to accept modifications that will keep borrowers in their homes (and keep servicing fees flowing to Countrywide).

headline: Transocean to Tap Public Markets for $6 Billion
abstract: Transocean, the world’s largest offshore oil and gas drilling contractor, on Monday said it plans to raise $8.5 billion by issuing debt in order to repay borrowings to pay shareholders in its recent purchase of GlobalSantaFe.

headline: Goldman Said to Top M&A League Tables
abstract: Wall Street powerhouse Goldman Sachs has done it again.

headline: Butler in Talks for Lagardere’s Virgin France Stake
abstract: Walter Butler, head of French buyout shop Butler Capital Partners, said Wednesday that he is negotiating to buy roughly a 75 percent stake in retailer Virgin France Group from defense and media conglomerate Lagardère.

headline: Sprint Picks Embarq Head as New C.E.O.
abstract: Sprint Nextel said Tuesday that it has named Daniel R. Hesse, an industry veteran, as its new chief executive, settling questions about the phone service provider’s leadership.

headline: Bear and Barclays: Odd Couple or Perfect Match?
abstract: Bear Stearns‘ chief executive said last week that his firm doesn’t need an outside investor. But the chief, James E. Cayne, also said he was willing talk if the right partner came along.

headline: Live Nation to Buy Madonna’s Merchandising Firm
abstract: Fresh from stealing Madonna from Warner Music Group, concert promoter Live Nation is in advanced talks to acquire the Material Girl’s merchandising company, Signatures Network, The New York Post reported.

headline: MetroPCS Sues Merrill Lynch for Fraud
abstract: Merrill Lynch was sued last week by MetroPCS Communications for fraud and misrepresentation.

headline: Score One for the Web’s Don Quixote
abstract: A quixotic mission to free government information took a stop closer to reality when Fastcase electronically published a free archive of federal case law.

headline: Sallie Mae Battle Could Be Costly to Investors
abstract: J.C. Flowers & Company has told its investors just how much money they may lose in the private equity firm’s battle over the buyout of Sallie Mae.

headline: Shareholders Move to Block Reddy Ice Deal
abstract: In another blow to Reddy Ice‘s proposed $1.1 billion takeover by hedge fund GSO Capital Partners, the company said that a lawsuit seeking to block the deal had been filed in Texas.

headline: Year-End Review, With Yourself
abstract: For year’s end, an exercise to help you set goals for the coming year.

headline: DuPont Fabros Gives a Lift to Fall I.P.O.’s
abstract: DuPont Fabros Technology raised $640.5 million in one of the richest initial public offerings so far this fall, as the owner of data centers for leading Internet names priced at the top of its range and rose in the open market Friday.

headline: U.S. May Scuttle Bain’s 3Com Deal, Report Says
abstract: U.S. intelligence agencies may scuttle Bain Capital‘s $2.2 billion cash buyout of 3Com, announced in September, because of concerns about the role of Chinese minority investor Huawei Technologies, The Washington Times reported.

headline: Fidelity Taps JPMorgan Executive
abstract: Fidelity Investments on Thursday named JPMorgan Chase‘s Michael K. Clark to head its new institutional services business, tapping another outsider as part of the company’s continuing reorganization.

headline: Thain Choice Shows the Long Arm of Goldman Sachs
abstract: John Thain. Robert E. Rubin. Henry M. Paulson.

headline: The Long and Short of It at Goldman Sachs
abstract: The closet thing the world has to a secret cartel running the world is the investment bank Goldman Sachs, whose alums are routinely Treasury secretaries, high advisers to presidents, and occasionally a governor or United States senator, says Ben Stein — half jokingly — in his weekly column in The New York Times

headline: Teachers Buys Glass Lewis for $46 Million
abstract: The Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan has bought Glass Lewis, a San Francisco-based investment research, proxy advisory and voting services firm, for $46 million from its Chinese owner, Xinhua Finance of Shanghai.

headline: A Different Formula for a Biogen Deal
abstract: Will DNA get mixed up in a sale of Biogen Idec?

headline: A Toast to the Top Women in Banking
abstract: At a gathering to toast the most powerful women in banking, there was a generally sense that despite some important inroads, more work was to be done.

headline: Schlumberger Offers $679 Million for Eastern Echo
abstract: Schlumberger, the oil-field services company, bid up to $679 million for a Norwegian-listed company, Eastern Echo, on Tuesday to expand its seismic operations at a time when record oil prices are driving demand.

headline: Ex-Chief Considers Bid for Children’s Place
abstract: Shares of Children’s Place rose 6 percent Monday after the company’s recently ousted chief executive and its largest shareholder, said he might put together an offer to buy the retailer.

headline: Perelman Seeks $500 Million ‘Blank Check’
abstract: MAFS Acquisition, a blank-check company led by billionaire financier Ronald O. Perelman, filed with regulators to raise as much as $500 million to fund an acquisition.

headline: Wary of Risk, Bankers Sold Shaky Mortgage Debt
abstract: As the subprime loan crisis deepens, Wall Street firms are increasingly coming under scrutiny for their role in selling risky mortgage-related securities to investors.

headline: A Dark-Horse Candidate for Citi’s Top Job?
abstract: Since last month, Citigroup has struggled to find a replacement for Charles O. Prince III, its recently resigned chief executive. It has looked inside the sprawling financial giant; it has examined the firm’s alumni (some of whom left the firm unwillingly); it has cast its eyes on the top executives of its rivals.

headline: Female Directors Earn More Than Men, Study Finds
abstract: A new survey on corporate board pay has come up with a surprising find: The median compensation for female directors is actually higher than that for male directors.

headline: They Told You So
abstract: By PETER EDMONSTON

headline: Black Sentenced to 6 and 1/2 Years in Prison
abstract: In the months since his convictions in July on fraud and obstruction of justice charges, Conrad M. Black, the fallen press baron who once presided over the world’s third-largest newspaper empire, was not above poking fun at himself as he waited to see how long he would spend in prison.

headline: Qatar Withdraws Bid for OMX
abstract: Sweden’s Financial Supervisory Authority said on Tuesday that Qatar Holding withdrew its request for approval as a suitable owner of Nordic bourse operator OMX.

headline: Morgan Stanley to Cut 300 More Jobs
abstract: Morgan Stanley has added to Wall Street’s wave of layoffs.

headline: FL Group Sheds Stake in AMR
abstract: FL Group, the Icelandic investment firm that had pressed American Airlines parent AMR to sell off assets, is now washing its hands of the company.

headline: As Bonuses Look Leaner, UBS Takes Stock
abstract: From our DealBook colleague Julia Werdigier in London:

headline: SolFocus Adds $11.6 Million to the Pot
abstract: SolFocus has now raised a total of $63.6 million in series B funding to move into production of its solar power plants.

headline: Bay Area Takes Lion Share of V.C. Investment, Study Finds
abstract: Although its share of the nation’s venture capital investments has shrunk from a year ago, the Bay Area remains the most desirable place by far for venture capitalists, according to an Ernst & Young and Dow Jones VentureOne study.

headline: Almost 25 Million Watch The ‘Dancing With the Stars’ Conclusion
abstract: Nearly 25 million viewers tuned in for final results of ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” on Tuesday, according to Nielsen’s estimates, the largest audience for the series this season but less than the fall finale a year ago. The two-hour show, which followed a rebroadcast of the Charlie Brown Christmas special at 8 p.m. (which drew 13.6 million viewers), helped put ABC on top of the night’s ratings overall.

headline: Is a Rush to M&A on the Horizon?
abstract: The slowdown in corporate profits amid the troubled financial climate in the United States might prompt corporations to turn increasingly to mergers and acquisitions in their search for growth, BusinessWeek reported.

headline: Rubin Is Set to Back Clinton
abstract: Robert E. Rubin, Treasury secretary in the Clinton administration and new chairman of Citigroup, has overcome early misgivings about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential candidacy and will support her publicly in the fight for the Democratic nomination, The New York Times reported.

headline: Programmers Welcome for the iPhone … Next Year
abstract: Steve Jobs writes that Apple will release a software development kit for the iPhone in February, after it figures out how to keep hackers out.

headline: Morgan Stanley Posts Loss, Sells Stake to China
abstract: Morgan Stanley posted a fourth-quarter loss, its first-ever quarterly loss, after taking an additional $5.7 billion write-down related to subprime mortgages. The investment bank said it would sell a $5 billion stake to the China Investment Corporation, that country’s sovereign wealth fund, to shore up its capital.

headline: A Kid-TV Star, Pregnant at 16
abstract: The Lede blog writes about Jamie Lynn Spears — younger sister of Britney, star of the hit Nickelodeon TV series “Zoey 101″ and now, at 16, a mother to be — and her television persona:

headline: Not Yet 40, But Already a Power-List Veteran
abstract: Jonathan Gray is becoming a fixture of the Wall Street power list. In recent months, Mr. Gray, the co-head of the Blackstone Group‘s real estate investment group, appeared in DealBook’s “Facebook of Wall Street’s Future” feature and got a spot on Vanity Fair’s “Next Establishment” list, which was a sidebar to its annual “New New Establishment” list of media moguls, financial heavyweights and other power brokers.

headline: Spains Bankinter Sells $1.18 Billion Stake to Credit Agricole
abstract: Spain’s Bankinter said Monday it had agreed to sell a 20 percent stake to France’s Credit Agricole for 809 million euros ($1.18 billion).

headline: British Airways and TPG Pull $5 Billion Iberia Bid
abstract: British Airways and TPG, the American private equity firm, on Monday withdrew their 3.4 billion euro ($5 billion) offer to buy Iberia, setting the stage for a prolonged contest for control of Spain’s flag carrier and increasing the prospect it could remain in Spanish hands.

headline: Venture-Backed XDx to Seek Nasdaq Listing
abstract: XDx, a molecular diagnostics company whose investors include Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, Sprout Capital and an affiliate of the Texas Pacific Group, said it plans to raise as much as $86.25 million in an initial public offering on the Nasdaq.

headline: Despite Writedown, J.P. Morgan’s Profits Rise
abstract: J.P. Morgan Chase reported a 2 percent rise in third-quarter profit on Wednesday — a modest gain, but one that came as it and other large banks were struggling with the effects of a stormy credit environment.

headline: Hellman to Acquire Goodman for $2.65 Billion
abstract: Private equity deals seem to be making a modest comeback.

headline: Absolute Capital Hires Outsider for Review
abstract: Absolute Capital, an Australian hedge fund that suspended withdrawals because of the turmoil in credit markets, has appointed an outside administrator to review the business, the company said Tuesday.

headline: The Real History of WYSIWYG
abstract: A former Xerox hardware designer says his wife coined the term, which describes most modern software interfaces.

headline: Montreal Exchange Ups Stake in Boston Options Exchange
abstract: Takeover target the Montreal Exchange will become the majority owner of the Boston Options Exchange, in a $52.5 million cash deal announced Friday.

headline: Writers, Studios Make Nice In Public Statements
abstract: The Associated Press reports:

headline: Where Did the Buck Stop at Merrill?
abstract: On Oct. 24, Merrill Lynch announced its biggest write-down ever, an $8.4 billion charge that also represents the biggest known loss in Wall Street history. Six days later, its chief executive, E. Stanley O’Neal, retired from the company he had run since 2002.

headline: Under Pressure from Activists, PDL Agrees to a Sale
abstract: Daniel Loeb, the hedge fund executive, has done it again. With the help of other vocal shareholders, Mr. Loeb, who runs the Third Point hedge fund, has won a public campaign to oust PDL BioPharma‘s chief executive, Mark McDade, and elicit from company management a promise of a sale only one month after the firm said it would set an independent course for itself.

headline: Comcast: We’re Delaying, Not Blocking, BitTorrent Traffic
abstract: Comcast tries to explain BitTorrent blocking reports. It manages the traffic for the average user and sometimes larger users of the pipes will find their content delayed, not blocked, the company says.

headline: Goldman Sachs’s $6 Billion Word
abstract: “No.”

headline: Sainsbury Says Bidders Seek Additional Funding
abstract: J Sainsbury, the British grocery chain in takeover talks with Delta (Two), said the investment company is seeking an additional 500 million pounds ($1.03 billion) of equity funding from its Qatari backers.

headline: Citic and Bear to Swap Stakes, Form Joint Venture
abstract: Citic Securities, a top state-controlled investment bank in China, will invest $1 billion in Bear Stearns and form a joint venture with the firm in Asia, the two companies announced early Monday. The deal comes amid speculation that Bear Stearns might seek a partner following the summer’s credit crunch, which took a toll on the firm’s earnings.

headline: Fantasy Bank Mergers: How About Citi-JP Morgan?
abstract: A report that an ambitious banker recently pitched a Citigroup–Bank of America merger has got the folks at Breakingviews thinking: Wouldn’t a combination of Citi and J.P. Morgan Chase make more sense? (At least one commenter on DealBook has been thinking the same thing.)

headline: ‘Housewives’ Rule Again
abstract: Despite tough competition from “Sunday Night Football” on NBC and an animated comedy line-up on Fox, ABC eked out a victory on Sunday as the night’s most watched network.

headline: U.S. to Call Buffett in Gen Re Trial
abstract: Federal prosecutors intend to call Warren E. Buffett, the billionaire investor and chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, to testify against five former senior insurance executives accused of helping the American International Group manipulate its financial statements through $500 million in phony transactions, according to court papers filed Monday.

headline: The First Orders Arrive for Chocolate Beta Bars
abstract: It’s an auspicious start for Mr. Rossetto and his business partner, Timothy Childs, who have set up their business in an old warehouse on the San Francisco waterhouse. They say they’re proud to be bringing a chocolate factory back to San Francisco, a city known for chocolate but currently without a manufacturer in town.

headline: Ad Networks Are the New Dot-Coms
abstract: Web sites of all sorts are starting their own advertising networks. Even Martha Stewart has decided that ad networks are a good thing.

headline: Nano’s Rear-View Mirror
abstract: Plastic-producing bacteria? How ’70s. But nanotech, and rising oil prices, is bringing new life to an old idea.

headline: Nasdaq to Add Philly Exchange to Its Stable
abstract: The Nasdaq Stock Market confirmed Wednesday that it would acquire the Philadelphia Stock Exchange for $652 million to expand its presence in the fast-growing equity options business.

headline: One on One With Dan Pink
abstract: An interview with Dan Pink, author of “Free Agent Nation,” a decade after the article that inspired the book.

headline: No “Daily Show”? How a Writers’ Strike Would Affect Online Video
abstract: The prospect of a writers’ strike, and its eventual settlement, will set the terms for Internet video and may increase its audience.

headline: Will ABC’s Tuesday Night Lineup Be the Fall Season’s First Casualty?
abstract: So far, none of the new shows of the fall season have been declared dead on arrival — yet. Some critics say that that may change this evening.

headline: Who’s Afraid of MBIA?
abstract: William Ackman, who leads Pershing Square Capital, is probably quite pleased that the markets and credit rating agencies seem to be picking up on the potential troubles at MBIA, the largest bond insurer in the United States. He has been betting for years that the company would blow up.

headline: 2 Myspace Executives Win Rich Paychecks, Report Says
abstract: Top MySpace executives Chris DeWolfe and Tom Anderson have struck rich deals to continue working at the company, which was bought by Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation in 2005, The Los Angeles Times reported.

headline: CNN’s Obama/Osama Habit
abstract: Inside the pressure-cooker that is live television, the name Barack Obama apparently becomes tricky.

headline: Red Bull bulletins
abstract: Red Bull continues its imaginative press releases. This time, with one week only between races, and a big, big story to recount after the last race – Sebastian Vettel destroying Mark Webber’s chances at victory – the team decided to produce its least offensive race preview yet, for the Chinese Grand Prix. No words at all, just the drawing:

headline: Revisiting Psychological Tests: Can They Really Do That?
abstract: An earlier post about psychological testing at work creates a stir with readers.

headline: From Miserable to Purgatory
abstract: Most housing markets are bad, and a builder blames the press

headline: Who Will Run Merrill? What Now for O’Neal?
abstract: Merrill Lynch directors yesterday named Alberto Cribiore, a board member and private equity executive, to look inside the firm and out for a chief executive to succeed E. Stanley O’Neal, who said that he would retire after 21 years.

headline: Canada’s Akela Pharma Eyes U.S. I.P.O
abstract: Akela Pharma, which is developing therapies for the inhalation and pain markets, plans a public offering of 5.3 million shares of common stock, according to a regulatory filing Friday.

headline: For Citigroup’s New Head, Focus Is Subprime Tangle
abstract: Until Sunday, Robert E. Rubin collected over $18 million a year as Wall Street’s ultimate hands-off executive. On Monday, he had to roll up his sleeves.

headline: Kraft to Sell Post Cereals to Ralcorp for $2.6 Billion
abstract: Ralcorp said on Thursday that it would acquire Kraft Foods‘ Post cereals business in a deal valued at about $1.65 billion. Including about $950 million in debt, the deal is worth $2.6 billion, said Ralcorp, a maker of private-label and frozen bakery foods.

headline: AT&T to Pay $2.5 Billion for Wireless Spectrum
abstract: AT&T agreed to pay $2.5 billion for licenses that will allow it to expand wireless services or provide video broadcasts in much of its coverage area, the company announced Tuesday.

headline: Northern Rock Rescue Effort Looks Shaky
abstract: Efforts to rescue Northern Rock, the struggling British lender, appear to be faltering amid a slew of bad news.

headline: Calpine Chief Gets $10.9 Million Stock Incentive
abstract: Calpine‘s chief executive, Robert May, can expect a $10.9 million stock incentive for guiding the struggling San Jose-based power producer out of the largest United States bankruptcy of 2005, according to papers filed in United States Bankruptcy Court in New York.

headline: Kraft Adds 2 Directors Allied With Peltz
abstract: Kraft Foods on Wednesday struck a deal with the activist investor Nelson Peltz, adding two board members nominated by his Trian Partners and avoiding a potential proxy battle.

headline: Bill Gates Presents the One (Really Big) Ringy Dingy
abstract: On Tuesday, Bill Gates will introduce new software to integrate communications by voice, video and instant messaging.

headline: Kellwood Rejects $544 Million Buyout Bid
abstract: Kellwood on Wednesday rejected a bid of $21 a share that Sun Capital Securities Group made last month, signaling that the company, which makes clothes under the Calvin Klein, Baby Phat and Nautica labels, feels confident enough in its prospects to play hard to get.

headline: Deutsche Bank Mulls Move to Join Banking Fund
abstract: Deutsche Bank, Germany’s biggest bank, is considering participation in an $80 billion plan supported by the United States Treasury to revive the commercial paper market, its chief executive, Josef Ackermann, said.

headline: Sentinel Trustee Files Suit Against Company Insiders
abstract: Executives of the Sentinel Management Group, a cash management firm based in Northbrook, Ill., operated through “a pattern of criminal conduct” and perpetrated “long-term, massive fraud” against its customers, a bankruptcy trustee named to oversee the company alleged Thursday in a lawsuit.

headline: Answers from Michael P. Walsh
abstract: Today we have answers to selected questions and comments prompted by the seventh part of our series on China’s environment from Michael P. Walsh, a mechanical engineer who has spent his entire career working on motor vehicle pollution control issues, in the United States and in other countries, including Brazil, Hong Kong, Mexico, Vietnam and China.

headline: A.I.G. Announces $8 Billion Buyback Plan
abstract: American International Group, the giant insurance company, said Wednesday that it had approved the repurchase of an additional $8 billion in stock.

headline: Italy’s ENI Buys Burren Energy for $3.58 Billion
abstract: Italy’s Eni has agreed to buy oil explorer Burren Energy for 1.736 billion pounds ($3.58 billion), boosting the oil major’s operations in the Republic of Congo and giving it a toehold in Turkmenistan, where a new leadership is warming to foreign investment.

headline: Teachers Buys Glass Lewis for $46 Million
abstract: The Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan has bought Glass Lewis, a San Francisco-based investment research, proxy advisory and voting services firm, for $46 million from its Chinese owner, Xinhua Finance of Shanghai.

headline: A Different Formula for a Biogen Deal
abstract: Will DNA get mixed up in a sale of Biogen Idec?

headline: A Toast to the Top Women in Banking
abstract: At a gathering to toast the most powerful women in banking, there was a generally sense that despite some important inroads, more work was to be done.

headline: Schlumberger Offers $679 Million for Eastern Echo
abstract: Schlumberger, the oil-field services company, bid up to $679 million for a Norwegian-listed company, Eastern Echo, on Tuesday to expand its seismic operations at a time when record oil prices are driving demand.

headline: Ex-Chief Considers Bid for Children’s Place
abstract: Shares of Children’s Place rose 6 percent Monday after the company’s recently ousted chief executive and its largest shareholder, said he might put together an offer to buy the retailer.

headline: Perelman Seeks $500 Million ‘Blank Check’
abstract: MAFS Acquisition, a blank-check company led by billionaire financier Ronald O. Perelman, filed with regulators to raise as much as $500 million to fund an acquisition.

headline: Wary of Risk, Bankers Sold Shaky Mortgage Debt
abstract: As the subprime loan crisis deepens, Wall Street firms are increasingly coming under scrutiny for their role in selling risky mortgage-related securities to investors.

headline: A Dark-Horse Candidate for Citi’s Top Job?
abstract: Since last month, Citigroup has struggled to find a replacement for Charles O. Prince III, its recently resigned chief executive. It has looked inside the sprawling financial giant; it has examined the firm’s alumni (some of whom left the firm unwillingly); it has cast its eyes on the top executives of its rivals.

headline: Female Directors Earn More Than Men, Study Finds
abstract: A new survey on corporate board pay has come up with a surprising find: The median compensation for female directors is actually higher than that for male directors.

headline: They Told You So
abstract: By PETER EDMONSTON

headline: Lone Star to Sew Up Deal for Accredited
abstract: Lone Star Funds, the buyout firm that backed out of its original bid for Accredited Home Lenders, expects to complete its revised tender offer for the subprime lender Friday.

headline: Google Gives Some Hints About Social Network Plan
abstract: Eric Schmidt, the chief executive of Google, said the company plans to use the social information implicit in Gmail and its other services to improve its search engine.

headline: Maker of Wonder Bread Rejects Burkle Bid
abstract: Bankrupt Interstate Bakeries has rejected the joint bid from Ronald Burkle’s Yucaipa and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters after it decided that the $580 million offer was not a qualified bid because it left too many unanswered questions.

headline: Merrill Appoints Chai as New Finance Chief
abstract: On his first full day as Merrill Lynch‘s chief executive, John A. Thain has already poached someone from his old firm.

headline: Barclays Shares Fall on Emergency Funding Rumors
abstract: Shares in Barclays fell the most in almost three months Friday morning on speculation that it approached the Bank of England for emergency funding.

headline: Goldman, Aetos to Buy Japan’s Simplex
abstract: Goldman Sachs and a partner plan to buy a Japanese property company, Simplex Investment Advisors, for 124.7 billion yen ($1.1 billion) as land prices in the world’s second-largest economy recover.

headline: Two Agencies Battle It Out Over Amaranth
abstract: Two federal agencies, both pursuing charges against the defunct hedge fund Amaranth Advisors, are waging a battle over which has jurisdiction over energy futures markets.

headline: SAC May Balk at ITT’s Edo Bid
abstract: The activist hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors served notice late Thursday that it might be dissatisfied with ITT‘s deal to acquire the defense contractor Edo for $1.5 billion.

headline: What’s the Best Buyout of 2007?
abstract: Forget your holiday plans for a minute and think back. Way back. All the way to June.

headline: European Central Bank Seeks to Ease Credit
abstract: The European Central Bank said that it would extend a lending deadline in December to help the banking system through a period of unusually tight credit at the end of the year, The New York Times reported. The action represents a renewed effort by the bank to calm a lending system that had showed signs of returning to normal recently but now appears nearly as nervous as during the summer days when the global credit turmoil began.

headline: The Lowdown on Money Issues, With Jean Chatzky
abstract: An interview with a personal finance expert, Jean Chatzy, who examines the financial side of career change and entrepreneurship.

headline: Chairman of Northern Rock Resigns
abstract: Northern Rock, the British lender that last month was the target of the country’s first bank run in 140 years, said Friday that its chairman, Matt Ridley, had resigned.

headline: Has Cerberus Lost Its Nose for Bargains?
abstract: Cerberus Capital Management‘s recent decisions to walk away from a couple of traditional leveraged buyouts, namely its deal for H&R Block‘s mortgage arm Option One and United Rentals, has taken some of the shine off the distressed investors, Breakingviews says.

headline: The Robot in the Newsroom
abstract: The New York Times redesigned technology Web page uses Blogrunner software that automates the discovery of relevant technology stories.

headline: Big Bank Seeks C.E.O. for L.T.R.
abstract: With Citigroup’s search for a new chief executive entering its third week, columnists Michael Lewis of Bloomberg News and Rob Cox of Breakingviews are offering the gigantic bank their unsolicited — and sharply ironic — advice on the situation.

headline: Ex-Qwest Chief Asks for New Trial
abstract: Joseph P. Nacchio, the convicted former chief executive of Qwest Communications International, asked a federal appeals court for a new trial, claiming he had been found guilty of insider trading based on insufficient evidence.

headline: The Next Big Anti-Subprime Bet
abstract: Paulson & Company made a big name for itself this summer after earning big profits by betting against subprime mortgages. Now it’s playing the contrarian yet again.

headline: NYSE Euronext to Launch Carbon Trading Market
abstract: NYSE Euronext will launch an international carbon trading market next year to position itself for an expected increase in emission credits trading as governments and industry step up efforts to cut pollution.

headline: Will Rivals Come to Sallie Mae’s Rescue?
abstract: Is Sallie Mae ripe for a rival bid?

headline: Herskovitz Calls ‘Quarterlife’ ‘on the Upswing’
abstract: Is the ambitious Web drama “Quarterlife” succeeding or fading? The answer may depend on the medium. The first episode of the serialized show about Web-savvy members of Generation Y has garnered nearly one million views on MySpace and YouTube since it premiered on Nov. 11. Later episodes have delivered roughly 100,000 views.

headline: ‘Three Little Words’ on GMA (But Not ‘Where is Charlie?’)
abstract: A woman pans a video camera from her face to a computer screen, where a message says “it’s not cancer.” Three little words can have quite an impact, as ABC News learned over the summer when it introduced a weekly segment on its user-generated content show “i-Caught.”

headline: ABN Bankers Said to Threaten Revolt Over Bonuses
abstract: After seven months of takeover warfare and the $99.1 billion it took to win ABN Amro, Royal Bank of Scotland may now have do battle with some of the Dutch lender’s bankers over loyalty bonuses.

headline: Celgene Coughs Up $2.9 Billion to Acquire Pharmion
abstract: The biotechnology company Celgene said Sunday that it would pay $2.9 billion in cash and stock to acquire Pharmion, strengthening Celgene’s cancer drug portfolio and its distribution in Europe.

headline: How To Make Red Ink Black
abstract: The More You Lose, The Better?

headline: MerchantCircle Rounds Up New Funding
abstract: MerchantCircle, a pioneer in online local advertising, raised $10 million in a Series B financing round, sticking with its faithful early-stage investors and adding a pair of key strategic partners.

headline: Rusal Launches Bid to Become World’s Largest Aluminum Miner
abstract: Rusal, a Russian miner controlled by billionaire Oleg Deripaska, agreed Friday to buy a 25 percent stake, worth about $13 billion, in OJSC MMC Norilsk Nickel and launch a takeover of the business that would create the world’s largest aluminum miner.

headline: Oracle Bid Adds New Element to BEA Backdating Suit
abstract: What does BEA Systems‘s rejection of Oracle‘s takeover bid have to do with backdated stock options?

headline: Terra Firma Said to Unveil EMI Plans
abstract: British investor Guy Hands’ Terra Firma, on the hunt for additional equity investors in EMI, is telling prospective partners they can nearly quadruple their money in the struggling major label and cash out within five years, The New York Post reported.

headline: Did Murdoch Mull a Times Offer?
abstract: In winning Dow Jones, Rupert Murdoch has taken over the paper he has long dreamed of owning, The Wall Street Journal. But the mogul dropped word earlier this week that he had considered bidding for another storied newspaper: DealBook’s parent, The New York Times.

headline: Who’s to Blame for Big Golden Parachutes?
abstract: Whenever a chief executive at a top firm loses his or her job because of poor performance, one question crops up right away: How big is the exit package? When the size of the chief’s golden parachute comes to light, it usually inspires a wave of criticism about the board of directors that seemed to sign the check.

headline: ‘Dog’ Suspended Over Alleged Remarks
abstract: A&E has suspended production on the popular show “Dog the Bounty Hunter” after the show’s star, Duane Dog Chapman, was allegedly heard expressing racist insults in two recorded phone calls.

headline: Shasta Closes $250 Million Fund
abstract: Silicon Valley’s Shasta Ventures has closed a $250 million venture capital fund to focus on early-stage technology companies.

headline: Microsoft to Target Small Deals
abstract: Microsoft Chief Executive Steve Ballmer said on Thursday the company aims to pursue an independent path, focusing on up to 20 smaller acquisitions of $50 million to $1 billion each annually rather than mega-deals.

headline: Google’s Next Frontier: Renewable Energy
abstract: Google the Internet company with a seemingly limitless source of revenue, plans to get into the business of finding limitless sources of energy.

headline: A Cloudbook on the Horizon
abstract: The $299 eeePC is a lightweight portable computer that is meant for browsing Web sites and running Internet applications.

headline: Developer Is China’s Latest Hot Stock Offering
abstract: Shares of SOHO China, a Beijing property developer, soared 15 percent on their first day of trading Monday in Hong Kong in the latest hot public stock offering.

headline: ‘Daily Show’ Archives Appear Online
abstract: Beginning today, eight years of episodes of “The Daily Show with Jon Stewart” are fully accessible on the show’s Web site.

headline: Developer Said to Eye Trump’s Atlantic City Casinos
abstract: Cordish, a Baltimore developer in a legal fight with Donald Trump over a casino development in Florida, is in talks to buy Mr. Trump’s Atlantic City casinos, according to The Philadelphia Inquirer.

headline: Fright Night Scares Off Viewers
abstract: Halloween festivities took a chunk out of network television audiences on Wednesday, but CBS retained the most viewers overall thanks to “Criminal Minds.” That show led the night, according to Nielsen’s estimates, with 14.7 million viewers at 9 p.m.

headline: Too Much Meddling When C.E.O.’s Go a-Courtin’?
abstract: Asking another corporation for its hand in marriage is always a delicate affair. But does a chief executive need to bring the directors along as chaperones? Does a merger-hungry C.E.O need his or her parents’ blessing before making a proposal?

headline: Strike News: Seth Meyers Brings It — Every Day
abstract: Seth Meyers, a writer and actor for “Saturday Night Live,” has had a “perfect attendance record” since the strike commenced on Nov. 5.

headline: New Life for ‘Quarterlife’
abstract: NBC has announced a premiere date for the Web-to-television series “Quarterlife.” The first of six episodes will debut on Feb. 18 at 9 p.m., after the premiere of the reality show “Baby Borrowers.”

headline: A Portrait of a Fallen Hedge Fund Manager
abstract: Victor Niederhoffer, the hedge-fund manager who lost his entire $130 million portfolio in the Thai stock market crash of 1997, has found himself out of luck again.

headline: Case closed – and politics
abstract: And so, indeed, the FIA is closing the affair.

headline: SFR May Dial Up $7.2 Billion Deal for Neuf Cegetel
abstract: Vivendi‘s SFR wireless phone unit is in talks with the other main shareholder in Neuf Cegetel in what investors said could be a 5 billion euro ($7.2 billion) purchase of the second-largest fixed-line phone company in France.

headline: Seeking Leaders, U.S. Companies Think Globally
abstract: The corner offices of corporate America are increasingly being filled from every corner of the world.

headline: Cisco Offices Are Raided in Brazil
abstract: Brazilian police and Federal Revenue Service officials raided offices of the Brazilian unit of the network equipment company Cisco Systems and arrested top executives as part of a continuing investigation into a smuggling and tax fraud scheme, authorities said late Tuesday.

headline: Two Private Equity Firms Try Glove Maker On For Size
abstract: Two Chicago private equity firms have acquired a Nevada-based maker of disposable gloves. The Chicago Tribune reported that BarrierSafe Solutions International was bought by Linden and The Edgewater Funds for an undisclosed sum.

headline: Former Citadel Trader Hangs His Own Shingle, Report Says
abstract: Anand Parekh, a former head equity trader at the Citadel Investment Group, is setting up his own hedge fund, according to Reuters.

headline: Strikers: Not Writing, But Still Blogging
abstract: Even when they’re on strike, Writers Guild of America members are still writers at heart. Perhaps for that reason, several television screenwriters and show-runners have been busy blogging about the situation.

headline: Bebo Copies Facebook, Which Invites Others to Do the Same
abstract: Bebo has developed a system to let applications written for Facebook run on its social network. Facebook then decided to let other networks do the same. All this is meant to fight off the Google-MySpace environment called OpenSocial.

headline: Chinese Interest Propels Standard Chartered’s Shares Up
abstract: Standard Chartered shares jumped in London on Monday morning following a report that a group of Chinese banks may be gearing up to invest in the firm.

headline: PopularityDialer Goes Offline
abstract: Over a decade ago, I remember seeing a “Saturday Night Live” skit that still stays with me. It was a talk show where all of the guests had one thing in common: they were all jerks or psychopaths whose one-time actions had created lifelong inconvenience for the rest of society. There was that guy who put poison into a bottle of Tylenol, initiating the era of the childproof (and adult-proof) package. There was the hijacker, whose actions led to the nationwide construction of airport X-ray machines. There was the creep who put razor blades into Halloween candy. And so on.

headline: Fatdoor Opens Up for V.C.’s
abstract: Fatdoor, a social network for neighbors, on Wednesday said it picked up $5.5 million in a first round of funding and former Yahoo veteran Jennifer Dulski as its chief executive.

headline: Cable Ratings: ‘Criminal Intent’ Lifts USA; ‘Nostradamus’ Helps History Channel
abstract: Original episodes of “Law & Order: Criminal Intent,” which moved from NBC to USA Network this fall, have helped the cable channel earn its best October ratings ever. The four episodes of the spinoff series, which made its seventh season debut on Thursday Oct. 4, have averaged just under 4 million viewers, a 95 percent increase over USA’s time period average during the same weeks last year.

headline: Will Another Biotech Get Put in Play?
abstract: There’s more than one way to diagnose Monday’s rise in Genzyme‘s stock.

headline: Bring This to the Next Meeting
abstract: How much money is wasted during meetings? This calculator could track it.

headline: Federal Prosectors Subpoena Genesco Over Buyout Deal
abstract: The shoe and hat retailer Genesco said on that it had received a subpoena from federal prosecutors in New York for documents related to buyout negotiations with Finish Line.

headline: Last Night in One Room: Kravis, Milken & Whitehead
abstract: Not since Michael Milken’s Predators’ Ball in the 1980’s have so many of Wall Street’s bold-faced names dared to mingle together. Until last night.

headline: China’s ICBC to Take $5.6 Billion Stake in Standard Bank
abstract: The Industrial & Commercial Bank of China said yesterday it would take a 20 percent stake in Standard Bank Group, the largest bank in Africa, for 36.7 billion rand ($5.6 billion).

headline: Teachers Buys Glass Lewis for $46 Million
abstract: The Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan has bought Glass Lewis, a San Francisco-based investment research, proxy advisory and voting services firm, for $46 million from its Chinese owner, Xinhua Finance of Shanghai.

headline: A Different Formula for a Biogen Deal
abstract: Will DNA get mixed up in a sale of Biogen Idec?

headline: A Toast to the Top Women in Banking
abstract: At a gathering to toast the most powerful women in banking, there was a generally sense that despite some important inroads, more work was to be done.

headline: Schlumberger Offers $679 Million for Eastern Echo
abstract: Schlumberger, the oil-field services company, bid up to $679 million for a Norwegian-listed company, Eastern Echo, on Tuesday to expand its seismic operations at a time when record oil prices are driving demand.

headline: Ex-Chief Considers Bid for Children’s Place
abstract: Shares of Children’s Place rose 6 percent Monday after the company’s recently ousted chief executive and its largest shareholder, said he might put together an offer to buy the retailer.

headline: Perelman Seeks $500 Million ‘Blank Check’
abstract: MAFS Acquisition, a blank-check company led by billionaire financier Ronald O. Perelman, filed with regulators to raise as much as $500 million to fund an acquisition.

headline: Wary of Risk, Bankers Sold Shaky Mortgage Debt
abstract: As the subprime loan crisis deepens, Wall Street firms are increasingly coming under scrutiny for their role in selling risky mortgage-related securities to investors.

headline: A Dark-Horse Candidate for Citi’s Top Job?
abstract: Since last month, Citigroup has struggled to find a replacement for Charles O. Prince III, its recently resigned chief executive. It has looked inside the sprawling financial giant; it has examined the firm’s alumni (some of whom left the firm unwillingly); it has cast its eyes on the top executives of its rivals.

headline: Female Directors Earn More Than Men, Study Finds
abstract: A new survey on corporate board pay has come up with a surprising find: The median compensation for female directors is actually higher than that for male directors.

headline: They Told You So
abstract: By PETER EDMONSTON

headline: United May Throw Off Baggage to Fly Higher
abstract: Airline consolidation is a perpetual conversation topic in the industry, but analysts so far have dismissed the recent push to combine Delta Air Lines and UAL‘s United Airlines.

headline: Google Shares Shoot Past $600
abstract: Why are the company’s shares still climbing? Analysts have a number of theories.

headline: Ratings: Reruns Return and Reality Emerges
abstract: With the November “sweeps” period over, the reruns have returned, and along with them, ratings for the leading networks on Thursday, ABC and CBS, plummeted accordingly. NBC and Fox, meanwhile, failed to make up much of any ground.

headline: Will R.B.S. Suffer the ‘Winners Curse’?
abstract: The $101 billion bid for ABN Amro by the consortium led by the Royal Bank of Scotland looked set to prevail after Barclays withdrew its offer Friday.

headline: ArcelorMittal Pays $26.6 Million for Chinese Steel Cord Firm
abstract: Luxembourg-based ArcelorMittal said Monday that it would pay $26.6 million to acquire a 90 percent stake in Rongcheng Chengshan Steelcord of China.

headline: Contests for Consumers to Create Ads ‘March’ On
abstract: The next commercial you see for the March of Dimes may have been created by a viewer rather than an advertising agency.

headline: A How-To Guide for Sovereign Wealth Funds
abstract: Sovereign wealth funds based in Asia and the Middle East are on the move. In recent months, these huge government-backed investment firms have taken stakes in Bear Stearns, the Carlyle Group, Advanced Micro Devices, and perhaps most notably, Citigroup.

headline: Hosts of ‘The View’ Support Strikers, Too
abstract: The women of “The View” expressed support for the striking television writers on Monday, following the decisions by Michelle Obama and John and Elizabeth Edwards to cancel their appearances on the show as a gesture of solidarity with the writers.

headline: Government Did Not Know of Airbus Problems, Report Finds
abstract: The French government was not aware of serious production delays for the Airbus A380 when a state-owned bank bought a stake in the plane maker’s parent, the European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company, a report by the finance ministry concluded Thursday.

headline: Sign of the Strike: Jan. Press Tour Canceled
abstract: The Television Critics Association’s January press tour has officially been canceled, the group’s president informed members in a letter Monday night.

headline: Deutsche Telekom Looks for Two-Tier Internet
abstract: Arguing that it is too expensive to deliver video to its home Internet users, Deutsche Telekom is preparing to charge a fee to companies that want to offer video and other high-bandwidth services, according to an industry newsletter.

headline: Studios Release First Viral Video
abstract: The Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers has belatedly entered the viral video field with a slide show that adds up the lost salaries caused by the two-month-old writers’ strike.

headline: For Navteq Chief, a Rewarding Round of Golf
abstract: What began with a trip to Pebble Beach may end with a $173 million payout for Judson C. Green.

headline: Real Losses Have Nothing to Do With Money
abstract: In his latest column, Andrew Ross Sorkin examines the human face behind the ups and downs of Wall Street that are so often covered by DealBook. These bankers are not, he says, just in it for the deal.

headline: A Big Loss at Merrill Stirs Unease
abstract: Since becoming chief executive of Merrill Lynch in 2002, E. Stanley O’Neal has been credited with making the investment bank leaner and more disciplined.

headline: Time Warner Unveils Details of Bewkes Deal
abstract: Time Warner has signed a five-year employment deal with its incoming chief executive, Jeff Bewkes, for $1.75 million a year in salary and an annual target bonus of $8.5 million.

headline: Shareholder Opposes Onex’s Husky Bid
abstract: A minority shareholder of Husky Injection Molding Systems says it will fight the proposed takeover of the company by Canadian buyout shop Onex, and will try to rally other shareholders to stop the deal or squeeze out a higher price.

headline: 2 Small Hedge Funds Merge
abstract: Two small hedge funds have merged in a rare deal as tiny investment pools, watching giants such as the Citadel Investment Group prepare  to post returns of up to 27 percent for the year, huddle together looking for better returns.

headline: With Enough ‘Daily Show’ Clips, You’ve Got a Whole Program
abstract: You can watch all the jokes, fake news and interviews from last night’s “Daily Show” on its new Web site, but don’t call that a “full episode.” Viacom’s deal with cable companies prevents it from putting whole programs online.

headline: Goldman Gets a Boost from China Nepstar I.P.O.
abstract: Goldman Sachs saw its stake in China Nepstar Chain Drugstore skyrocket after the Chinese drugstore chain went public in New York on Friday. Shenzhen, China-based Nepstar raised about $334 million when it sold 20.6 million American Depositary Shares at $16.20 each, up from $11.50 to $13.50 a share.

headline: Cisco Secures a Deal for Securent
abstract: Cisco Systems announced a $100 million agreement on Thursday to buy venture-backed Securent. The three-year-old company makes security software that helps companies manage different tiers of application users.

headline: Russian Energy Concern Files Suit Against Abramovich
abstract: An affiliate of Sibir Energy is seeking what could be billions of dollars in damages in a lawsuit in London against the billionaire Roman Abramovich and his investment company, Millhouse Capital, saying that it was cheated out of its Russian assets.

headline: Stuff I’m Reading, Listening to, Watching
abstract: This week’s links touch on search optimizing your résumé, building your brand, how magazines treat personal finance and what women are wearing to work.

headline: What Does Lampert Have in Store for Sears?
abstract: Many investors are wondering how Edward Lampert, the billionaire hedge-fund manager who controls Sears Holdings, plans to wring profits from the shopworn department-store chain.

headline: DP World of Dubai to Make an Initial Offering
abstract: DP World confirmed Sunday that it will sell 20 percent of its shares, worth at least $3.5 billion, next month in what will be the Middle East’s largest initial public offering.

headline: China Plans to Open a Market in Stock Futures
abstract: In an effort to develop a stock futures market that will give investors more options and help them hedge risk, China is planning to introduce stock index futures soon and is ready to approve new quotas for foreign investors in the country’s red hot stock markets.

headline: Merrill’s Chief to Leave; Talk Turns to Successor
abstract: E. Stanley O’Neal’s six-year reign at Merrill Lynch is coming to an end. After an $8.4 billion write-down and an unauthorized merger approach to a rival bank, Wachovia, Mr. O’Neal has lost the confidence of his board and is expected to resign as chairman and chief executive as early as Monday, The New York Times reported.

headline: TPG to Take $270 Milion Stake in Japan’s NIS, Report Says
abstract: TPG, the U.S. buyout fund, may announce its biggest Japan acquisition as early as this week, investing 30 billion yen ($270 million) in lender NIS Group, Bloomberg News said.

headline: John Mack in the Hot Seat
abstract: Morgan Stanley portrayed Wednesday’s decision to take a $5 billion infusion from China as a strategic move, and not a desperate act. Still, the announcement came as the firm reported the first quarterly loss in its 72-year history and as a joke about foreign investments was making the rounds on trading floors: “Shanghai, Dubai, Mumbai or goodbye.”

headline: F.T.C. Approves Google-DoubleClick Deal
abstract: Antitrust regulators approved Google‘s $3.1 billion purchase of DoubleClick, clearing the way for a formidable combination in the burgeoning online advertising sector.

headline: Fortress Posts Loss for 3rd Quarter
abstract: The hedge fund and private equity company Fortress Investment Group reported a third-quarter loss on Tuesday, hurt by a special charge.

headline: Will F.T.C. Move on Whole Foods Deadline?
abstract: While Whole Foods Market has closed its deal with its rival natural foods purveyor, Wild Oats Markets, despite a lawsuit filed by the Federal Trade Commission, the case is still very much alive.

headline: Britain’s Chrysalis Goes on the Block
abstract: Chrysalis Group, a British independent music company long coveted by a number of the major labels including Warner Music Group, has officially put itself up for sale with the hopes of raising as much as $300 million, The New York Post reported.

headline: Regulators Approve Nokia’s Navteq Deal
abstract: The federal government Thursday approved Finnish cell-phone maker Nokia‘s $8.1 billion acquisition of Chicago-based digital mapmaker Navteq.

headline: Kohlberg Kravis Sells Argillon for $314 Million
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts agreed on Monday to sell a German catalysts and ceramic materials producer, Argillon to a British catalysts and ceramic materials group, Johnson Matthey for 214 million euros ($314 million), marking a final exit from a group of companies it bought from Siemens in 2002.

headline: Ratings: Tryptophan Nation
abstract: On a Wednesday night with below average television viewing because of the Thanksgiving holiday, CBS took first place thanks to “Criminal Minds” and “CSI: NY.”

headline: Site That Tracks Brokers Questioned on Erased Cases
abstract: As part of a new campaign to educate American investors, Finra, the private regulator for securities firms and stockbrokers, points people to its huge database that tracks brokers who have run into trouble with customers.

headline: Barclays Denies $10 Billion Write-Down Rumors
abstract: Barclays may soon admit some sort of bad news related to its mortgage holdings. But the embattled British bank says that it isn’t $10 billion worth.

headline: JPMorgan to Invest $200 Million in the Movies
abstract: JPMorgan Chase said Monday it will invest $200 million in film and entertainment projects to add to its entertainment advisory and banking operations. The New York investment bank said it will use subordinated debt for investments such as film and television financings, acquisitions and print and digital media start-ups.

headline: 2 Ex-Executives of Body Armor Supplier Are Charged
abstract: Two former top executives of DHB Industries, the leading supplier of body armor to the United States military, were indicted Thursday on charges of insider trading, fraud and tax evasion, federal prosecutors said.

headline: The Buyout Boom Is Alive and Well. In China.
abstract: Private equity dealmaking may be slowing in the United States, but according to The Washington Post, some of the biggest and most powerful dealmakers here have found a way to keep the buyout boom going: by aggressively pushing into China.

headline: Lerach Pleads Guilty to Conspiracy
abstract: William S. Lerach, 61, a former partner at the law firm now known as Milberg Weiss, pleaded guilty to conspiracy on Monday.

headline: Former Grassley Aide Turns Buyout Lobbyist
abstract: Chuck Grassley hasn’t exactly been making life easy for the big private equity firms. In June, the Republican Senator from Iowa co-sponsored legislation, informally known as the Blackstone Bill, that would more than double the tax rate on publicly traded investment firms such as Blackstone Group and Fortress Investment Group. This week, he and Sen. Max Baucus, a Democrat from Montana, sent letters to Carlyle Group and other buyout firms as part of an inquiry into reports of declining safety standards at private-equity-owned nursing homes.

headline: The Fast Life and Strange Death of a Hedge Fund Manager
abstract: A life of private jets and black-tie balls ended with Seth Tobias, a wealthy investment manager and a familiar presence on CNBC, floating face down in the swimming pool of his mansion in Jupiter, Florida.

headline: Spain’s Mapfre in $2.2 Billion Deal for U.S. Insurer
abstract: Spanish insurer Mapfre, seeking a platform from which to expand in the United States, said Tuesday it had agreed to buy The Commerce Group for $2.21 billion.

headline: Has Lampert Cut Too Much at Sears?
abstract: Edward S. Lampert, the billionaire financier and chairman of Sears Holdings, is fond of saying that a company must be regularly “pruned,” like a tree or a wardrobe. But “you can’t cut your way to success,” he warned investors in his annual letter this year.

headline: Tribune Says Deal Is on Track
abstract: Tribune, the media conglomerate, on Wednesday sought to reassure investors that its deal to go private was moving forward. Despite skepticism on Wall Street, the company’s chief executive, Dennis J. FitzSimons, said the transaction to take Tribune private remained on track to close in the fourth quarter.

headline: Golden Globes Broadcast In Doubt
abstract: “Hollywood’s glamour machine has gotten stuck between a promise that the stars will still show up at next month’s Golden Globes and a threat that 3,000 picketing writers will chase them away,” Michael Cieply reports.

headline: Cadbury Moves Ahead With Spinoff Plans
abstract: With no deep-pocketed private equity investors on the horizon, Cadbury Schweppes has decided to go ahead with a plan to spin off its 7 billion-pound ($14.2 billion) North American soft drinks business.

headline: Blackstone Said to Be Eyeing Briatin’s Close Brothers
abstract: The Blackstone Group is reportedly one of several parties to have approached British investment bank Close Brothers Group, which recently rebuffed a 1.4 billion pound ($2.8 billion) offer from smaller rival Cenkos Securities and Iceland’s Landsbanki Islands.

headline: A Year Later: Chat on AIM through GMail
abstract: Gmail users can now have instant-message conversations with users of AOL’s AIM system, fulfilling a key term of the deal in which Google invested $1 billion in AOL. The message services of Yahoo and MSN are linked to each other but not to Google or AOL.

headline: Buyer’s Remorse
abstract: A Massive Case of Buyer’s Remorse

headline: Zell Hopes to Close Tribune Deal Next Week
abstract: Samuel Zell, the real-estate magnate, hopes that the $8.2 billion deal he’s leading to take Tribune private will close Dec. 20.

headline: Clips: 4Kids for CW, ‘Criminal Intent’ on USA, Leno Desk for Sale
abstract: — 4Kids Entertainment, which programs Saturday morning children’s shows for Fox affiliates, will begin doing the same thing for the CW network, TV Week reports.

headline: Banks Are Said to Resume Sale of Chrysler Debt
abstract: A group of Wall Street banks plan to make another attempt to start selling $10 billion of Chrysler loans this week, according to news reports. The move follows the banks’ decision in July to shelve the debt offering amid woes in the credit markets.

headline: Apollo Hires Real Estate Lawyer as It Hunts for Bargains
abstract: Apollo Real Estate Advisors, an affiliate of the private equity firm Apollo Management, has hired a leading real estate lawyer as it looks for opportunities in the distressed mortgage sector.

headline: 2 Alitalia Bidders Outline Turnaround Plans
abstract: Air One, one of the finalists to buy Alitalia, said its recovery plan for the Italian carrier includes a complete renewal of the fleet, new destinations in China and the Americas, and an international partner.

headline: Shares Slip Further on Fear of Bank Debt
abstract: Investors have entered December, usually a winning month on Wall Street, cautiously. Fears of further weakness in the financial sector helped push the stock market down for a second day Tuesday.

headline: How Deal-Making Lawyers Keep Score
abstract: For lawyers who like rankings, there is more than one way to keep score. But the question remains, Does a high ranking matter, and for whom?

headline: Consumer Fear
abstract: Consumer sentiment warns of low holiday sales.

headline: Teachers Buys Glass Lewis for $46 Million
abstract: The Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan has bought Glass Lewis, a San Francisco-based investment research, proxy advisory and voting services firm, for $46 million from its Chinese owner, Xinhua Finance of Shanghai.

headline: A Different Formula for a Biogen Deal
abstract: Will DNA get mixed up in a sale of Biogen Idec?

headline: A Toast to the Top Women in Banking
abstract: At a gathering to toast the most powerful women in banking, there was a generally sense that despite some important inroads, more work was to be done.

headline: Schlumberger Offers $679 Million for Eastern Echo
abstract: Schlumberger, the oil-field services company, bid up to $679 million for a Norwegian-listed company, Eastern Echo, on Tuesday to expand its seismic operations at a time when record oil prices are driving demand.

headline: Ex-Chief Considers Bid for Children’s Place
abstract: Shares of Children’s Place rose 6 percent Monday after the company’s recently ousted chief executive and its largest shareholder, said he might put together an offer to buy the retailer.

headline: Perelman Seeks $500 Million ‘Blank Check’
abstract: MAFS Acquisition, a blank-check company led by billionaire financier Ronald O. Perelman, filed with regulators to raise as much as $500 million to fund an acquisition.

headline: Wary of Risk, Bankers Sold Shaky Mortgage Debt
abstract: As the subprime loan crisis deepens, Wall Street firms are increasingly coming under scrutiny for their role in selling risky mortgage-related securities to investors.

headline: A Dark-Horse Candidate for Citi’s Top Job?
abstract: Since last month, Citigroup has struggled to find a replacement for Charles O. Prince III, its recently resigned chief executive. It has looked inside the sprawling financial giant; it has examined the firm’s alumni (some of whom left the firm unwillingly); it has cast its eyes on the top executives of its rivals.

headline: Female Directors Earn More Than Men, Study Finds
abstract: A new survey on corporate board pay has come up with a surprising find: The median compensation for female directors is actually higher than that for male directors.

headline: They Told You So
abstract: By PETER EDMONSTON

headline: At WNBC, News On Top of News
abstract: One month after WNBC introduced an innovative local newscast at 7 p.m., it seems to be gaining some traction.

headline: When The Music Stopped
abstract: Citigroup Takes A Bath

headline: Lehman Raises Cash to Invest in Leveraged Debt
abstract: Lehman Brothers, one of the banks with the largest exposures to leveraged debt, has raised $670 million of equity capital to invest in leveraged loans it hopes to buy at a discount, the bank said Monday.

headline: Hong Kong Exchange Looks to Trade Smog Rights
abstract: As Hong Kong struggles under a daily cloud of noxious fumes from local traffic and nearby factories in mainland China, the Hong Kong Stock Exchange is considering using its financial muscle as part of a solution.

headline: Ebay Takes Afterbuy
abstract: The online auctioneer eBay said Thursday it had acquired an online sales tool, Afterbuy.com by purchasing its operator, ViA-Online, a German auction management software company. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

headline: Morgan Stanley’s No-Good, Very Bad Day
abstract: Many hedge funds wilted in the dog days of August, burned by the subprime mortgage market’s implosion. But Morgan Stanley‘s quantitative-strategies traders had one heck of an awful day.

headline: Cheyne Pays $6.7 Million in Tax Settlement in Britain
abstract: Cheyne Capital, the British hedge fund manager whose $6.7 billion structured investment vehicle Cheyne Finance went into bankruptcy last month, has paid a 3.2 million pound ($6.7 million) tax settlement to British authorities.

headline: Applied Precision Cancels I.P.O., Sells Unit
abstract: Seventeen months after filing for an initial stock offering that it never completed, Applied Precision said it had dropped its I.P.O. plans and has sold its semiconductor test-instrumentation business to Rudolph Technologies.

headline: A Fine Mess for UBS
abstract: UBS is in another mess. It is trying to get out of financing a merger between two shoe retailers — Genesco and Finish Line — that now looks like a bad deal from almost any perspective.

headline: Apollo-Backed Paper Company Seeks Listing
abstract: Verso Paper, which Apollo Management bought from International Paper last year for $1.4 billion, filed with regulators Thursday to raise as much as $345 million in an initial public offering.

headline: Boardroom Mutiny at A.C.S.; the Cayne Memo
abstract: Where’s the memo? As many DealBook readers have noticed, our link to the internal memorandum from Bear Stearns chief executive James Cayne was broken in Friday morning’s e-mail newsletter. Here’s the right one — and sorry for the confusion.

headline: Before Stockpickr.com, a Hedge Fund Deal Not Done
abstract: In a mini-profile of a hedge fund manager, James Altucher, and his investment Web site Stockpickr.com, BusinessWeek reports that Mr. Altucher eschewed a tantalizing offer from a large hedge fund to bring his investment strategy — and that of Warren E. Buffet and George Soros — to the masses.

headline: Wheeling-Pitt Investors Approve Esmark Deal
abstract: Steelmaker Wheeling-Pittsburgh and steel distributor Esmark said their shareholders approved the merger of the two companies.

headline: What Downturn? On Wall St., Bonus Pool Is Up
abstract: It’s been a year that many Wall Street firms would just as soon forget. In many cases, the firms’ earnings fell to decade-lows, and their shareholders, who suffered their worst losses since 2002, were justifiably disenchanted.

headline: Two Funds Put Philips in Spotlight
abstract: Two hedge funds appear to be taking aim at a cash pile held by Royal Philips Electronics. Jana Partners and the D.E. Shaw Group, which own about 1.6 percent of the company, announced that they have teamed up to review Philips’s results and capital structure.

headline: Is Europe Winning the Hedge Fund Race?
abstract: Driven by an improving regulatory and investment climate, the European hedge fund industry is growing rapidly and could shortly overtake the industry in the United States, an investment analyst contended Thursday at a conference organized by Dechert, a Philadelphia-based law firm.

headline: Strike News: Strike and Counterstrike
abstract: Wednesday the writers guild’s claims about residuals were rebuffed by ABC Studios. Thursday the studio’s claims about residuals were rejected by the writers.

headline: Yahoo Deal Adds Content From CNBC
abstract: Yahoo Finance, the most popular business news Web site, will begin distributing content from the business news channel CNBC on Wednesday.

headline: Daniel Och’s Blackstone-Size Windfall
abstract: He’s not Stephen Schwarzman, but when it comes to I.P.O. payouts, Daniel Och is close.

headline: Fund of Hedge Funds Taps Public Markets
abstract: Gottex Fund Management, the Lausanne- and London-based fund of hedge funds group, this month made its opening on the Swiss Exchange, the latest in a line of alternative asset managers cashing in on a perceived appetite among investors for publicly quoted hedge funds.

headline: Genzyme Moves for Re-Vote on Bioenvision Deal
abstract: Genzyme‘s effort to take over a key partner for $345 million took another twist this week.

headline: Umbro Shareholder Gives Nike Bid a Boost
abstract: Shares of Umbro, the seller of soccer-related goods, rose Wednesday after a major shareholder said he may support Nike‘s 285 million pound ($569 million) bid for the company.

headline: Merrill Fires Executive in Asian Unit
abstract: Merrill Lynch ousted the co-head of its Asian fixed-income business Tuesday amid a management shake-up after $8.4 billion of losses on subprime mortgage-related securities and bad loans.

headline: Led by Troubled Banks, Shares Slide
abstract: Shares of financial companies stumbled Monday in the aftermath of the shake-up at Citigroup, sending the stock markets down and leaving investors on edge about further troubles in the credit market.

headline: Paul Allen and Echostar Line Up for Spectrum Auction
abstract: We don’t know everyone who is bidding in the 700-megahertz spectrum auction, but Paul Allen and Echostar have signed up to bid against Google, AT&T and Verizon.

headline: How a Prince Lost His Citi Crown
abstract: As recently as last month, Charles O. Prince III could count on the support of Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia, the biggest shareholder of Citigroup, the financial behemoth that Mr. Prince had run for four years.

headline: Nasdaq Opens Up in Beijing to Seek Mainland Offerings
abstract: Nasdaq, the No. 2 U.S. stock exchange, set up shop in Beijing on Monday as it looks to attract more Chinese firms to list on the exchange instead of alternatives such as Hong Kong.

headline: JDS Uniphase to Buy Hologram Maker
abstract: JDS Uniphase, a maker of telecommunications equipment, has agreed to buy American Bank Note Holographics, whose holograms are used by MasterCard and Visa, for $138 million in cash and stock, the companies announced Tuesday.

headline: Lilliputian Systems Fattens Its Pot With $18 Million
abstract: Lilliputian Systems, a notoriously secretive company developing matchbook-sized fuel cells, has landed $18 million in new funding, according to recent documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: When Leno & O’Brien Return: Shorter Monologues, Longer Musical Acts?
abstract: A spokeswoman for NBC said in order to resume taping, producers planned to reduce the amount of written material for the shows, such as monologues, and rely more heavily on celebrity guests and musical acts.

headline: Analysis: Harman’s Off-Key Deal
abstract: The news of Harman International‘s broken buyout agreement with Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Goldman Sachs seemed to come and go Monday without much attention. That was probably a good thing for Harman — and perhaps part of its media strategy — because it struck a lousy deal.

headline: Investors Give Gemstar Deal a Cold Shoulder
abstract: Judging by the two companies’ stock prices on Friday, it seems shareholders are tuning out Macrovision‘s $2.8 billion offer for Gemstar-TV Guide International.

headline: Co-Founder of Skype Defends Its Value
abstract: In his first public remarks since quitting last week as chief executive of the Internet phone company Skype, Niklas Zennstrom said Tuesday that he had no regrets about his handling of the company but conceded that he might have tried to squeeze money out of it too quickly.

headline: FilmBankers Raises $200 Million for Indie Movies
abstract: FilmBankers International of Beverly Hills, Calif., is raising a $200 million private equity fund to invest directly in U.S. independent films.

headline: Writedowns Expected at J.P. Morgan and BofA
abstract: J.P. Morgan Chase and Bank of America are expected to take a combined $3 billion in writedowns when they report quarterly earnings later this month, an analyst estimated. The Financial Times said the losses, from leveraged loans and mortgage-related securities, would take to more than $20 billion the total writedowns at the world’s top banks because of the summer’s market turmoil.

headline: IHT F1 guy on CNN
abstract: Any readers of this blog interested in seeing what I look and talk like – and who I was rooting for yesterday – can check out the interview of me on CNN this morning as I speak about what I thought happened at the Chinese Grand Prix.

headline: Black’s Warhols Go on the Block
abstract: Conrad Black, the former media mogul convicted this summer of corporate fraud and obstruction of justice, is back in the news. That is because two Warhol paintings he owns will be auctioned by Christie’s, each with a selling price estimated at $150,000 to $200,000. The first auction is Nov. 14.

headline: Loews Sets Spinoff of Lorillard Unit
abstract: Loews Corporation, the diversified conglomerate, said Monday that its board of directors approved a plan to spin off Lorillard, the cigarette maker, as a separately traded company.

headline: Red Kite Fund Said to Lose 22 Percent in November
abstract: Red Kite Metals, a hedge fund that posted a gain of 188 percent last year, lost about 22 percent last month as copper prices fell, Bloomberg News reported Thursday citing two unnamed investors in the fund.

headline: Avista Hires Adviser for Energy Unit
abstract: Avista Capital Partners said on Monday that it had hired the former chief executive of Trico Marine Services to advise its energy practice.

headline: Big Law Firm Settles Age-Discrimination Suit
abstract: Sidley Austin, one of the nation’s largest law firms, has agreed to pay $27.5 million to 32 former partners to settle a closely watched age-discrimination lawsuit brought by the federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.

headline: Death By a Thousand Write-Downs
abstract: What’s really killing investors’ confidence in Wall Street firms is the uncertainty and unpredictability of the recent write-downs, David Weidner wrote in a commentary on MarketWatch. The solution may be for more firms to take a tough line on marking to market.

headline: Absolut Parent to Be Sold Next Year, Sweden Says
abstract: The maker of Absolut vodka, Vin & Sprit will be sold next year via auction, the Swedish government said on Tuesday, and could fetch $6 billion to $7 billion in what would be the country’s biggest privatization ever.

headline: New Leader for Brown Brothers Harriman
abstract: Brown Brothers Harriman & Company, the nation’s oldest private commercial bank, will announce Tuesday that it has appointed Douglas A. Donahue Jr. as its new managing partner, the equivalent of a chief executive, The New York Times said.

headline: Writers Talks Get Dose of Reality
abstract: “As wrangling over a new contract for striking Hollywood writers focused on digital media, other issues abruptly emerged as potential stumbling blocks,” the Associated Press reports.

headline: Clips: Tom Green, TV Guide, CW Promos
abstract: — Tom Green, the former MTV comic, is taking his Internet talk show to television. It is currently streamed live from his living room toTomGreen.com, but beginning in January it will air on a handful of stations in late-night time slots, Broadcasting & Cable reports.

headline: With Not a Joke Written, Jimmy Kimmel Hosts Music Awards
abstract: More than 13 minutes into ABC’s live broadcast of the American Music Awards last night, the host finally made his appearance. Jimmy Kimmel went on to explain that as a member of the Writers Guild he was on strike — “in my heart,” at least — and couldn’t write any jokes.

headline: Monday Night Quarterbacking
abstract: With the major television networks facing significant competition Monday from baseball playoffs on TBS, the sci-fi hit “Heroes” matched its all-time low in the ratings as NBC plunged to a disappointing third place on the night.
