According to Nielsen Media Research, “Heroes” drew a total of 10.9 million viewers at 9 p.m. while its ratings among adults 18 to 49 fell to a level even with its lowest mark last season in early May.

headline: It Never Happened
abstract: On Oct. 19, the 20th anniversary of the 1987 crash, The Financial Times had an interesting anecdote about Black Monday. The only trouble with it is that is simply not true.

headline: JackBe Nabs $9.5 Million from V.C.’s
abstract: JackBe, a provider of user-driven enterprise mashup software, announced Wednesday that it had secured $9.5 million in its third round of funding.

headline: S.E.C. Bars Investors’ Directors From Ballots
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission ruled Wednesday that public companies could block investors from putting director candidates on corporate ballots, a major setback for shareholders seeking a greater say in boardroom affairs.

headline: Strine on Sallie Mae’s M.A.E.
abstract: Investors, lawyers and deal makers have been avidly dissecting the “material adverse effect” clause in the $25 billion buyout of Sallie Mae in an attempt to suss out who has the legal edge. By and large, these folks are just kibbitzers. The person whose opinion really matters is Vice Chancellor Leo E. Strine Jr., of the Delaware Court of Chancery in Wilmington.

headline: Wall Street’s Minnows Make Big Calls on Banks
abstract: A few hitherto unknown analysts have made names for themselves recently with their headline-grabbing calls on investment banking writedowns, Breakingviews says.

headline: Saving the Auditors
abstract: Can the auditors be saved?

headline: Sainsbury Family Reiterates Opposition to Qatar Bid
abstract: Members of the Sainsbury family will move to block the Qatari bid for the Sainsbury supermarket chain unless a deal is struck with the group’s pension fund trustees, The Telegraph reported.

headline: Seeking Ideas for Gift Giving Fatigue
abstract: Some thoughts on gift giving fatigue, in and out of the workplace.

headline: Visa Completes Restructuring Ahead of I.P.O.
abstract: Visa, which plans to go public by early next year, said on Wednesday it completed a restructuring ahead of its initial public offering.

headline: IBM to Buy Cognos in $4.9 Billion Deal
abstract: That didn’t take long.

headline: Earnings Are Disappointing at 3 Big Banks
abstract: Three large banking companies, Wells Fargo, Regions Financial and KeyCorp. reported lower-than-estimated third-quarter profits Tuesday and said rising loan losses might hurt future earnings.

headline: Going Long on Fine Art
abstract: Art investments are risky business, if what happened this week at Sotheby’s in New York is any indication. On Wednesday, an art auction crashed and burned when five of 26 lots went unsold and another 10 sold at prices below the minimum bids that Sotheby’s had set. In the wake of that debacle, Sotheby’s stock took a record 35 percent plunge.

headline: Teachers Buys Glass Lewis for $46 Million
abstract: The Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan has bought Glass Lewis, a San Francisco-based investment research, proxy advisory and voting services firm, for $46 million from its Chinese owner, Xinhua Finance of Shanghai.

headline: A Different Formula for a Biogen Deal
abstract: Will DNA get mixed up in a sale of Biogen Idec?

headline: A Toast to the Top Women in Banking
abstract: At a gathering to toast the most powerful women in banking, there was a generally sense that despite some important inroads, more work was to be done.

headline: Schlumberger Offers $679 Million for Eastern Echo
abstract: Schlumberger, the oil-field services company, bid up to $679 million for a Norwegian-listed company, Eastern Echo, on Tuesday to expand its seismic operations at a time when record oil prices are driving demand.

headline: Ex-Chief Considers Bid for Children’s Place
abstract: Shares of Children’s Place rose 6 percent Monday after the company’s recently ousted chief executive and its largest shareholder, said he might put together an offer to buy the retailer.

headline: Perelman Seeks $500 Million ‘Blank Check’
abstract: MAFS Acquisition, a blank-check company led by billionaire financier Ronald O. Perelman, filed with regulators to raise as much as $500 million to fund an acquisition.

headline: Wary of Risk, Bankers Sold Shaky Mortgage Debt
abstract: As the subprime loan crisis deepens, Wall Street firms are increasingly coming under scrutiny for their role in selling risky mortgage-related securities to investors.

headline: A Dark-Horse Candidate for Citi’s Top Job?
abstract: Since last month, Citigroup has struggled to find a replacement for Charles O. Prince III, its recently resigned chief executive. It has looked inside the sprawling financial giant; it has examined the firm’s alumni (some of whom left the firm unwillingly); it has cast its eyes on the top executives of its rivals.

headline: Female Directors Earn More Than Men, Study Finds
abstract: A new survey on corporate board pay has come up with a surprising find: The median compensation for female directors is actually higher than that for male directors.

headline: They Told You So
abstract: By PETER EDMONSTON

headline: UBS to Write Down $10 Billion as It Prepares Stake Sales
abstract: UBS said on Monday that it would write down its subprime mortgage investments by $10 billion but would replenish its capital by selling stakes worth 13 billion Swiss francs to the Singapore government and an unnamed Middle Eastern investor.

headline: Has J.C. Flowers Taken the Lead in Northern Rock Race?
abstract: J.C. Flowers, the private equity firm, is expected to submit a firm proposal for Northern Rock in the next two to three weeks and believes that it is further ahead than the consortium led by Richard Branson in the race for the stricken mortgage bank, The Times of London reported.

headline: Rudolph Shows the Way for CBS
abstract: The Christmas classic “Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer” led CBS to a Tuesday night victory in the ratings as the special delivered 14.4 million viewers at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates.

headline: F1 special report
abstract: Incidentally, I know there’s often no real mix between this blog and the articles I do elsewhere on the IHT site via the newspaper. So I thought I would just signal readers to the Formula One Season Review special report that I did that was published in the newspaper as a special section a couple of days ago, as it’s a fairly complete round-up of the season – plus a story about “Stars ‘n Cars” (which is a category I did not do as much on the blog this year, I think). (The report also had a cool graphic showing the top four drivers’ progress through the season, but unfortunately that is not available online.)

headline: Dubai Buys ‘Substantial’ Stake in Sony
abstract: Dubai International Capital, a private equity company owned by the ruler of Dubai, said it had made a “substantial investment” in Sony, boosting the shares of the Japanese electronics and entertainment firm.

headline: Zell on The Los Angeles Times: No Sale
abstract: The Chicago real estate magnate and Tribune owner Samuel Zell said Tuesday he had no plans to sell The Los Angeles Times to any of the moguls who previously had expressed an interest in buying the newspaper.

headline: CBS Teases New Shows, But Airs Reruns
abstract: Yesterday TV Decoder noted that NBC and ABC have shifted the premiere dates for two January series. A reader wondered: “Is this also the reason for CBS executing the irritating ‘bait and switch’ of the last two nights?”

headline: At Morgan Stanley, Succession Still in Question
abstract: John Mack is giving up his bonus in 2007. Will the chief of Morgan Stanley need to give up his job as well?

headline: U.S. Must Get Tougher on Deal Compliance, Lawyer Says
abstract: An antitrust lawyer and former Federal Trade Commission official said that the Department of Justice should get tougher if it wants more timely compliance with merger divestiture orders.

headline: Everpower Fueled by Good Energies
abstract: A wind power startup, Everpower Renewables, is flying high after receiving $55 million in funding from renewable energy investment firm Good Energies.

headline: At Last, French Software Maker Finds a Mate
abstract: Finally.

headline: Michael Biondi, Lazard Banker, Dies at 50
abstract: Michael J. Biondi, a Lazard partner and a heavyweight among mergers and acquisitions bankers, died Monday evening at his home in Greenwich, Conn. Mr. Biondi worked as Lazard’s co-chairman of investment banking, a role he held since 2003. The cause of death was unknown, pending an autopsy.

headline: Blackstone Installs Industry Vet Atop Hilton Hotels
abstract: In its first major move since closing the $26 billion deal to buy Beverly Hills-based Hilton Hotels, the Blackstone Group on Monday named the head of an industry rival as Hilton’s new top executive.

headline: Investors Groove on Music Start-Ups
abstract: While the music industry remains perpetually confused in trying to figure out the best ways to make money through digital offerings, there are plenty of entrepreneurs seeking success where the big players have failed, The Deal.com notes.

headline: Rocky Road for I.P.O.’s in 2008?
abstract: As financial markets go, so go initial public offerings.

headline: The Secret to Raising the Value of Eyeballs
abstract: Mass advertising is dying, and targeted ads are one way that content companies are hoping to cover their costs.

headline: Euro Disney
abstract: The first time I visited Euro Disneyland outside Paris, for Euro Disney’s 2004 annual meeting held in March, I realized something was very different from the Disney parks I had known in the United States.

headline: Barry Diller’s Big Breakup
abstract: IAC/InterActiveCorp, the media-and-Internet conglomerate cobbled together by Barry Diller, said Monday that it plans to carve itself up into five companies. The spinoffs seemed to signal a retreat for Mr. Diller, a media magnate who was the Unites States’s most highly paid chief executive in 2005.

headline: Memo Pad
abstract: CROWDED SKIES United States airlines carried 72.2 million passengers in July, a record for a single month, says the Transportation Department’s Bureau of Transportation Statistics. They carried 63.2 million domestic passengers in July, up 1.3 percent from the previous high of 62.4 million in July 2005, and 8.9 million international passengers, up 3.2 percent from the previous high of 8.7 million in July 2006. Load factors in July — the percentage of all seats occupied by paying customers — reached a record monthly high for combined domestic and international flights at 86 percent, topping the previous high of 85.8 percent in June. During the first seven months of this year, the airlines carried a record 451.7 million domestic and international passengers, 2.9 percent more than in the period in 2006.

abstract: The Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan has bought Glass Lewis, a San Francisco-based investment research, proxy advisory and voting services firm, for $46 million from its Chinese owner, Xinhua Finance of Shanghai.

abstract: Will DNA get mixed up in a sale of Biogen Idec?

abstract: Schlumberger, the oil-field services company, bid up to $679 million for a Norwegian-listed company, Eastern Echo, on Tuesday to expand its seismic operations at a time when record oil prices are driving demand.

abstract: A new survey on corporate board pay has come up with a surprising find: The median compensation for female directors is actually higher than that for male directors.

abstract: As the subprime loan crisis deepens, Wall Street firms are increasingly coming under scrutiny for their role in selling risky mortgage-related securities to investors.

abstract: Since last month, Citigroup has struggled to find a replacement for Charles O. Prince III, its recently resigned chief executive. abstract: A new survey on corporate board pay has come up with a surprising find: The median compensation for female directors is actually higher than that for male directors.

headline: Drop in Sales of a Drug Leads to a Write-Down
abstract: Johnson & Johnson said last night that it would record a $440 million write-down to account for declining revenue from its heart-failure infusion treatment, Natrecor.

headline: Can Airports Calm the Nerves?
abstract: Air travelers can now visit medical clinics, nail salons and spas while waiting out delays.

abstract: The broadcast networks are using TV show Web sites to offer clips, outtakes, interviews, games, message boards and blogs — not to mention entire episodes.

abstract: In another sign of the downward trend in newspaper advertising, Scripps said it would split into two companies, one for its cable television businesses and one for its newspapers.

abstract: Intel benefited from a reorganization and various new products after several quarters of a bruising price war with Advanced Micro Devices.

abstract: Sprint Nextel has rejected an offer from Providence Equity Partners and SK Telecom of South Korea to replace management and invest $5 billion in the company.

headline: Canada: Merger of Energy Trusts
abstract: Penn West Energy Trust, a Canadian energy trust, agreed to acquire Canetic Resources Trust for about 3.6 billion Canadian dollars ($3.8 billion) to cushion the impact of a new tax. The combined trust would have tax pools, or accrued credits used to reduce tax payments, valued at about 5.5 billion Canadian dollars at the end of 2007, according to the statement. Canetic’s unit holders would receive 0.515 of a Penn West unit and a distribution of 9 cents a Canetic unit before the closing, according to the companies. That values the offer at 15.84 Canadian dollars for each Canetic unit, 7.1 percent above the closing price on Tuesday. Both companies are based in Calgary.

abstract: The national rail service blamed fires along high-speed rail lines on sabotage, as a strike entered its eighth day.

headline: Mexico: U.S. Plans $1 Billion in Aid to Fight Drugs
abstract: The United States would give Mexico $1 billion in aid over the next two years to fight drug cartels under an aid package that will need Congressional approval, said Carlos Rico, the Mexican under secretary for North American affairs. For months, the two governments have been holding discussions about a program that would provide the Mexican police and prosecutors with training, equipment and advanced technology from the United States. Details of the negotiations have not been made public, and aides in the United States Senate and the House of Representatives said lawmakers had yet to be briefed. Judith Bryan, a spokeswoman for the United States Embassy in Mexico City, said a final agreement had not yet been reached.

headline: Many Czechs Love U.S., but Say ‘Hold the Radar’
abstract: The Czech population is deeply divided over whether its country should host a controversial U.S. missile-defense radar system that is opposed by Russia.

headline: New Way of Counting Radio Listeners May Cut Ad Income
abstract: Arbitron, which measures ratings for the radio industry, has been testing a new electronic measurement tool that monitors exposure to radio stations throughout the day.

headline: Food and Fuel Compete for Land
abstract: For years, cheap food and feed were taken for granted in the United States. Now the price of some foods is rising sharply, and a blame alert is under way.

headline: Surprise Pressure From Myanmar’s Neighbors
abstract: The Philippine president suggested that her country might not ratify a new regional charter unless Myanmar committed to democratic reforms and released Aung San Suu Kyi.

headline: Benazir Bhutto, 54, Lived in Eye of Pakistan Storm
abstract: Charismatic, striking and a sly political operator, Ms. Bhutto was reared in the turbulence of Pakistani politics and became the Muslim world’s first female leader.

headline: Western Union Empire Moves Migrant Cash Home
abstract: Migration is so central to Western Union that forecasts of border movements drive the company’s stock.

headline: Chávez’s Vision Shares Wealth and Centers Power
abstract: Venezuela seems likely to start an extraordinary experiment in centralized, oil-fueled socialism.

headline: Federal Judge Calls Rendition Process ‘Outsourcing’
abstract: A federal judge in New York sharply questioned government lawyers on Friday at a hearing involving a Syrian-born Canadian detained at Kennedy Airport in 2002 and sent to Syria.

headline: Virgin Group in Lead for Bank
abstract: The Virgin Group appeared as the front-runner today to buy Northern Rock, the troubled British mortgage lender, after winning the backing of the Treasury and Bank of England.

headline: Newly Elected South Korean Forecasts Chill With North
abstract: The South Korea president-elect, Lee Myung-bak, declared Thursday that he would not hesitate to criticize North Korea’s authoritarian government.

headline: British Hand Over Basra to Iraqis
abstract: British forces gave up military control of the final region under their supervision after four and a half years.

headline: The Very Expensive Reality of Chasing Reality TV
abstract: Would-be contestants can drop big money auditioning for reality television shows and contests.

headline: A Simple System, Superb at Math
abstract: It may seem like a magical device, but at its heart, a G.P.S. unit is simply a radio receiver.

headline: New York Widens Inquiry on Mortgages
abstract: The New York attorney general has subpoenaed Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac as part of his investigation into collusion between appraisers and lenders to inflate home values.

headline: Oil Closes Above $86 a Barrel
abstract: Tensions in the Middle East and uncertainties about the American economy propelled prices into record territory.

headline: Treaty on Running European Union Is Signed
abstract: The new treaty, which changes the way the bloc is run, includes the creation of a permanent post of E.U. president to represent Europe on the world stage.

headline: Youths Clash With the Police in France
abstract: Dozens of youths clashed with the police for the second night in a row in a working- and lower-class suburb north of Paris on Monday.

headline: Bell Labs Is Gone. Academia Steps In.
abstract: A headline last Sunday with the Ping column, about research partnerships between universities and corporations, referred incorrectly to the status of Bell Labs. Although it is no longer part of AT&T, it has not been discontinued; it is now the research arm of Alcatel-Lucent. The column also misspelled the surname of the president of Arizona State University, who said that universities’ roles in such partnerships would evolve in coming decades. He is Michael Crow, not Crowe.

headline: Dreamliner Is Expected to Meet Its Revised 2008 Deadline
abstract: Boeing said it expected to deliver the first 787 in November or December 2008 after improving supply-chain problems that had led to a six-month delay.

headline: American Faces Espionage Charge in Nigeria
abstract: An aid worker arrested last month was in possession of  information that could jeopardize national security, a prosecutor at a Nigerian High Court said Monday.

headline: Economic Signals Send Stocks Higher
abstract: Last week’s advance was hard-won. Stocks dropped for three days in a row, then rebounded on Friday after a surprisingly strong report on retail sales.

headline: Newcomer to Casinos Counts on Knowing the Players
abstract: Francis Lui, deputy chairman of the Galaxy Entertainment Group, offered his views on Macao, the intensity of the Chinese gambler and why he thinks he will outsmart his more experienced rivals.

headline: Warning for Drug
abstract: The European health regulator said Pfizer’s Champix, a stop-smoking aid, should carry a warning about the risk of suicide attempts among patients. In urging the warning, the regulator, the European Medicines Agency, followed the lead of American health officials who said last month doctors should monitor patients for mood shifts and patients should tell their doctors of changes.

headline: Tadahiro Sekimoto, Electronics Executive, Dies at 80
abstract: Mr. Sekimoto presided over NEC, the Japanese electronics firm, during its rise into a top global computer maker before resigning in a military procurement scandal

headline: How Many Site Hits? Depends Who’s Counting
abstract: Even though online advertising is growing fast, that growth is being stunted, industry executives say, because nobody can get the basic visitor counts straight.

headline: BP, Under New Chief, to Pay a Big Settlement
abstract: The record financial settlements are part of an effort by BP’s new chief executive, Tony Hayward, to move the company away from its troubled recent past.

headline: Maker Seeks to Restrict Cancer Drug Used on Eye
abstract: Genentech is moving to restrict the use of its drug Avastin by ophthalmologists, a move that could substantially raise the costs of treating a common eye disease.

headline: Turkey Bombs Kurdish Rebels in Iraq for 2nd Day, Kurds Say
abstract: The Turkish military, which made three large cross-border attacks in the past week, had not issued a statement confirming an operation by Sunday night.

headline: Scrutiny for Insurers of the Aged
abstract: The top-ranking Republican on the Senate Finance Committee has asked 11 long-term care insurance companies to explain “troubling data” regarding how policyholders’ claims are handled and paid.

headline: Teachers Buys Glass Lewis for $46 Million
abstract: The Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan has bought Glass Lewis, a San Francisco-based investment research, proxy advisory and voting services firm, for $46 million from its Chinese owner, Xinhua Finance of Shanghai.

headline: A Different Formula for a Biogen Deal
abstract: Will DNA get mixed up in a sale of Biogen Idec?

headline: A Toast to the Top Women in Banking
abstract: At a gathering to toast the most powerful women in banking, there was a generally sense that despite some important inroads, more work was to be done.

headline: Schlumberger Offers $679 Million for Eastern Echo
abstract: Schlumberger, the oil-field services company, bid up to $679 million for a Norwegian-listed company, Eastern Echo, on Tuesday to expand its seismic operations at a time when record oil prices are driving demand.

headline: Ex-Chief Considers Bid for Children’s Place
abstract: Shares of Children’s Place rose 6 percent Monday after the company’s recently ousted chief executive and its largest shareholder, said he might put together an offer to buy the retailer.

headline: Perelman Seeks $500 Million ‘Blank Check’
abstract: MAFS Acquisition, a blank-check company led by billionaire financier Ronald O. Perelman, filed with regulators to raise as much as $500 million to fund an acquisition.

headline: Wary of Risk, Bankers Sold Shaky Mortgage Debt
abstract: As the subprime loan crisis deepens, Wall Street firms are increasingly coming under scrutiny for their role in selling risky mortgage-related securities to investors.

headline: A Dark-Horse Candidate for Citi’s Top Job?
abstract: Since last month, Citigroup has struggled to find a replacement for Charles O. Prince III, its recently resigned chief executive. It has looked inside the sprawling financial giant; it has examined the firm’s alumni (some of whom left the firm unwillingly); it has cast its eyes on the top executives of its rivals.

headline: Female Directors Earn More Than Men, Study Finds
abstract: A new survey on corporate board pay has come up with a surprising find: The median compensation for female directors is actually higher than that for male directors.

headline: They Told You So
abstract: By PETER EDMONSTON

headline: To Compete, Iranian State TV Adapts
abstract: A mini-series set in Paris during World War II, featuring the love story of an Iranian-Palestinian diplomat and the Jewish woman he helps to flee the Nazis, is a hit with viewers in Iran.

headline: Turkey Authorizes Troops to Enter Iraq to Fight Rebels
abstract: Turkey’s move toward cross-border military action in Iraq comes in the face of strong opposition by the United States.

headline: After Rocky Election, Nigerians Warm to New Leader
abstract: Five months after a contentious election, many Nigerians have found a lot to like about Umaru Yar’Adua, who was sworn in as president in May.

headline: China Will Make Hong Kong Wait to Elect Leader
abstract: China said that Hong Kong would have to wait at least another decade for democratic elections to select its leader.

headline: Amway Adds Entertainment to Product Line
abstract: Amway, the door-to-door peddler of vitamins and soap, is pouring millions of dollars into a new online store called Fanista, which will initially sell DVDs and CDs.

headline: U.N. Body Plans to End Investigation of Contracts
abstract: The General Assembly plans to put an early end to an in-house panel that has exposed more than $600 million in tainted U.N. contracts and is investigating an additional $1 billion.

headline: A Rate Cut, a Rally and a Plunge
abstract: The Federal Reserve cut short-term interest rates last week, but the broad stock market fell anyway.

headline: As Kurds’ Status Improves, Support for Militants Erodes in Turkey
abstract: Militant proponents of Turkey’s newly publicly celebrated Kurdish identity threaten to complicate further progress on the very rights that they claim to fight for.

abstract: A study in The Journal of Consumer Research explores people’s faulty memories of how much they liked an experience, showing that they look for cues in their own subsequent behavior.

headline: Despite Aid, Malnutrition in Darfur Rises

headline: A Top Sicilian Mafia Boss Is Held, Italy Says

abstract: The first members of a brigade in Diyala Province have started to leave, but because of continuing violence, another brigade that is already in Iraq will take its place.

abstract: Subaru of America dismissed its creative and media agencies unexpectedly and is moving its account to Carmichael Lynch in Minneapolis, part of the Interpublic Group.

headline: Myanmar’s Resources Provide Leverage

headline: In Russia, Ford Hurt by Strike and Rising Pay

headline: In the Crowded Sky, Change Is Approaching
abstract: Because this is the worst year ever for airline delays, air travel has suddenly become a hot political issue.

headline: 35 Are Killed in Iraq, 5 by U.S. Troops

headline: Polishing Up the Apple in Applebee’s

headline: Consumer Advocates Seek a ‘Do-Not-Track’ List
abstract: A coalition of privacy groups asked the government today to set up a mandatory do-not-track list for the Internet.

headline: 7 Are Acquitted in Madrid Bombings
abstract: Three men were found guilty of murder and 18 others were convicted of lesser charges, but none of the accused ringleaders of the attack were convicted.

abstract: Workers at major Ford plants are voting this weekend on a new contract whose approval looks likely, even though dissidents are stepping up efforts to defeat it.

abstract: New Web-based services are making it easier for smaller businesses to compile important customer information.

headline: The Year of the Cellphone
abstract: If you think there was a lot of cellphone news this year, you ain’t seen nothin’ yet. The coming year is going to be the real Year of the Cellphone.

headline: Back in Times Square, Toshiba Stands Tall
abstract: Toshiba America has signed a 10-year lease for a giant sign, 55 feet by 55 feet, on 1 Times Square.

abstract: On a second day of rallies against President Putin, riot police officers detained numerous marchers.

headline: Microsoft Is Yielding in European Antitrust Fight
abstract: European regulators hailed the deal as a breakthrough that should create more competition, especially for server software that powers corporate data centers and the Internet.

The company, based in Moscow, acquired major assets of Yukos, the oil company that was controlled by Mikhail Khodorkovsky, this year. A statement on Rosneft’s Web site said the increased output was a result of several acquisitions and increased production rates at several oil fields.

abstract: Promising news from the Middle East sent the Dow up 215 points, a long way toward making up for yesterday’s steep sell-off.

abstract: Despite growing scrutiny of the quality and safety of Chinese goods, China’s exports are up 27 percent so far this year.

abstract: The death of the Tamil leader, who frequently met with peace envoys and spoke to journalists, leaves the group with no obvious public face.

abstract: Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve on Tuesday after the Fed’s monetary policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, decided to lower interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point:.

abstract: Kirk Kerkorian, a 90-year-old billionaire, plans a $1.4 billion tender offer to acquire a 16 percent stake in Tesoro, a United States refiner whose profit jumped tenfold in the last four years.

headline: Balancing Bottom Lines and Headlines
abstract: A chart with an article on Sept. 30 about the business model of The St. Petersburg Times in Florida included an incorrect figure from Nielsen/NetRatings for the Web site traffic of a competitor, The Tampa Tribune, in November 2006. The total number of unique visitors was about 870,000, not 637,247, according to Nielsen/NetRatings.

abstract: SLM, the parent of Sallie Mae, which for years profited from placing large bets on its own stock going up, now faces a possible loss of more than $1 billion.

abstract: Thousands of software developers are creating features for Facebook, the fast-growing social network, many hoping to strike it rich alongside Facebook’s own employees.

abstract: The U.S. has agreed to forgive $26 million of debt and the government of Costa Rica has committed to invest a similar amount in conserving high-risk natural areas.

abstract: Growing up in Boston, I figured I could handle any type of problem the gods of driving threw at me. I met my match in Singapore, a place known for its law-abiding citizens.

abstract: In southern Africa, a child’s name is chosen to convey a specific meaning, and not, as is common in the West, the latest fashion.

abstract: In a setback for American producers, a federal trade panel ruled Tuesday against the American glossy paper industry’s request for tariffs on imported Chinese paper.

abstract: Dennis J. FitzSimons will step down as chairman and chief executive of Tribune Company as soon as an $8.2 billion takeover deal is completed, the company said.

abstract: The International Herald Tribune is to announce plans on Monday to transform its financial section online and in print by forging an alliance with Reuters.

abstract: New data showed that Abbott Laboratories’ new drug-coated heart stent, Xience V, ouperformed the market leader in preventing coronary arteries from clogging again.

abstract: The business interests of megachurches include aviation subsidiaries and investment partnerships.

abstract: The president of Chad warned nine French citizens who had been arrested for trying to fly 103 children from Darfur to France, saying they faced punishment for their “horrible act.”

abstract: Reebok will segue next month from shoe business to show business, teaming with the IFC cable network for a celebrity interview series that is being produced by a new entertainment arm of Reebok.

abstract: Proposed constitutional changes would speed President Hugo Chávez’s efforts to formally establish a socialist state.

abstract: Five American soldiers were killed and seven wounded after an Army Black Hawk helicopter crashed outside Treviso, Italy.

abstract: A vast majority of cellphone owners are not taking advantage of this Internet capability, even though it is available to most of them.

abstract: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week included Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills.

abstract: The news suggests President Vladimir V. Putin plans to maintain a hold on much of the power he has accrued.

abstract: In its third cross-border attack into Iraq within a week, Turkey that its warplanes had killed hundreds of separatist Kurdish rebels. Iraq says no one had been wounded or killed.

abstract: A 34-year-old immigrant from Ghana pleaded guilty to a reduced charge of conspiracy to cause explosions.

headline: Letters
abstract: A Consumption Tax.

headline: Britain: Water Utility Acquired
abstract: The Kelda Group, a water supplier to British cities including Leeds and Sheffield, agreed to be bought by a group including Citigroup and HSBC Holdings for £3.04 billion ($6.26 billion). Kelda’s shareholders will receive 1,100.65 pence a share, including a dividend of 10.65 pence, a premium of 17.5 percent over the closing price on Wednesday, the day before Kelda said it had been approached. Kelda, based in Bradford, also reported a 58 percent increase in first-half profit after raising prices at its Yorkshire Water unit, which supplies about 4.7 million people and 140,000 businesses.

headline: A Top Rival in Pakistan Is Carted Off by the Police
abstract: The opposition politician Imran Khan, who emerged from hiding on Wednesday, was seized by hard-line students and turned over to the police, witnesses said.

headline: A Model for Health Care That Pays for Quality
abstract: Seeing low fees for family doctors as a weak link in the nation’s health care system, some big employers and health insurers are seeking new ways to pay doctors to reward high-quality medical care.

headline: In Bangladesh, Picking Through the Pieces
abstract: In claiming relatively few lives, the cyclone that tore across Bangladesh left many more people in utter ruin.

headline: Brazil: Oceanair Orders Planes
abstract: Airbus won a $2.65 billion order from OceanAir, a Brazilian carrier that plans to add domestic and international flights.

headline: A Compromise on Use of Avastin to Treat Eye Disease
abstract: Genentech appears to have resolved a dispute with ophthalmologists that will allow its drug Avastin to continue to be used to treat eye diseases, boths sides said.

headline: Payload: Taking Aim at Corporate Bribery
abstract: A probe of a British military contractor is but one in a bounty of investigations recently started under a once-obscure anticorruption law.

abstract: The opposition leader Benazir Bhutto said she had warned the Pakistani government that suicide bomb squads were going to go after her on her return to the country.

headline: Korean Leaders Open Talks
abstract: In their first meeting in 15 years, the prime ministers of North and South Korea discussed economic initiatives today.

headline: Fed Official Hints at No Rate Cut
abstract: A Federal Reserve governor warned today that another interest rate cut would probably offer few benefits to the economy.

headline: Georgia Leader Calls Early Election to Decide His Fate
abstract: The president of Georgia, Mikheil Saakashvili, on Thursday called for a special presidential election on Jan. 5, saying he would test whether he retained a mandate.

headline: In Iran, Group of ‘Mothers’ Criticizes Nuclear Policy
abstract: More than 500 Iranian women calling themselves “mothers of peace” have signed a letter to senior officials expressing their fear that there will be a war over Iran’s nuclear program.

headline: China: Advocate Said to Be Tortured
abstract: Yang Chunlin, a land rights activist who was detained in July after obtaining more than 10,000 signatures on a petition that proclaimed human rights more important than playing host to the Olympics, has been chained for days in fixed position and forced to clean the wastes of other inmates, according to the group China Human Rights Defenders. Mr. Yang is awaiting trial in Heilongjiang Province on charges of subverting state power. According to relatives, he has been denied access to a lawyer.

headline: G.M. Sales Rise; Most Rivals Down
abstract: G.M.’s U.S. sales were up 4 percent in September, while Honda’s increased 13.8 percent. But Toyota, Ford and Chrysler all sold fewer vehicles.

headline: Giving to Charity, Through Real Estate
abstract: The Ventures column last Sunday, about donating real estate to charitable organizations, misspelled the surname of the director of gift planning at New York University, where donated apartments have been used to house faculty members. He is Alan Shapiro, not Shaprio.

abstract: The food magazine Bon Appétit hired a well-known designer to transform the former site of a Hard Rock Cafe into a temporary restaurant, scheduled to last only two weeks.

abstract: Hunter Lewis presents both yes and no answers to the titular question and several related ones in “Are the Rich Necessary?”

abstract: Two car bombs exploded in quick succession near United Nations offices and an Algerian government building.

abstract: Rarely on Wall Street, where money travels in herds, has one firm gotten it so right when nearly everyone else was getting it so wrong.

abstract: The house of the prominent Sunni, Adnan al-Dulaimi, a leader of the Iraqi Consensus Front, is in Adel, an affluent Sunni-majority neighborhood in Baghdad.

abstract: The verdict against a mother of two from Minnesota was a crucial victory for the recording industry in its legal effort to rein in music piracy.

abstract: American military officials and Iraqi investigators say the F.B.I. and State Department are refusing to share information with them on their investigation into the Blackwater killings.

headline: Not a Jolly Season for 2 Top Bankers
abstract: Despite a very bad year, the chiefs of both Bear Stearns and Morgan Stanley are holding on to their power.

headline: Investor Safe Haven Becomes a Concern
abstract: In another sign of turmoil in the credit markets, large financial firms are being forced to protect money market funds from losses brought on by investments that no longer seem safe.

headline: Investors Shrug Off Global Cash Injection
abstract: Market euphoria over trans-Atlantic action by central banks to fix the global credit crisis wore off quickly Thursday, with investors saying they expect the injection of cash to do little to solve long-term problems.

headline: China Detains Dissident, Citing Subversion
abstract: The authorities have detained a prominent Chinese human rights advocate on suspicion of subversion, escalating a crackdown on dissent.

headline: Memo Pad
abstract: THE WORST YEAR Domestic airline performance through September of this year ranked as the worst for any comparable period in at least 12 years, the Transportation Department’s Bureau of Transportation Statistics reported yesterday. Through September, 73.18 percent of flights arrived on time this year, compared with 76.14 percent in the same period last year and the 12-year high, 82.82 percent in 2003. The worst 3 of the top 32 major airports through September of this year were all in the New York area: Newark Liberty (59.60 percent on time) LaGuardia (59.85 percent) and Kennedy (60.86 percent). The best three were Salt Lake City (80.31 percent), and Oakland (80.22 percent) and San Diego (78.95 percent) in California.

headline: British Premier Will Withdraw More Iraq Troops
abstract: Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Britain said he planned to withdraw 500 additional troops from Iraq’s southern region by the end of the year.

headline: Court Rejects Fuel Standards on Trucks
abstract: A federal appeals court said that new fuel-economy standards for light trucks, including S.U.V.’s, didn’t thoroughly assess the impact of greenhouse gases.

headline: In China, a Rising Star Falters
abstract: The reputation of China Expert Technology suffers as hints of possible fraud emerge.

headline: Separatist Rebels Accuse Ethiopia’s Military of Killing Civilians in Remote Region
abstract: Separatist rebels fighting in the Ogaden region of Ethiopia accused the government on Monday of strafing nomads in recent days at a watering hole with helicopter gunships, killing up to a dozen civilians.

headline: I.R.S. Looks at Mortgage Securities
abstract: The I.R.S. is examining the use of arcane but powerful investment entities known as real estate mortgage investment conduits to see if participants are reaping illegal tax benefits.

headline: Trade Deficit Narrowed in August
abstract: The trade gap shrank to its lowest level since January as a weak dollar bolstered export sales to record levels and the cost of non-energy imports dipped, the government said.

headline: At Wikipedia, Illustrators May Be Paid
abstract: The foundation that runs Wikipedia has finally agreed to pay contributors who create illustrations for the online encyclopedia a modest fee for their work.

headline: ‘Kid Nation’ Slips in Viewers but Gains in Advertisers
abstract: Although the audience for “Kid Nation” has continued to shrink, the CBS reality program has nearly tripled its number of advertisers since the series premiere.

headline: Google to Join Spectrum Auction
abstract: Google could use the frequencies to offer nationwide wireless broadband access, competing with DSL and cable.

headline: Ruling to Delay Word on Pakistan Vote Tally
abstract: Saturday’s vote will be held, but a court will rule after the election on legal challenges against Gen. Pervez Musharraf.

headline: Icahn Acquires More Shares of Blockbuster, Nudging His Stake to 16%
abstract: Carl C. Icahn holds 13.2 million shares of Blockbuster Class A shares, according to a filing yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Canceling Harman Deal, Suitors Buy Bonds Instead
abstract: Goldman Sachs and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts agreed to end their $8 billion buyout of Harman International, which makes speakers, and instead buy $400 million of the company’s bonds.

headline: Teachers Buys Glass Lewis for $46 Million
abstract: The Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan has bought Glass Lewis, a San Francisco-based investment research, proxy advisory and voting services firm, for $46 million from its Chinese owner, Xinhua Finance of Shanghai.

headline: A Different Formula for a Biogen Deal
abstract: Will DNA get mixed up in a sale of Biogen Idec?

headline: A Toast to the Top Women in Banking
abstract: At a gathering to toast the most powerful women in banking, there was a generally sense that despite some important inroads, more work was to be done.

headline: Schlumberger Offers $679 Million for Eastern Echo
abstract: Schlumberger, the oil-field services company, bid up to $679 million for a Norwegian-listed company, Eastern Echo, on Tuesday to expand its seismic operations at a time when record oil prices are driving demand.

headline: Ex-Chief Considers Bid for Children’s Place
abstract: Shares of Children’s Place rose 6 percent Monday after the company’s recently ousted chief executive and its largest shareholder, said he might put together an offer to buy the retailer.

headline: Perelman Seeks $500 Million ‘Blank Check’
abstract: MAFS Acquisition, a blank-check company led by billionaire financier Ronald O. Perelman, filed with regulators to raise as much as $500 million to fund an acquisition.

headline: Wary of Risk, Bankers Sold Shaky Mortgage Debt
abstract: As the subprime loan crisis deepens, Wall Street firms are increasingly coming under scrutiny for their role in selling risky mortgage-related securities to investors.

headline: A Dark-Horse Candidate for Citi’s Top Job?
abstract: Since last month, Citigroup has struggled to find a replacement for Charles O. Prince III, its recently resigned chief executive. It has looked inside the sprawling financial giant; it has examined the firm’s alumni (some of whom left the firm unwillingly); it has cast its eyes on the top executives of its rivals.

headline: Female Directors Earn More Than Men, Study Finds
abstract: A new survey on corporate board pay has come up with a surprising find: The median compensation for female directors is actually higher than that for male directors.

headline: They Told You So
abstract: By PETER EDMONSTON

headline: Media Analyst Takes Post at Time Warner
abstract: Time Warner has quietly hired a prominent media analyst as it reshuffles its executive ranks in the weeks before Jeffrey L. Bewkes takes over as chief executive.

headline: German Bank Acts to Help Its Programs Tied to U.S. Mortgages
abstract: The German bank WestLB said Monday it would guarantee full liquidity to several of its investment vehicles that had put money into asset-backed securities.

headline: Postive Data for Abbott’s Proposed Heart Stent
abstract: The newest data showed that the Xience V stent outperformed the market leader in preventing coronary arteries from reclogging over a two-year period in more than 600 patients.

headline: Slot Machines for the Young and Active
abstract: A new class of slot machines, aimed at attracting younger players who grew up with video games, is demanding something more than the ability to pull a lever — skill.

headline: Cave May Hold Secrets to Legend of Ancient Rome
abstract: Italy has released the first images of a deep cavern where some archaeologists believe ancient Romans honored Romulus and Remus — the legendary founders of Rome.

headline: Spain: Court Bomb Suspects on Trial
abstract: Thirty men suspected of being Islamic terrorists, most of them Moroccans and Algerians, went on trial at the National Court in Madrid, the building they are charged with plotting to blow up.

headline: Despite U.S. Opposition, United Nations Budget Is Approved
abstract: The General Assembly approved a two-year budget of $4.17 billion, with the U.S. casting the only vote against the measure because it included financing for a conference the U.S. felt would be prejudicial to Israel.

headline: A Golf Course Where Water Is No Hazard
abstract: Afghanistan’s only golf course is the result of one man’s dreamy vision nudged ever closer to a rugged reality.

headline: More Jobs to Be Cut at Alcatel After Loss
abstract: Alcatel-Lucent said it plans to cut 4,000 more jobs, equal to 5 percent of its work force, on top of the 12,500 cuts it has already announced.

headline: Insider-Trading Inquiry at Airbus Owner Advances
abstract: The case in France centers on whether executives of E.A.D.S. and Airbus were aware of problems with production of the Airbus A380 when they exercised stock options.

headline: Hunt for Cholesterol Drug Is Not Over
abstract: Drugs to raise so-called good cholesterol may still have a future despite the failure last year of an experimental treatment from Pfizer, researchers said.

headline: State-Run Florida Fund Hit by Withdrawals
abstract: School districts and local governments in Florida have pulled $8 billion out of a state-run investment pool after learning that the money market fund contained more than $700 million of defaulted debt.

headline: Eni of Italy Signs a Pipeline Deal With Gazprom
abstract: Gazprom signed a contract with Eni, the Italian energy group, to build a pipeline linking Russia to Europe via the Black Sea.

headline: A Made-for-TV Boss Helps Revive ABC
abstract: Meet Stephen McPherson, the latest Hollywood executive cast in the dual roles of entertainment genius and volatile bulldozer.

headline: G.M. Posts Its Biggest Quarterly Loss
abstract: The automaker reported a $39-billion loss after it took a huge noncash charge to write down deferred tax credits.

headline: WORLD BRIEFING | EUROPE; Greece: Labor Minister Fired
abstract: The government appointed a new labor and welfare minister after dismissing her predecessor over the weekend.

headline: For the Yachting Class, the Latest Amenity Can Take Flight
abstract: Many among the rich or famous want a yacht, and what buyers want most now are accessories: minisubmarines and helicopters.

headline: Musharraf Lifts State of Emergency in Pakistan
abstract: The move restores fundamental rights weeks ahead of parliamentary elections but will not resolve tensions in Pakistan.

headline: Central Bankers to Lend Billions in Credit Crisis
abstract: Led by the Fed, five central banks announced an aggressive infusion of capital into the banking system, hoping to ease the credit crunch.

headline: Solving and Marketing Eternity (Again)
abstract: Putting together a successful media plan to introduce a product has been likened to solving a puzzle. Now, to bring out a prize puzzle in the United States that has proved popular overseas, a toy company is proceeding initially without traditional advertising in the mainstream media.

headline: Discontented, DreamWorks Is in Talks to Join NBC
abstract: Although NBC Universal is interested in striking a deal, it wants DreamWorks to find outside financing to make its movies, which Universal could then distribute.

headline: A Universe of Gadget Advice
abstract: Buying a book online is easy, but buying electronics can be intimidating. The bad news is there is no one-stop shop for consumer electronics.

headline: Tapped Out, but Hopeful: A Break in Texas’s Oil Decline
abstract: As oil approaches $100 a barrel, there is plenty of incentive to find more American oil, but even with new investment, the nation’s oil fields are mostly tapped out.

headline: Bush Offers Turkish Leader Help Against Rebels
abstract: President Bush declined to answer how he would react if the Turks launched a major attack into Iraqi Kurdistan but said both sides agreed that some action was necessary.

headline: In Argentina, a Campaign Promising Change Offers More of the Same
abstract: Cristina Fernández de Kirchner could risk losing the support of Argentina’s lower classes if she does not move to stem rising inflation and prevent a looming energy crisis.

headline: Mideast Teams Begin Peace Talks
abstract: Israeli and Palestinian negotiating teams met in Jerusalem on Wednesday to start peace talks toward a permanent status agreement, but the only agreement made was to meet again.

headline: Sallie Mae Sues to Force a Buyout
abstract: The giant student lender is suing the firms that agreed to buy it, but are now trying to renegotiate the deal.

headline: Drug Makers Help Lead Rebound in Overseas Shares
abstract: Global stocks rebounded Thursday from their lowest point in more than two months, led by drug makers and utilities, whose profits are less vulnerable to an economic slowdown.

headline: Chinese Chemicals Flow Unchecked Onto World Drug Market
abstract: Pharmaceutical ingredients exported from China are often made by companies that are neither certified nor inspected by Chinese drug regulators.

headline: F.B.I. Says Guards Killed 14 Iraqis Without Cause
abstract: An investigation of the shooting deaths of 17 Iraqi civilians by Blackwater personnel found that all but three of the shootings were unjustified, officials said.

headline: Google Enters the Wireless World
abstract: Google announced that it is leading an industry alliance to transform mobile phones into powerful computers.

headline: Divided Korea Paralyzes Families Torn Apart Long Ago
abstract: Thousands of South Korean families are still waiting to hear from loved ones taken to North Korea as prisoners during the Korean War over a century ago.

headline: If You Thought a Half-Hour of TV Was Worth 4 Minutes, Here’s Proof
abstract: The mini-episodes of discontinued TV programs, to be shown online, are part of a Pepsi campaign designed to celebrate the brand’s old logos, slogans and jingles.

headline: Success Without Ads
abstract: Consumer Reports, a monthly magazine, continues to thrive with a subscription-only model, even on the Web.

headline: Executive Says Imus Deserves Another Chance
abstract: The chief executive of the media company that is believed to be on the brink of returning Don Imus to broadcast radio said Friday that Mr. Imus’s firing was sufficient punishment for his derogatory comments.

headline: If Buyout Firms Are So Smart, Why Are They So Wrong?
abstract: Private equity firms have repeatedly broken their word when breaking a deal, trying to shift the blame to investment banks.

headline: Bomb Explodes in Pakistan, Killing Woman Carrying It
abstract: It was unclear whether the woman was a suicide bomber or whether she was carrying a bomb to plant it somewhere.

headline: Protector of Lake Loses Appeal in Chinese Court
abstract: A Chinese environmental leader lost his appeal of a conviction on blackmail and fraud charges, even as authorities promised to clean up the lake he fought to protect.

headline: Here, a Nick While Shaving Could Determine the Stanley Cup
abstract: A properly piloted Zamboni can do more good than any other single piece of grooming equipment in major league sports.

headline: Legal or Not, Abortion Rates Compare
abstract: A comprehensive global study of abortion suggests that outlawing the procedure does little to deter women seeking it.

headline: A Magazine Challenges the Big Boys
abstract: Amid growing media overload, reading matter piles up at home, but The Week is read.

headline: Toy Makers’ Responses to Lead-Test Findings
abstract: Below are written responses from two public relations agencies representing RC2, the company that makes Thomas the Tank Engine toys. The first comes from Nancy Davies of Salmon Borre Group in Lake Forest, Ill. (The bold-faced sections are Ms. Davies’s summary of the questions I asked her over the phone.) The second response — about whether RC2 is offering refunds — comes from Joanne Tremulis of Burson-Marsteller in Chicago.

headline: Tea Leaves Don’t Show a Holiday Lift
abstract: For stocks to reverse their slide, investors probably will have to overlook the negative impact that the housing market seems to be having.

headline: Tax Cuts Increased Income, but Hardly Equally
abstract: The I.R.S. income data help explain why so many Americans report feeling economic distress, despite overall economic growth since the Internet bubble burst in 2000.

headline: Baghdad’s Weary Start to Exhale as Security Improves
abstract: Iraqis are beginning to reclaim their lost lives five months after extra U.S. troops arrived, but the depth of the changes remains open to question.

headline: Big Law Firm Settles Age-Discrimination Suit
abstract: Sidley Austin, one of the nation’s largest law firms, has agreed to pay $27.5 million to 32 former partners to settle a closely watched age-discrimination lawsuit.

headline: A Surgeon Opens Up, and Not With a Scalpel
abstract: Dr. Thomas R. Russell, the executive director of the American College of Surgeons, discusses medical innovation, the health care crisis and more.

headline: Sarkozy Walks Out on ’60 Minutes’
abstract: President Nicolas Sarkozy of France was clearly upset about a question posed by the correspondent Lesley Stahl about his marriage.

headline: The Law of Unintended Consequences?
abstract: A new study has found that the Sarbanes-Oxley Act may have made Wall Street analysts less able to forecast corporate earnings.

headline: The Performer in Waiting
abstract: “After you’ve seen life and death, it kind of puts into context what happens in an artistic institution.”

headline: Imbibers Add It All Up, and Gulp
abstract: Some people are surprised to find that the money they spend on alcohol can add up to tens of thousands in lost retirement savings.

headline: Sending Up Satellites and Closing the Digital Divide
abstract: Pradman P. Kaul, C.E.O. of Hughes Communications, discusses satellite communications and how his company can compete with cable and phone companies.

headline: I Want My Web TV
abstract: A growing number of people are watching TV online; sometimes the future looks very different when it arrives and more.

headline: Making a Millionaire Feel Special Once Again
abstract: With average account sizes around $3 to $5 million, registered advisers are marketing themselves as providers of objective financial advice.

headline: A Place in the Sun (and Close to Campus)
abstract: Many college towns are beginning or stepping up efforts to lure retirees.

headline: For Love and a Little Money
abstract: Some retirees have found that being paid something for doing volunteer work can be good for both the organization and for themselves.

headline: Shut Out in Kyrgyzstan Elections, Opposition Party Vows Protests
abstract: President Kurmanbek Bakiyev called the election three years ahead of schedule to break a stalemate with the previous Parliament, which was dominated by the opposition.

headline: When Employees Sue
abstract: Preventing relationships with employees from going sour - or worse yet, leading to legal action - often comes down to common sense.

headline: The Hague: General Who Besieged Sarajevo Gets 33 Years
abstract: The International Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia sentenced Dragomir Milosevic a former Bosnian-Serb general, to 33 years in prison.

headline: System ‘Failed’ Young Rape Victim
abstract: Outrage and disbelief continued to spread across Australia over the decision of a local judge to allow nine Aborigines who pleaded guilty to the gang rape of a 10-year-old Aboriginal girl last year to walk free.

headline: Teachers Buys Glass Lewis for $46 Million
abstract: The Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan has bought Glass Lewis, a San Francisco-based investment research, proxy advisory and voting services firm, for $46 million from its Chinese owner, Xinhua Finance of Shanghai.

abstract: Schlumberger, the oil-field services company, bid up to $679 million for a Norwegian-listed company, Eastern Echo, on Tuesday to expand its seismic operations at a time when record oil prices are driving demand.

abstract: MAFS Acquisition, a blank-check company led by billionaire financier Ronald O. Perelman, filed with regulators to raise as much as $500 million to fund an acquisition.

abstract: As the subprime loan crisis deepens, Wall Street firms are increasingly coming under scrutiny for their role in selling risky mortgage-related securities to investors.
