abstract: Since last month, Citigroup has struggled to find a replacement for Charles O. Prince III, its recently resigned chief executive. It has looked inside the sprawling financial giant; it has examined the firm’s alumni (some of whom left the firm unwillingly); it has cast its eyes on the top executives of its rivals.

headline: Female Directors Earn More Than Men, Study Finds
abstract: A new survey on corporate board pay has come up with a surprising find: The median compensation for female directors is actually higher than that for male directors.

headline: They Told You So
abstract: By PETER EDMONSTON

headline: Thailand Race Begins
abstract: Official campaigning for Thailand’s first general elections since last year’s military coup began Wednesday as 18 parties registered for the Dec. 23 balloting.

headline: Striking Writers Peddle Words, for Outlets Off the Picket Line
abstract: Sometimes it seems that every time the striking television and movie writers put down their picket signs, they pick up their pencils.

headline: The Fed Jammed Your In-Box
abstract: Troubles in the credit market are fueling a boom in e-mail spam, companies are looking for ways around the Do Not Call list and more.

headline: Christian Split in Lebanon Raises Specter of Civil War
abstract: Many Lebanese worry that another civil war is imminent and some in its divided Christian community have begun re-establishing militias.

headline: Tip of the Week: Is Your Computer Connected to the Internet?
abstract: Your computer may look as if it’s just sitting there innocently, but it could be secretly connecting to the Internet.

headline: A Practical Strategy for Growth Investing
abstract: If you can look past Louis Navellier’s boasting, “The Little Book That Makes You Rich” is a useful book on growth investing.

headline: Glaxo Appoints New Chief
abstract: Andrew Witty was named GlaxoSmithKline’s new chief executive, ending a yearlong internal competition to succeed Jean-Pierre Garnier, who retires next year.

headline: Yum Profit Rises 17%, Propelled by Overseas Growth
abstract: The fast-food giant said its third-quarter profit had risen 17 percent on the strength of surging sales in the international and China divisions.

headline: Cerberus Seeks Court Ruling to End Deal
abstract: Cerberus, still trying to scuttle its $4 billion purchase of United Rentals Inc., said that it had filed a request for declaratory judgment in New York State Supreme Court.

headline: Natixis’s Bond Insurer to Receive $1.5 Billion
abstract: Natixis SA’s bond-insurance unit, CIFG Guaranty, will be taken over by the French bank’s controlling shareholders in a $1.5 billion rescue to preserve its top credit rating.

headline: Lebanon’s Leaders Unable to Agree as Deadline Nears
abstract: Politicians living in a security cocoon far from the public eye struggled to negotiate a deal in a series of last-ditch sessions before President Lahoud’s term expires.

headline: Crazy Little Thing Called Risk
abstract: Investors are learning that others’ moves can ruin a portfolio.

headline: Some Hunches About Intuition
abstract: Some managers might be able to improve their intuition, while others could learn from charting it.

headline: Being Skeptical of Green
abstract: Consumers who think they can help improve the environment should be careful when it comes to their purchasing decisions and avoid relying on labels.

headline: Building a Greener Cardboard Box
abstract: Recycling programs are  improving the environmental impact of all the packaging Americans consume, says Patrick J. Moore, chairman and chief executive of the Smurfit-Stone Container Corporation.

headline: China Minsheng Buys Stake in U.S. Lender
abstract: China Minsheng Banking said Monday it would pay up to $317 million for a 9.9 percent stake in UCBH Holdings, the parent company of United Commercial Bank of San Francisco.

headline: Dubai Feels Sting as Och-Ziff Slides
abstract: Funds from overseas have been eagerly acquiring stakes in United States-based private equity firms and hedge funds, with mixed results so far. The Chinese government’s $3 billion investment in the Blackstone Group has been a money loser. On Monday, Dubai’s big bet on Och-Ziff Capital Management offered another cautionary tale.

headline: Goldman Sachs to Build Philanthropy Fund
abstract: On the back of record profit so far this year, Goldman Sachs, the global investment bank, is starting a donor-driven philanthropy fund that intends to reach $1 billion over the next few years.

headline: Germany Forces More Hedge Fund Disclosure
abstract: Germany’s cabinet has approved a bill that would force hedge funds to disclose details of the financing and timing of their takeover bids for public companies.

headline: Biogen Sale: A $30 Bllion Deal or a Busted Auction?
abstract: Biogen Idec, the biotechnology company that is reportedly attempting to sell itself to a major pharmaceuticals company before the end of the year, may be having trouble finding a buyer. Biogen Idec shares have fallen sharply over the last month on concern the Cambridge company won’t fetch much of a premium – if it sells at all.

headline: Plaintiffs Face Skeptical Court in Key Fraud Case
abstract: Shareholders looking for deep pockets to sue in securities fraud cases faced an uphill battle at the Supreme Court on Tuesday.

headline: Yahoo to Buy 10% of Alibaba’s I.P.O. Shares
abstract: Yahoo will subscribe for 10 percent of the shares to be sold by Alibaba.com, China’s largest e-commerce company, in an initial public offering that is expected to raise about $1 billion, according to a term sheet.

headline: Cruz Is Out at Morgan Stanley
abstract: Morgan Stanley said that Zoe Cruz, a co-president and one of the highest-ranking women on Wall Street, would leave the investment bank in the latest management shakeup since the summer’s credit turmoil.

headline: Late-Night Hosts: ‘We’ll Be Right Back’?
abstract: At least six of the eight late-night television hosts who have stayed off the air during the writers’ strike are paying the salaries of their nonwriting staff members, Bill Carter notes in today’s Times. “The question the hosts are struggling with is how long they can continue to stay off the air and subsidize their staffs, and what happens when they decide they cannot do it any longer.”

headline: Bioheart Cuts I.P.O. Price
abstract: The biotechnology company Bioheart slashed the expected price range of its planned initial public offering, while slightly increasing its size, according to a regulatory filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Thursday.

headline: Swedish Bank Picks Up Fund of Hedge Funds
abstract: A Swedish bank, SEB, acquired Key Asset Management, a manager of funds of hedge funds based in London.

headline: Cardtonics Falls in First-Day Trading
abstract: An automatic teller machine operator, Cardtronics, faced difficulty getting cash from the market for initial public offerings in its stock market debut on Tuesday, according to MarketWatch.

headline: Critiquing a Critique of Private Equity
abstract: The verdicts are in on Robert Greenwald’s new short film critiquing the head of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

headline: Revisiting Flowers’ (First) Shinsei Deal
abstract: J. Christopher Flowers has been a busy globe-trotter lately. As The Financial Times’ Alphaville points out, the head of J.C. Flowers & Company has bid for, and subsequently tried to run away from, Sallie Mae; reportedly made an offer for Britain’s Northern Rock; and taken a stake in Germany’s HSH Nordbank. But on Tuesday, he returned to the deal that put him on the map, leading a consortium for a $1.8 billion stake in Japan’s Shinsei Bank.

headline: Who Will Sit On Jay and Conan’s Couches?
abstract: How are late-night hosts going to be funny without writers, and who is going to sit on their couches as guests?

headline: Show Runners May Be One-Half On Strike
abstract: The Writers Guild of America represents screenwriters for both film and television. But those writers are considerably more powerful behind the scenes of the small screen, and that fact “has big implications if Hollywood writers go on strike next month,” Ed Wyatt writes in today’s Times.

headline: Switzerland’s Galencia Swallows Canadian Rival
abstract: Galenica, Switzerland’s largest drug wholesaler, agreed to buy Aspreva Pharmaceuticals of Canada for $915 million to hasten development of new treatments and expand into additional markets.

headline: Thoma and Cressey Move for a Breakup
abstract: Longtime private equity partners Carl Thoma and Bryan Cressey will split their Chicago-based firm into two separate investment teams as a possible prelude to a definitive divorce.

headline: Weak Dollar May Reduce European Bonuses
abstract: The drop of the American dollar against the British pound and the euro may claim some of the bonus money of European investment bankers as the latest victim.

headline: Authoria Takes $22.5 Million from V.C.s
abstract: Authoria, a maker of personnel and human resources software, raised $22.5 million in a fifth round of debt and equity funding from a group including two new investors, Horizon Technology Finance and Velocity Financial Group.

headline: Coty Buys Kelso’s Del Labs for $800 Million
abstract: Kelso & Company, a private equity firm, said it would sell Del Laboratories, which makes Sally Hansen nail care products, to the fragrance giant Coty in a deal valued at about $800 million, according to The Deal.com.

headline: Programming for Kids, from Cradle to Adulthood
abstract: Starting today, the preschool network Noggin and the teen network The N no longer share a channel.

headline: Rio Tinto Rejects $140 Billion Takeover Bid
abstract: BHP Billiton said Thursday that it had approached Rio Tinto about a potential takeover that would create a global mining giant worth about $360 billion. Rio rejected its offer, but BHP added that it would continue to press for a deal, which would rank among the largest mergers in history.

headline: Banks’ Plan to Help May Need Help Itself
abstract: Does the rescue plan for the credit markets need to be saved?

headline: Unhappy Tesla Founder, or Impostor?
abstract: On Friday, Tesla Motors issued a statement on its Web site explaining that the Silicon Valley electric-car start-up’s founder and former chief executive, Martin Eberhard, “has transitioned from the board of directors and executive management of the company to the advisory board.”

headline: Follow That Oval Leather Ball
abstract: NBC scored a victory in the ratings on the last Sunday of 2007 thanks to its prime time football coverage, which earned approximately 14 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s overnight estimates. CBS and Fox finished second and third, respectively, with both networks benefiting from overruns of their own football coverage, which extended well into the 7 p.m. hour.

headline: New Contract for ABC News Writers
abstract: The Writers Guild of America and ABC have reached an agreement on a new contract for 250 ABC News writers, editors, artists, assistants, and researchers, the guild said Thursday morning.

headline: The Cost of Riding Stephen Schwarzman’s Private Jet
abstract: The Blackstone Group has avoided being grounded.

headline: I.B.M. Blue Gene Still the Fastest Computer
abstract: I.B.M. retains the title as maker of the world’s fasterst computer, but more of the fastest machines are overseas.

headline: A Boom Time for Islamic Finance
abstract: Even as banking segments like those that securitize subprime mortgages and finance leveraged buyouts suffer from the current crisis, Islamic finance is seeing spectacular growth.

headline: Lehman and the Benefits of Low Expectations
abstract: Analysts seemed divided on the results reported by Lehman Brothers, which ushered in a bleak earnings season for Wall Street on Thursday by saying quarterly profit fell 12 percent, reflecting a slump in its core fixed-income business. But while some analysts were disappointed, others were relieved.

headline: The Spectrum Auction Secrecy Begins
abstract: At least four major companies are thought to have filed today to bid in the coming auction for wireless spectrum. But F.C.C. rules prevent any of them from talking about it.

headline: Group Takes Stake in Countrywide
abstract: Brandes Investment Partners said Monday that it had taken a 7.9 percent stake in Countrywide Financial, becoming its second-largest investor.

headline: KRG Capital Closes $1.96 Billion Fund
abstract: Midmarket buyout firm KRG Capital Partners said it closed its fourth private equity fund at $1.96 billion, beating its $1.25 billion target by 57 percent.

headline: Digital Actors in ‘Beowulf’ Are Just Uncanny
abstract: The makers of the computer-animated movie “Beowulf” used motion-capture technology to digitize performances by famous actors — with some not-so-pleasing results.

headline: Warner Music’s Madonna Complex
abstract: As if digital music sales and unauthorized file-swapping weren’t bad enough, now the Warner Music Group has another potential headache on its hands. Her name is Madonna.

headline: EnCana to Pay $2.5 Billion in Texas Gas Deal
abstract: EnCana is paying $2.5 billion to buy out its partner in the Amoruso natural gas field in Texas. The play could become the most important in its North American portfolio.

headline: How to Spiff Up Your Résumé
abstract: Advice from a resume expert on how to make yours a recruiter’s dream.

headline: A Sunday Night Home Run for Fox
abstract: As the Boston Red Sox brought the World Series to an abrupt and early end on Sunday, Game 4, like the others in the series, proved to be a boon for Fox, lifting the network to first place in the night’s ratings. Although exact audience figures for the live broadcast were not yet available, Nielsen’s overnight estimates show Fox easily leading every time slot Sunday except the 9 p.m. hour when ABC’s “Desperate Housewives” finished first among adults 18 to 49, drawing 18.1 million total viewers.

headline: SAC Capital Trader Strikes Out on His Own
abstract: From Jenny Anderson, a DealBook colleague:

headline: Acxiom Says Buyers Will End Deal
abstract: Another day, another deal’s collapse.

headline: Ratings: Boost For ‘Samantha’ and ‘Big Bang’
abstract: ABC remained No. 1 in the ratings on Monday thanks to consistently solid audiences for “Dancing With the Stars” and “Samantha Who.”

headline: Al Gore, Venture Capitalist
abstract: Add another line to Al Gore’s ever-expanding resume.

headline: TPG Presses Ahead With Iberia Bid Despite Rival Offer
abstract: TPG Capital will push ahead with its offer for Spain’s No. 1 airline Iberia Lineas Aereas de España despite seeing its indicative 3.4 billion euro ($5 billion) offer trumped by a rival Spanish syndicate, The Deal.com reported.

headline: Financials, Once a Balm, Now Hamper the Market
abstract: As the air came out of the technology and telecommunications bubble this decade, the stock market found a new champion in the financial sector.

headline: Teachers Buys Glass Lewis for $46 Million
abstract: The Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan has bought Glass Lewis, a San Francisco-based investment research, proxy advisory and voting services firm, for $46 million from its Chinese owner, Xinhua Finance of Shanghai.

headline: A Different Formula for a Biogen Deal
abstract: Will DNA get mixed up in a sale of Biogen Idec?

headline: A Toast to the Top Women in Banking
abstract: At a gathering to toast the most powerful women in banking, there was a generally sense that despite some important inroads, more work was to be done.

headline: Schlumberger Offers $679 Million for Eastern Echo
abstract: Schlumberger, the oil-field services company, bid up to $679 million for a Norwegian-listed company, Eastern Echo, on Tuesday to expand its seismic operations at a time when record oil prices are driving demand.

headline: Ex-Chief Considers Bid for Children’s Place
abstract: Shares of Children’s Place rose 6 percent Monday after the company’s recently ousted chief executive and its largest shareholder, said he might put together an offer to buy the retailer.

headline: Perelman Seeks $500 Million ‘Blank Check’
abstract: MAFS Acquisition, a blank-check company led by billionaire financier Ronald O. Perelman, filed with regulators to raise as much as $500 million to fund an acquisition.

headline: Wary of Risk, Bankers Sold Shaky Mortgage Debt
abstract: As the subprime loan crisis deepens, Wall Street firms are increasingly coming under scrutiny for their role in selling risky mortgage-related securities to investors.

headline: A Dark-Horse Candidate for Citi’s Top Job?
abstract: Since last month, Citigroup has struggled to find a replacement for Charles O. Prince III, its recently resigned chief executive. It has looked inside the sprawling financial giant; it has examined the firm’s alumni (some of whom left the firm unwillingly); it has cast its eyes on the top executives of its rivals.

headline: Female Directors Earn More Than Men, Study Finds
abstract: A new survey on corporate board pay has come up with a surprising find: The median compensation for female directors is actually higher than that for male directors.

headline: They Told You So
abstract: By PETER EDMONSTON

headline: Carlyle Raises First Infrastructure Fund
abstract: The Carlyle Group, the private equity firm, has raised its first infrastructure fund, which is focused on North America, where the company believes public-private partnerships will increase. Common in Europe, these arrangements involve private companies that deliver and run public assets such as roads, schools and hospitals.

headline: A Divided Italian Governement Postpones Alitalia Decision
abstract: Alitalia on Thursday put off a decision to pick a buyer until next week after the Italian government failed to choose its preferred bidder for the ailing carrier.

headline: Resolution Said to Be Close to Accepting 11th Hour Bid
abstract: Resolution, the British insurer, was preparing last night to accept a bid by Standard Life, the Scottish life insurer and pensions provider, to acquire the business for 4.9 billion pounds ($10.1 billion), The Guardian reported.

headline: Permira to Invest in Macao Casino Operator
abstract: Permira, the London-based private equity group, plans to take a 20 percent stake in Galaxy Entertainment Group, a Hong Kong company that runs casinos and hotels in the former Portuguese colony of Macao. Permira will pay $840 million for the stake, according to a press release from Galaxy, which said it will raise an additional $163 million through an institutional placement of new shares.

headline: Assuming Jobs
abstract: Job growth is weaker than it looks

headline: Banks Bid for Japan Airlines’ Credit Card Unit, Report Says
abstract: Three financial companies, the Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, Japan’s largest publicly traded bank; the Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group; and Credit Saison may submit bids for Japan Airlines’ credit card unit, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: The Downsides to a Citi Split
abstract: As Citigroup searches for a new leader mid a series of staggering losses, many investors have clamored for another potential solution to the bank’s woes. A breakup.

headline: In DreamWorks Fight, It’s Mogul vs. Mogul
abstract: All of Hollywood was shaken up this year over reports of a deepening feud between Paramount and DreamWorks, the movie studio that is the home of Steven Spielberg. Press reports were atwitter with word that Mr. Spielberg wasn’t happy with the lack of recognition due DreamWorks — and a response in September from the head of Paramount’s parent, Viacom, that the studio’s walking away would be “completely immaterial.”

headline: ON Semiconductor Signs $915 Million Deal for Amis
abstract: ON Semiconductor agreed to buy chipmaker Amis Holdings for $915 million agreement, driven in part by depressed stock valuations and the specter of a down cycle in the chip industry.

headline: For Hedge Funds, Echoes of an Ugly August
abstract: At first glance, investors in OZ Master Fund, the flagship of the giant hedge-fund firm Och-Ziff Capital, might not be thrilled to learn that it was down 0.3 percent last month. (Now that Och-Ziff is publicly traded, we can all enjoy periodic updates on its funds’ performance.)

headline: Short Seller Sinks Teeth Into Insurer
abstract: William Ackman may be incapable of giving short answers, if his hourlong presentation at an investment conference last Wednesday is any sign. But the activist hedge fund manager is nothing if not persistent.

headline: Super Conduit Leaves Many Banks Cold
abstract: Two weeks after Bank of America, Citigroup, JP Morgan and Wachovia pledged their support for the Master Liquidity Enhancement Conduit, intended to take the sting out of the recent liquidity squeeze, other banks have chosen to look the other way.

headline: Tuesday Night Ratings Wrap-Up
abstract: In the third week of its fourth season, Fox’s medical drama “House,” with Hugh Laurie, continued to soar in the ratings, leading Tuesday night with 17.7 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Among adults 18 to 49, the 9 p.m. show easily surpassed its closest competitors on the night, NBC’s “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit,” which won the 10 p.m. hour with 12.2 million total viewers, and ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” results episode at 9 p.m. (16 million), which finished third overall in the 18 to 49 set.For the night, Fox ranked No. 1, despite its drama “Bones” (8.3 million) finishing runner up at 8 p.m. to CBS’s “NCIS” (16.1 million). CBS earned second place overall in total viewers but finished fourth among adults 18 to 49.

headline: Start-up Aims to Be Digital-Content Bazaar
abstract: A startup coming out of stealth mode is hoping to upend the market for digital products in the same way eBay did for all types of physical products, the Red Herring reports.

headline: Dubai’s DP World Said to Eye $3.5 Billion I.P.O.
abstract: DP World, the Dubai government port owner with holdings from Britain to China, plans to raise as much as $3.5 billion in the Middle East’s second-biggest initial share offering, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: In Hollywood, Shows of Solidarity
abstract: Some prominent show runners — “the writer-producers who fill multiple roles at the helm of television programs” — are siding with the Writers Guild of America.

headline: Citi May Start New Round of Layoffs
abstract: Is more pain in store for Citigroup?

headline: Euronext to Launch Private Equity Index
abstract: Euronext, the European stock exchange grouping of NYSE Euronext, plans to launch a private equity index early next year, to be published alongside its market benchmarks, a senior exchange official said Wednesday.

headline: Multitasking I Can Support
abstract: A new company puts a healthful twist on business networking.

headline: Cerberus Backs Out of United Rentals Deal
abstract: United Rentals, the rental equipment company, said Wednesday that Cerberus Capital Management had backed out of its planned $4 billion purchase of the company.

headline: NBC Universal Plays Catch-Up in International Markets
abstract: “Among the big American media companies, NBC Universal was late to move into international markets,” Eric Pfanner writes in Sunday’s International Herald Tribune.

headline: Qwaq Suits Up With $7 Million Round
abstract: Much like Second Life, Qwaq Forums uses animated avatars representing users to populate 3-D office spaces, complete with rotating fans and potted plants. Only instead of being a time killer, Qwaq Forums aims to actually increase productivity by allowing clients to skip those long flights and stuffy conference rooms and let their avatars take the meeting for them.

headline: Morgan Stanley Eyes Big India Push
abstract: Morgan Stanley is unleashing a major drive to tap India’s domestic wealth next year, hiring 100 private bankers in a bid to manage $1 billion in assets by the end of 2010.

headline: The Future of Journalism Is Stuck in the Lincoln Tunnel
abstract: One person who isn’t on the program for Wednesday’s Network Journalism Summit but should be is Joshua Crandall, the founder of Clever Commute, a service through which bus and train riders alert each other to delays.

headline: The Back Door Into Facebook Ads
abstract: Although Microsoft has locked up banner ad space on the site, companies like AdBrite still see opportunities in other areas of Facebook.

headline: New England V.C.’s Get Their Own Networking Site
abstract: People who sign in to the newest social network won’t be looking for dates or posting a list of their favorite movies. They will be searching for companies to invest in and listing their interests in areas like clean energy or enterprise software.

headline: Atomic Wedgie: Better to Watch Than Receive
abstract: FremantleMedia, the production company behind “The Price Is Right” and the British version of “American Idol,” wants to cash in on recent interest in Web-to-television programming deals.

headline: Starwood’s Founder Makes a New Splash
abstract: In 2005, when Barry Sternlicht left Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide, a company he founded and turned into one of the world’s largest hotel chains, few people might have thought that he would be returning to the industry less than two years later. And in such a splashy way.

headline: Christmas Specials Include 24 Hours of ‘Miracle On 34th Street’
abstract: Fox Movie Channel is showing “Miracle On 34th Street” from 6 a.m. Tuesday to 6 a.m. Wednesday, Kathryn Shattuck notes:

headline: Resources for Job-Seeking Veterans
abstract: A new program that trains military personnel for technology jobs is good news for those heading toward civilian life.

headline: Will ABN Deal Become a Headache?
abstract: After seven months of fierce battling, the Royal Bank of Scotland-led consortium, comprised of Dutch-Belgian Fortis and Spain’s Banco Santander, finally won the bid for the Dutch bank ABN Amro for $99.1 billion in the largest financial-services takeover ever.

headline: China to Allow Hong Kong Stock Purchases, Analyst Says
abstract: China will introduce a program allowing individuals to invest directly in Hong Kong equities in the second quarter of next year, HSBC Holdings said.

headline: Tough Times for V.C.s?
abstract: According to BusinessWeek, this is a bad time to be a venture capitalist. Anyone who says differently, Sarah Lacy writes, “is raising a new fund — or works at one of the few firms having a good year.”

headline: The Luddite in the Googleplex
abstract: Speaking to the especially wired group of executives and politicians at Google’s Zeitgeist conference, Yves Chouinard, the founder of the Patagonia outdoor clothing maker, said he has never used a keyboard and that technology tends to homogenize culture.

headline: Tips from Blogland
abstract: Advice from bloggers about building relationships with the media and about how introverts can use the Internet.

headline: Ex-Executive of Wal-Mart Drops Suit on Severance
abstract: A former advertising executive for Wal-Mart Stores has decided to drop her breach-of-contract lawsuit against the retailer, saying that the lawsuit had become financially draining and more complex than she had expected.

headline: How Does Goldman Do It?
abstract: Among Wall Street’s big investment banks, one has remained an object of fascination and more than a little envy of late. We speak, of course, of Goldman Sachs, which has managed to avoid the subprime-related write-downs that its brethren have been forced to take. The firm was not even among those subpoenaed by Andrew Cuomo, New York’s attorney general, for information related to its subprime-tied activities.

headline: Credit Crunch Shows Signs of Easing
abstract: The leveraged-loan market, often used to finance leveraged buyouts, made an impressive rebound last month, according to Standard & Poor’s Leveraged Commentary & Data. But the comeback in the junk-bond market was more muted, The New York Times’s Floyd Norris wrote Saturday in his “Off the Charts” column.

headline: $200 Billion to Invest, but in China
abstract: As governments in the Middle East take big stakes in American companies, China’s state-run investment fund has quietly shifted its focus from overseas deals to bolstering the country’s troubled banking system.

headline: Will BofA Retreat From Investment Banking?
abstract: New York investment bankers sometimes refer to Bank of America as a “wannabe” investment bank, because its securities arm lacks the heft of its larger Wall Street rivals. On Thursday, Bank of America proved that its investment banking unit could mess things up just as well as the big guys.

headline: Cablevision’s Largest Shareholder to Oppose Buyout
abstract: Cablevision Systems‘s largest shareholder, ClearBridge Advisors, said early Wednesday it would vote against the Dolan family’s $10.6 billion proposed buyout of the company, putting the deal on the edge of collapse.

headline: Strike News: Both Sides Dig In
abstract: “Striking screenwriters on Thursday night dismissed a new set of proposals from producers as a massive rollback, and called on their members to continue their walkout with fresh resolve despite a plan to continue talks on Tuesday,” Michael Cieply reports.

headline: Strike Schedule: What Will ABC Do?
abstract: Of the four broadcast networks, ABC is the only one that has not announced plans for its January and February schedule, which will probably have to change because of the writers’ strike. In Sunday’s New York Times, Michael Cieply wrote that the alphabet network “could significantly increase its reality programming from the five to six hours it has run this fall”:

headline: In TV Versus Internet, TV Still Wins
abstract: Amid the buzz about DVR playback, iTunes downloads, YouTube video streaming, and Slingbox place-shifting, it’s easy for prognosticators to dismiss television as an antiquated medium.

headline: Britain Agrees to Guarantee More Northern Rock Debt
abstract: The British government deepened its involvement in Northern Rock on Tuesday, offering to guarantee more of the stricken mortgage bank’s liabilities as it battles to find a private-sector buyer.

headline: Barclays Sues Bear Stearns in Fund Collapse
abstract: Barclays Bank accused Bear Stearns on Wednesday of loading one of its hedge funds with about $500 million in troubled assets just weeks before it and another Bear Stearns fund collapsed.

headline: Nielsen Rescinds a New Ratings Policy
abstract: A recent Nielsen rule change allowed NBC last month to report two separate broadcasts of “Heroes” as one cumulative rating, which was thought to be a more accurate assessment of the show’s audience. But the single rating for two airings of the show angered rival networks and media buyers, who complained loudly to Nielsen.

headline: Court to Hear Arguments in Genesco Suit
abstract: The Tennessee Chancery Court will hear arguments Wednesday in Genesco‘s suit to enforce its $1.3 billion merger agreement with the shoe retailer Finish Line.

headline: Russia’s LSR Group Eyes $1.5 Billion I.P.O.
abstract: The LSR Group, a Russian real estate and building materials group, is planning to raise up to $1.5 billion from a dual listing in London and Moscow.

headline: DundeeWealth Shares Rise on Merger Speculation
abstract: DundeeWealth surged 6.7 percent on speculation that Bank of Nova Scotia may buy the Canadian money manager to expand its mutual-fund business.

headline: A Prince and His Palace in the Sky
abstract: It’s been a busy month for Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia. After helping to push Charles O. Prince III out of the top job at Citigroup, the bank’s largest shareholder is now claiming bragging rights to the world’s largest private jet.

headline: Biogen Shares Plummet as No Buyer Surfaces
abstract: Big pharmaceutical companies may be desperate for new products, but they apparently are not ready to obtain them at any price.

headline: Viewers Turning To The Web For TV
abstract: The most popular Web source for full episodes of television shows is ABC.com, according to a study conducted by The Nielsen Company and released today.

headline: Scripps to Split Into Two Companies
abstract: The media business is in spin mode.

headline: Ask Questions of Dan Nye, C.E.O. of LinkedIn
abstract: The future of social networking? Competing with Facebook? All those e-mails from people wanting you in their network? Ask your question for Dan Nye, the C.E.O. of LinkedIn, in the comments to this post.

headline: Cerberus’s Feinberg Testifies in United Rentals Trial
abstract: Stephen Feinberg, the famously reclusive founder of hedge fund and private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management, faced a grilling Tuesday over his decision to pull out of the $7 billion takeover of United Rentals during the first day of trial in the court battle.

headline: Goldman Said to Buy Stake in Winton Capital
abstract: Winton Capital Management, a $10 billion London hedge fund manager, has sold a 10 percent stake to a new Goldman Sachs-backed private equity fund reportedly targeting hedge funds.

headline: Sunday Ratings: Above All, Football
abstract: NBC’s “Sunday Night Football” broadcast of the game between the Philadelphia Eagles and the New England Patriots lifted the network to a first place win on Sunday night. The game scored the highest metered-market ratings for a prime time football game since November 2005, according to early data.

headline: China Formally Opens Investment Fund
abstract: China formally opened its state investment company, which is intended to manage about $200 billion of its massive foreign exchange reserves, on Saturday, Chinese state media reported.

headline: Sovereign Wealth Funds: A Shopping List
abstract: The announcement Monday night that Citigroup was selling a $7.5 billion stake to a Middle Eastern sovereign fund, the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority, is just the latest in a recent string of acquisitions by Middle Eastern and Asian sovereign wealth funds.

headline: Teachers Buys Glass Lewis for $46 Million
abstract: The Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan has bought Glass Lewis, a San Francisco-based investment research, proxy advisory and voting services firm, for $46 million from its Chinese owner, Xinhua Finance of Shanghai.

headline: A Different Formula for a Biogen Deal
abstract: Will DNA get mixed up in a sale of Biogen Idec?

headline: A Toast to the Top Women in Banking
abstract: At a gathering to toast the most powerful women in banking, there was a generally sense that despite some important inroads, more work was to be done.

headline: Schlumberger Offers $679 Million for Eastern Echo
abstract: Schlumberger, the oil-field services company, bid up to $679 million for a Norwegian-listed company, Eastern Echo, on Tuesday to expand its seismic operations at a time when record oil prices are driving demand.

headline: Ex-Chief Considers Bid for Children’s Place
abstract: Shares of Children’s Place rose 6 percent Monday after the company’s recently ousted chief executive and its largest shareholder, said he might put together an offer to buy the retailer.

headline: Perelman Seeks $500 Million ‘Blank Check’
abstract: MAFS Acquisition, a blank-check company led by billionaire financier Ronald O. Perelman, filed with regulators to raise as much as $500 million to fund an acquisition.

headline: Wary of Risk, Bankers Sold Shaky Mortgage Debt
abstract: As the subprime loan crisis deepens, Wall Street firms are increasingly coming under scrutiny for their role in selling risky mortgage-related securities to investors.

headline: A Dark-Horse Candidate for Citi’s Top Job?
abstract: Since last month, Citigroup has struggled to find a replacement for Charles O. Prince III, its recently resigned chief executive. It has looked inside the sprawling financial giant; it has examined the firm’s alumni (some of whom left the firm unwillingly); it has cast its eyes on the top executives of its rivals.

headline: Female Directors Earn More Than Men, Study Finds
abstract: A new survey on corporate board pay has come up with a surprising find: The median compensation for female directors is actually higher than that for male directors.

headline: They Told You So
abstract: By PETER EDMONSTON

headline: Microsoft to Spin Off ‘Halo’ Creator Bungie
abstract: Microsoft plans to spin off Bungie Studios, creator of the blockbuster “Halo” video game trilogy, but said Friday it would maintain close ties with the company and retain a minority stake in it.

headline: A Positive Spin On Housing
abstract: I came across a blog that thinks I simply do not understand what is going on in the housing market, as shown by the Off-The-Charts column on Saturday. That column argued that we’ve never had a severe decline in housing starts — such as we have now — without a recession.

headline: Alcoa to Sell Packaging, Consumer Units for $2.7 Billion
abstract: Alcoa said late Friday that it will sell its consumer and packaging divisions, which make Reynolds Wrap among other products, to the Rank Group of New Zealand for $2.7 billion in cash.

headline: Applebee’s Shareholders Say Yes to Ihop
abstract: Applebee’s International shareholders voted to approve the $2.1 billion takeover of the casual dining chain by pancake restaurant owner IHOP. The Applebee’s vote in Overland Park, Kan., clears the way for the transaction to be completed next month.

headline: Reading the Post-Game Analysis for Citi
abstract: Has Citigroup‘s Charles O. Prince III maneuvered himself into checkmate, or is he in control of the chessboard? Was the mega-bank’s latest management shuffle a bloop single or a fly out?

headline: Strike News: An Ending, Not End, For ‘Heroes’
abstract: The writers’ strike appears to have prompted NBC to promote the last original episode of “Heroes” as a mid-season finale.

headline: Bourdais finishes with another victory
abstract: Sébastien Bourdais is all set to test with Toro Rosso this week, complete with an eighth victory in his final race of his final year in Champ Car. That was a record number of wins for Bourdais in a single season in Champ Car, and brings his total to 31 victories in five seasons.

headline: Activist Fund Steps Up Pressure on HSBC
abstract: An acttivist hedge fund Knight Vinke on Tuesday accelerated its attack on HSBC with a fresh call to “grasp the nettle” and tear up its existing strategy.

headline: Enron Lawyers Seek $700 Million in Fees
abstract: Lawyers who recovered about $7.2 billion in settlements for investors who were damaged by the collapse of the energy trader Enron in late 2001 are seeking $700 million for their efforts, the largest fee in history in a securities fraud case.

headline: BlackRock Co-Founder Strikes Out on His Own
abstract: BlackRock‘s co-founder and chief investment officer of fixed income, Keith Anderson, has quit to start his own debt fund, in an attempt to take advantage of volatile credit markets.

headline: Merrill Takes Stake in BCE Ahead of L.B.O.
abstract: Merrill Lynch agreed to buy a stake in Bell Canada’s parent, BCE, for 475 million Canadian dollars ($489 million) from Providence Equity Partners and a group of banks, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing Thursday.

headline: Bristol-Myers Sells Unit to Avista for $525 Million
abstract: Drug developer Bristol-Myers Squibb said Monday it will sell its medical imaging unit to private equity firm Avista Capital Partners for about $525 million in cash.

headline: An Amazing Fraud
abstract: The story of Universal Express and the contempt in which its former chief executive, Richard Altomare, held the law and the interests of its shareholders, gets more and more outrageous.

headline: Hicks’ ‘Blank Check’ Fund Raises $552 Million
abstract: A Dallas financier, Tom Hicks, raised $552 million in the initial public offering Wednesday for his Hicks Acquisition Company I, a “blank-check” buyout firm that plans to acquire distressed companies in Canada and the United States in any industry except energy.

headline: Turner Researcher Calls 2007 ‘Transformational’ For Cable
abstract: In a year-end report for the media on Wednesday, Jack Wakshlag, the chief research officer for Turner Broadcasting, emphasized what a good year it had been for cable television’s ratings.

headline: ESPN Tries Life Beyond Sports
abstract: ESPN is set to announce a new newsmagazine today, in another effort to expand its brand beyond hardcore sports fans.

headline: What really came out of the McLaren appeal
abstract: What was most important in what came out of the McLaren appeal against the stewards’ decision to not punish BMW Sauber and Williams at the Brazilian Grand Prix was not this statement from the FIA:

headline: Classmates.com Looks to Raise $144 Million in I.P.O.
abstract: Classmates.com on Friday set the terms of its initial public offering at 12 million shares, with an estimated price range of $10 to $12 per share in a bid to raise as much as $144 million, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

headline: Peoples Choice Awards Get Strike Makeover
abstract: Producers of the People’s Choice Awards “said on Wednesday the upcoming show will be presented in a new prerecorded ‘magazine’-style format because of the Hollywood writers strike.”

headline: Citi Said to Reject Proposal for BofA Merger
abstract: Was Bank of America, known for its acquisitive streak, considering swallowing rival behemoth Citigroup?

headline: Electronic Arts to Add 2 Video Game Studios to Its Stable
abstract: Seeking to fill gaps in its product lineup, the video game publisher Electronic Arts said Thursday that it would acquire two software studios from Elevation Partners in a deal worth $860 million, the largest in its history.

headline: Vimpel Dials Up $4.3 Billion Telecom Deal
abstract: Vimpel Communications, Russia’s second-largest mobile operator, said Friday it agreed to buy Golden Telecom for about $4.3 billion. Under the deal, which had been widely expected, Vimpelcom will pay $105 for each Golden Telecom share, a 5 percent premium to its closing price Thursday.

headline: Blankfein’s $68 Million Bill to Shareholders
abstract: Are this man’s services worth more than $18,000 an hour?

headline: F.T.C. Tries Again to Stop Whole Foods Deal
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission is not taking its failure to block Whole Foods Market merger with Wild Oats Markets lying down.

headline: Will One Beer Deal Lead to Another?
abstract: With the news that SABMiller and Molson Coors plan to combine their United States operations, Wall Street is turning its attention to another brewing giant: Anheuser-Busch.

headline: Northern Rock Seeks to Block Leak of Bidding Memo
abstract: As Northern Rock continues negotiations with potential suitors a legal skirmish has broken out between the stricken British lender and the news media. Northern Rock said Wednesday that it had obtained a court injunction barring further publication of a confidential memo prepared for potential bidders for the troubled mortgage lender.

headline: Is Wall Street Still on Par?
abstract: By PETER EDMONSTON

headline: A Big Debut for Goldman’s New Fund?
abstract: Despite the notorious blowups of several hedge funds at Goldman Sachs this summer, it seems investors remain bullish on the investment bank’s prowess.

headline: Facebook: What Would Google Do?
abstract: As Facebook reaches for more investors and pushes hard (then backs off) on its advertising plans, it may want to look at the equally ambitious, but slower paced, style of Google.

headline: Delta Says It May Seek a Deal
abstract: Flush from a better-than-expected third quarter, Delta Air Lines said it is again considering a merger partner.

headline: Join the Discussion
abstract: Over the past four months, we’ve had contributions to our discussion of China’s environmental crisis from 14 experts, responding to comments or questions from nearly 600 readers. To catch up on the conversation to date, simply scroll down this page. To get involved, post a comment on the latest article in the series — on the drive to stage a “Green Olympics” in Beijing next summer — by using the comments box below.

headline: N.J. Casino Panel Approves Harrah’s Buyout
abstract: The New Jersey Casino Control Commission gave unanimous approval Wednesday for two private-equity firms to purchase Harrah’s Entertainment for $27.8 billion. The 5-0 vote, after a 2 1/2-hour hearing, supported the joint bid by Apollo Management and the Texas Pacific Group. Harrah’s owns four casinos in Atlantic City and six in Las Vegas.

headline: Sullivan & Cromwell Names New Partners
abstract: How important are overseas markets in the deal-making business these days? Just look at the list of newly elected partners at Sullivan & Cromwell, the New York-based firm that is a perennial front-runner in the league tables that track merger advisory work.

headline: Bam! ‘Emeril Live’ Is Gone
abstract: “Emeril Live!,” the cooking show hosted by Emeril Lagasse that helped put Food Network on the map ten years ago, will cease production in two weeks, the cable channel confirmed on Monday.

headline: Personal Gain Seen in O’Neal’s Wachovia Talks
abstract: When Merrill Lynch directors were briefed late last week about E. Stanley O’Neal’s approach to G. Kennedy Thompson, the chief executive at Wachovia, according to The New York Times, they were furious. (Even if he technically didn’t do anything wrong.)

headline: Wall Street Regulator Reaches Out to Main Street
abstract: It has famous Wall Street parents and an alphabet-soup abbreviation known only to investment professionals. Now Finra, the new private regulator for securities firms, mutual fund houses and stockbrokers, has a bold plan: to be a best friend to America’s ordinary investors.

headline: Revisiting Breast Cancer’s Effect on Careers
abstract: Column and blog post on businesses relating to breast cancer generates reader comments.

headline: American Public Boosts I.P.O. Price
abstract: American Public Education increased the expected price range of its initial public offering to $18 to $19 a share, setting up the company’s two venture capital owners for a richer-than-expected payday.

headline: Behind the Citi Chairman’s Other Title
abstract: As of Tuesday, Citigroup became the first major Wall Street firm to claim not only a foreign-born individual as its chief executive, but also the only one to have a knight as its chairman. That would be Winfried F.W. Bischoff, a German-born, South African-educated banker who joined Citi in 2000.

headline: Strike Ends Most Scripted TV Work
abstract: “Production on all but two of the last few scripted prime-time television shows shooting in Los Angeles ground to a halt on Friday as a crippling strike by Hollywood writers neared the end of its sixth week, an industry group said,” Reuters reports.

headline: Strike News: ‘Criminal Minds’ Producer Talks to Fans
abstract: Bypassing the media, the executive director of the CBS drama “Criminal Minds” has written a letter directly to fans about the writers’ strike.

headline: Verizon Wireless Says ‘Bring Your Own’ Device
abstract: Verizon Wireless will allow any device and any application to run on its network next year. This will help increase volume and strengthen its hand in bidding for more bandwidth.

headline: Aryx Therapeutics Prices I.P.O.
abstract: Aryx Therapeutics set terms for its initial public offering late Tuesday, disclosing that it plans to sell 5 million shares for between $14 and $16 apiece.

headline: Sony Sells Chip Division to Toshiba
abstract: Sony is selling its advanced computer chip operations to Toshiba, both companies said Thursday, in the latest sign Sony is raising cash and shedding operations to focus on its core electronics sector.

headline: Log Off and Get to Work
abstract: According to a new survey, more companies are blocking MySpace in the workplace than are blocking oncoming rival Facebook.

headline: Banks and Buyout Firms, Together Again
abstract: Way back in 2004, there was lots of angst on Wall Street about the potential conflicts between private equity funds and investment banks. Many firms, including Morgan Stanley and J.P. Morgan Chase, decided the best strategy to ease clients’ concerns was to cut their buyout arms loose.

headline: Ex-Partner at Milberg Weiss Pleads Guilty
abstract: Steven G. Schulman, a former partner at the law firm now known as Milberg Weiss, pleaded guilty on Tuesday to a racketeering conspiracy charge.

headline: Will Thain Come Between Merrill and BlackRock?
abstract: Now that John Thain apparently will take the reins of Merrill Lynch, here is a question to consider: What next for the firm’s relations with BlackRock?

headline: In Winning EMI, Is Guy Hands Losing Out on Other Deals?
abstract: Guy Hands, the chief executive of the buy-out group Terra Firma, is in “a wild panic” about his $4.7 billion acquisition of EMI and how he’ll manage to make a return on the record company, according to The Financial Times’ Alphaville blog.

headline: Bank of America’s Profits Fall 32 Percent
abstract: Bank of America, the third large money-center bank to report earnings this week, said its net income fell 32 percent in the third quarter to $3.70 billion, a sharper drop than many analysts had been expecting. The decline was less than the 57 percent plunge in profits at Citigroup. But the results were far worse than the 2 percent rise in earnings posted by J.P. Morgan Chase.

headline: Quest Energy Raises $163.8 Million in I.P.O.
abstract: Quest Energy Partners, an Oklahoma City-based oil and gas exploration company, raised $163.8 million on Thursday with an initial public offering that priced below expectations.

headline: ABC Takes Tuesday Night
abstract: With a special appearance from Charlie Brown and an unexpected exit on “Dancing With the Stars,” ABC earned the most viewers overall on Tuesday. The autumn perennial “It’s the Great Pumpkin, Charlie Brown” drew 11.4 million viewers at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates, putting ABC on top in the hour among adults 18 to 49. The Peanuts special also boosted ABC’s audience in the time slot by nearly 5 million viewers compared with last week’s episodes of “Cavemen” and “Carpoolers.”

headline: Merrill Denies Making ‘Inappropriate Transactions’
abstract: Responding to a Wall Street Journal story that said it tried to use questionable deals with hedge funds to delay potential write-downs, Merrill Lynch has denied doing anything wrong. The rebuttal did little to reverse the sharp decline in the company’s stock, however.

headline: Google and Friends to Gang Up on Facebook
abstract: A week after losing out to Microsoft in a bid to invest in Facebook, Google is hitting back.

headline: Next Chief at Citigroup Likely to Be an Outsider
abstract: Wall Street has been contemplating a successor to Charles O. Prince III almost since he took over as Citigroup‘s chief executive four years ago. Now the job is actually open.

headline: Deal Reached to Cover Remaining Risks at Germany’s IKB
abstract: KfW Group, which organized the bailout of IKB Deutsche Industriebank over subprime losses, said an agreement was reached with German banking associations to cover the lender’s remaining risks of about $520 million.

headline: Disney Chief Calls ABC ‘Well Prepared’
abstract: Disney executives downplayed the severity of a strike on the company’s financial performance. “We think the network is well prepared,” Bob Iger said.

headline: Listen Up: A New Kind of Spam
abstract: Get ready for a new kind of unsolicited junk e-mail: audio spam.

headline: G.M. Said to Be Selling Truck Unit to Navistar
abstract: Navistar International, an Illinois-based maker of trucks and diesel engines, is expected to announce Thursday that it is buying General Motors‘ medium-duty truck business, according to The New York Times.

headline: Is the Media Blob Passé?
abstract: Viacom has tried it. So has Time Warner. E.W. Scripps and Belo are getting in on the trend.

headline: Teachers Buys Glass Lewis for $46 Million
abstract: The Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan has bought Glass Lewis, a San Francisco-based investment research, proxy advisory and voting services firm, for $46 million from its Chinese owner, Xinhua Finance of Shanghai.

headline: A Different Formula for a Biogen Deal
abstract: Will DNA get mixed up in a sale of Biogen Idec?

headline: A Toast to the Top Women in Banking
abstract: At a gathering to toast the most powerful women in banking, there was a generally sense that despite some important inroads, more work was to be done.

headline: Schlumberger Offers $679 Million for Eastern Echo
abstract: Schlumberger, the oil-field services company, bid up to $679 million for a Norwegian-listed company, Eastern Echo, on Tuesday to expand its seismic operations at a time when record oil prices are driving demand.

headline: Ex-Chief Considers Bid for Children’s Place
abstract: Shares of Children’s Place rose 6 percent Monday after the company’s recently ousted chief executive and its largest shareholder, said he might put together an offer to buy the retailer.

headline: Perelman Seeks $500 Million ‘Blank Check’
abstract: MAFS Acquisition, a blank-check company led by billionaire financier Ronald O. Perelman, filed with regulators to raise as much as $500 million to fund an acquisition.

headline: Wary of Risk, Bankers Sold Shaky Mortgage Debt
abstract: As the subprime loan crisis deepens, Wall Street firms are increasingly coming under scrutiny for their role in selling risky mortgage-related securities to investors.

headline: A Dark-Horse Candidate for Citi’s Top Job?
abstract: Since last month, Citigroup has struggled to find a replacement for Charles O. Prince III, its recently resigned chief executive. It has looked inside the sprawling financial giant; it has examined the firm’s alumni (some of whom left the firm unwillingly); it has cast its eyes on the top executives of its rivals.

headline: Female Directors Earn More Than Men, Study Finds
abstract: A new survey on corporate board pay has come up with a surprising find: The median compensation for female directors is actually higher than that for male directors.

headline: They Told You So
abstract: By PETER EDMONSTON

headline: Google-Backed 23andMe Debuts
abstract: 23andMe, an online company backed by funds from Google that is selling a personal DNA test for $999, has made its start as a kind of genetics-focused MySpace or Facebook, but with the more serious aim of allowing medicine someday to target Americans’ ills more precisely.

headline: This Friday, It’s ‘Lights’ On
abstract: “Friday Night Lights” spent its first season on NBC’s Tuesday schedule, but beginning tonight it moves to the traditional high school football night of Friday.

headline: Google’s OpenSocial Is Not a Facebook Killer
abstract: Google’s new OpenSocial initiative is nifty technology, but it’s not a product that in itself will cause any trouble for Facebook or MySpace.

headline: Preparing for Change, Time Warner Hires Media Analyst
abstract: Time Warner has quietly hired a prominent media analyst as it reshuffles its executive ranks in the weeks before Jeffrey L. Bewkes takes over as chief executive from Richard D. Parsons.

headline: Who’s Left Holding The Bag?
abstract: I did a blog item yesterday on the examiner’s report on Universal Express, which said the company never made money and did not have enough cash to pay its employees, let alone its creditors.

headline: Blackstone Teams With ChemChina in Nufarm Bid
abstract: The Blackstone Group has teamed up with China National Chemical and the private equity firm Fox Paine to bid up to $3 billion Australian dollars ($2.75 billion) on Monday for Australia’s Nufarm, a deal that would create the world’s largest generic farm chemicals firm.

headline: Yucaipa Plans Bid for Twinkies Bakery
abstract: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters on Friday joined forces with Ronald Burkle’s Yucaipa and Bimbo Bakeries USA and have a plan for Yucaipa to buy the bankrupt Interstate Bakeries, which makes Wonder Bread and Twinkies.

headline: Blackstone Said to Be Close to Scrapping PHH Deal
abstract: It seems more and more likely that PHH should be added to the list of failed buyouts.

headline: One Question Answered
abstract: Holy cripes, I’m blown away by the number of responses to my “Pogue’s Imponderables.” 450 responses in the first 36 hours!

headline: Akela to Scrap U.S. I.P.O.
abstract: Akela Pharma said on Thursday it would not go ahead with its U.S. public offering, citing unfavorable market conditions for small and micro-cap companies.

headline: Merrill Says It Expects Big Loss for 3rd Quarter
abstract: Merrill Lynch said on Friday that the credit market turmoil will take a toll on its third-quarter earnings, confirming analysts’ fears.

headline: Microsoft Wins One in the War Against Google
abstract: Microsoft said it would invest $240 million in Facebook. The money will help Facebook challenge Google and by extension help Microsoft.

headline: The Future of Solar-Powered Homes
abstract: This weekend, at a few minutes past 9 a.m. EST, “CBS News Sunday Morning” will broadcast my report on this year’s Solar Decathlon. (This show’s stories often get rescheduled at the last moment, but so far it’s looking good for Sunday.)

headline: Cerberus Withdraws $6.2 Billion Bid for Affiliated Computer Services
abstract: Cerberus Capital Management officially withdrew its $6.2 billion offer for Affiliated Computer Services on Tuesday, blaming the credit squeeze and the refusal of the company’s board to negotiate a deal.

headline: Cox Says S.E.C. Is Examining Banks’ Subprime Disclosures
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission is looking at whether banks made proper disclosures when announcing their investments in subprime-mortgage products, the agency’s chairman, Christopher Cox, said on Wednesday.

headline: Citadel, BlackRock to Inject $2.5 Billion into E*Trade
abstract: E*Trade Financial, the troubled Internet bank and brokerage, said Thursday it secured a $2.55 billion cash infusion from a group led by hedge-fund firm Citadel Investment Group.

headline: Time Warner May Be in for a New Era of Dealmaking
abstract: The news that Jeffrey L. Bewkes, Time Warner‘s the chief operating officer, will succeed Richard D. Parsons as chief executive at the end of the year had industry watchers wondering if a spate of dealmaking may be in the offing at world’s largest media company.

headline: Bear Bids Adieu to $8 Billion in Assets
abstract: At Bear Stearns, you can take it with you.

headline: Westpac Corrals Rams Home
abstract: Westpac Banking will buy the brand and distribution business of Australia’s Rams Home Loans Group, swooping onto assets of the lender, which struggled to refinance its debt after the subprime mortgage crisis in the United States.

headline: ABC’s Sequel to ‘Dancing’: More Dancing
abstract: ABC’s hit franchise “Dancing With the Stars” is the envy of the broadcast networks. The reality show routinely placed No. 1 on the weekly prime time ratings charts this fall, and the season finale averaged almost 25 million viewers on Tuesday night, when Helio Castroneves, a race car driver, beat out Melanie Brown of the Spice Girls and Marie Osmond to win.

headline: For Lawyers, Perks to Fit a Lifestyle
abstract: The perks for lawyers have burgeoned in recent years as firms pull out the stops to attract top-notch talent. While extras for the partners have always been common, many are now finding their way to associates – young lawyers who have not yet made partner, The New York Times reports.

headline: Strike News: Appearances On ‘The View’ Canceled; CBS Debate Could Be Jeopardized
abstract: Less than a week after becoming the first candidate to visit the writers’ picket lines in Southern California, John Edwards and wife Elizabeth said today that they had canceled their scheduled appearance on the ABC talk show “The View” next week to “honor the members of the Writers Guild of America.”

headline: Prison Term in Safety-Kleen Fraud Case
abstract: The former chief financial officer of the Safety-Kleen hazardous waste disposal company was sentenced Thursday to 5 years and 10 months in prison after admitting to securities and bank fraud charges.

headline: Oracle, I.B.M. Said to Have Bid for Business Objects
abstract: A preliminary proxy filing for SAP‘s $5.7 billion acquisition of Business Objects, a French software firm, reveals that two other bidders had stepped forward.

headline: More Goodies in Apple’s New Operating System
abstract: In today’s Times, I reviewed Apple’s latest operating system, Mac OS X 10.5 “Leopard.” I noted that Apple claims to have added over 300 new features.

headline: Morgan Stanley Co-Presidents Disclose Ownership Stakes
abstract: Morgan Stanley‘s two new co-presidents, Walid Chammah and James Gorman, disclosed in regulatory filings that they own a combined total of more than $57 million worth of the investment bank’s shares.

headline: Citigroup Names Executive to Oversee Subprime Assets
abstract: Citigroup named Richard Stuckey to manage most of its $43 billion of subprime mortgage assets, choosing the same executive who nine years ago helped unwind Long-Term Capital Management‘s bad bets.

headline: Navteq Takes a Hit on EU Scrutiny of Rival’s Deal
abstract: Shares of digital mapping company Navteq nosedived Wednesday after the European Commission served notice that it would conduct an in-depth, stage-two investigation of the takeover of Navteq’s biggest competitor, Tele Atlas of the Netherlands.

headline: 3,000 Layoffs Today. More Tomorrow?
abstract: The axe has fallen. Bank of America said it will eliminate 3,000 jobs following its announcement last week of a huge drop in earnings for the third quarter. Most of the layoffs will come from its investment banking unit. BofA also said it was starting a strategic review of its investment banking business, raising the prospect of significant changes for the firm.

headline: Off to The New York Times Small Business Summit
abstract: Shifting Careers blogger is holding virtual office hours at The New York Times Small Business Summit

headline: Strike, Day Five: Show-Runners Receive Breach-of-Contract Letters, Agents Meet with Guild
abstract: — The New York Times: “At least two major television studios, 20th Century Fox and CBS Paramount, have sent breach-of-contract letters to the show runners on their current series who have stopped performing their production duties once they went on strike with other television writers.”

headline: NBC Will Buy TiVo Data
abstract: NBC Universal has “agreed to start offering interactive advertising services and subscribe to a ratings service from TiVo,” Reuters reports.

headline: Drew Carey, Celebrity Libertarian
abstract: Loyal viewers of “The Price Is Right” can recite Bob Barker’s sign-off on cue. “Help control the pet population; have your pet spayed or neutered,” he said at the end of every hour. Might Drew Carey, the new host of the CBS game show, sign off by telling big government to take a hike?

headline: F.C.C.’s Media Proposal May Lead to Asset Sales
abstract: The head of the Federal Communications Commission on Tuesday announced the details of his plan to relax the longstanding rule that had prevented a company from owning both a newspaper and a radio or television station in the same city.

headline: Pennsylvania Insurance Merger Review Won’t Be Done Until 2008
abstract: Pennsylvania’s two largest health insurers, which in March agreed to merge, won’t know whether they will be able to go ahead with the deal until next summer, at the earliest.

headline: Asian Offerings Push Goldman to Top of the Tables
abstract: Despite this summer’s turmoil in the United States and European credit markets, and the associated volatility in developed equity markets, investment banks, especially Goldman Sachs, can take solace from the seemingly unstoppable growth in Asia-Pacific equity markets.

headline: BofA Replaces Chief of Investment-Grade Bond Trading
abstract: The Bank of America said that its head of investment-grade bond trading has resigned, continuing a shakeup after the company’s corporate and investment bank reported a 93 percent decline in third-quarter profit. The bank also closed its European credit strategy team, a spokesman, Brandon Ashcraft, said Wednesday according to Bloomberg News.

headline: ‘Dateline’ to Return; Death of ‘Life’?
abstract: NBC’s stalwart newsmagazine “Dateline” will return to the network’s prime time schedule on Dec. 12 for the first time in over a month.

headline: Bear Stearns Issues More Pink Slips
abstract: Bear Stearns cut 300 jobs Monday to reduce costs, as the investment bank continued to deal with the summer’s credit turmoil that swept through Wall Street.

headline: Dana Installs Big Auto Names for New Board
abstract: From DealBook’s colleague Micheline Maynard:

headline: Allure of Alternative Assets Remains Strong
abstract: Despite the summer’s woes at buyout firms and hedge funds, private investment vehicles — large institutional investors with long-term plans to diversify away from simple stocks and bonds — are likely to continue pouring billions into alternative investments, The New York Times reports. And at least for now, the effort to crimp the industry’s tax advantages has faltered.

headline: News Unlikely to Fill TV Strike Holes
abstract: News programming has proved to be unpopular on network television, even as the writers’ strike creates holes in prime time schedules, the Associated Press reports:

headline: Hologic’s $6.3 Billion Deal Nears Close
abstract: A $6.3 billion deal to create a women’s healthcare giant was years in the making.

headline: Rio Tinto May Offer BHP an Alliance, Report Says
abstract: Rio Tinto is considering offering joint ventures with BHP Billiton as an alternative to BHP’s proposed $140 billion takeover, The Telegraph reported.

headline: Is Information Overload a $650 Billion Drag on the Economy?
abstract: A business research firm tries to estimate the “cost of unnecessary interruptions” in terms of lost productivity and innovation.

headline: Happiness Revisited, With a Gender Twist
abstract: Chiming in on the conversation about gender and happiness.

headline: F1 speculative fiction
abstract: What was a lively, busy off-season is turning into a full-fledged Formula One crisis. Two bits of breaking news today raise questions about the future of the sport. Reminiscent of the leaked information in Italy during the heat of the spy scandal, a McLaren memo was leaked to the British press overnight that makes the Renault story look worse than previously described. The key word is the “780” drawings of the McLaren car – reminiscent of the 780 pages of Ferrari data that McLaren had.

headline: Comedy Central Hosts Stewart and Colbert To Return Jan. 7
abstract: Comedy Central’s pair of popular news satirists, Jon Stewart and Stephen Colbert, will return to their late-night television shows on Jan. 7, two months after production was suspended because of a writers’ strike.

headline: Colbert’s Facebook Fan Club Gains 78 New Members Per Minute
abstract: Today on The Caucus blog, “Colbert’s Facebook Flock:”

headline: BEA Systems Says Oracle Bid Is Too Low
abstract: Oracle‘s latest acquisition target, BEA Systems, is hardly rushing into its suitor’s arms.

headline: NBC Gets a Bargain With Oxygen, Analysts Say
abstract: NBC Universal, it seems, got itself a bargain with its $925 million deal for Oxygen, a cable television channel aimed at women.

headline: How Analysts’ Auto Estimates Went Off Course
abstract: From DealBook colleague Micheline Maynard:

headline: WestLB Seeks Merger with Helaba
abstract: The owners of WestLB, a German bank that has been battered by a trading scandal and turmoil in the mortgage markets in the United States, said on Wednesday they would seek merger talks with a publicly-owned counterpart, Helaba.

headline: Building Your Own High-Tech “Bug”
abstract: Bug Labs, a company that wants users to build their own high-tech gadgets, prepares for a January rollout.

headline: TCI Starts Proxy Fight at CSX
abstract: Two activist hedge funds took another shot at CSX on Wednesday as they named an alternate slate of directors, in the first sign that they will wage a proxy fight.

headline: The Young and the Not So Restless
abstract: Today’s Shifting Careers column focuses on young leaders, and what everyone else can learn from them.

headline: Wagamama’s Owners May Pull I.P.O., Report Says
abstract: Wagamama’s private equity owners are looking to auction the popular British noodle bar chain rather than continue with a planned initial public offering, The Financial Times reported.

headline: China’s Great Wall Sells Drive Maker to Iomega
abstract: Iomega, an American distributor of computer data storage equipment, said Wednesday that it was entering into a complex $310 million deal to acquire ExcelStor, a Chinese contract maker of disk drives.

headline: The Fear Bubble
abstract: Prices for Internet companies are skyrocketing. But this bubble isn’t about the start-ups that can change the world; it is about established Internet companies afraid of Google, and what might be the next Google.

headline: Black Friday Alert: Big Plasma Sets on Sale
abstract: This holiday season, prices for LCD sets will fall by less than 20 percent, while plasma set prices will be down 30 percent. Meanwhile low cost brands will take even more share from Sony and Samsung.

headline: Teachers Buys Glass Lewis for $46 Million
abstract: The Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan has bought Glass Lewis, a San Francisco-based investment research, proxy advisory and voting services firm, for $46 million from its Chinese owner, Xinhua Finance of Shanghai.

headline: A Different Formula for a Biogen Deal
abstract: Will DNA get mixed up in a sale of Biogen Idec?

headline: A Toast to the Top Women in Banking
abstract: At a gathering to toast the most powerful women in banking, there was a generally sense that despite some important inroads, more work was to be done.

headline: Schlumberger Offers $679 Million for Eastern Echo
abstract: Schlumberger, the oil-field services company, bid up to $679 million for a Norwegian-listed company, Eastern Echo, on Tuesday to expand its seismic operations at a time when record oil prices are driving demand.

headline: Ex-Chief Considers Bid for Children’s Place
abstract: Shares of Children’s Place rose 6 percent Monday after the company’s recently ousted chief executive and its largest shareholder, said he might put together an offer to buy the retailer.

headline: Perelman Seeks $500 Million ‘Blank Check’
abstract: MAFS Acquisition, a blank-check company led by billionaire financier Ronald O. Perelman, filed with regulators to raise as much as $500 million to fund an acquisition.

headline: Wary of Risk, Bankers Sold Shaky Mortgage Debt
abstract: As the subprime loan crisis deepens, Wall Street firms are increasingly coming under scrutiny for their role in selling risky mortgage-related securities to investors.

headline: A Dark-Horse Candidate for Citi’s Top Job?
abstract: Since last month, Citigroup has struggled to find a replacement for Charles O. Prince III, its recently resigned chief executive. It has looked inside the sprawling financial giant; it has examined the firm’s alumni (some of whom left the firm unwillingly); it has cast its eyes on the top executives of its rivals.

headline: Female Directors Earn More Than Men, Study Finds
abstract: A new survey on corporate board pay has come up with a surprising find: The median compensation for female directors is actually higher than that for male directors.

headline: They Told You So
abstract: By PETER EDMONSTON

headline: Thain’s $50 Million Clean-Up Job
abstract: Call him Wall Street’s richest mop-up man, at least for now.

headline: Verizon’s Real Move to Openness
abstract: Verizon Wireless said today it will use a technical standard known as LTE for its next generation network. Since that standard is being adopted by most of the world, and by AT&T in the United States, Verizon’s move will spur competition and give customers more choices for phones.

headline: Tech Buyouts Were Scarce in Third Quarter
abstract: Leveraged buyouts of technology companies nearly vanished in the third quarter, in lockstep with the evaporating supply of cheap debt, according to analyst firm The 451 Group.

headline: Eldercare, an Inevitable Work/Life Issue
abstract: Some advice about eldercare, a daunting work/life issue for those who face it.

headline: Swiss Life to Pay $1.64 Billion for Germany’s AWD
abstract: Swiss Life surprised investors on Monday with plans to buy AWD, the dynamic German financial advisory group, hard on the heels of big disposals in recent weeks.

headline: Without Correspondents In Pakistan, TV Networks Rely on Producers and Part-Timers
abstract: Of the U.S. television networks, only ABC and CNN had full-time personnel in Pakistan when the former Pakistan prime minister Benazir Bhutto was assassinated on Thursday.

headline: Permira Wins $2.2 Billion Deal for Japan’s Arysta
abstract: The private equity firm Permira said it had won the race to buy the agrichemical company Arysta LifeScience for about 250 billion yen ($2.2 billion) enterprise value, marking its first deal in Japan.

headline: Merrill Said to Consider $5 Billion Infusion
abstract: Another day, another report of a banking deal by a sovereign wealth fund.

headline: S.E.C.’s Lead WorldCom Lawyer to Join Simpson Thacher
abstract: Peter H. Bresnan, the man who led the Securities and Exchange Commission’s landmark accounting fraud lawsuit against WorldCom, is trading his enforcement duties for private practice.

headline: Level 3 Sells Ad Unit to DG FastChannel
abstract: Level 3 Communications on Wednesday said it will sell the advertising distribution business of Vyvx to DG FastChannel. Vyvx is a wholly owned subsidiary of Level 3. Under the terms of the deal, Level 3 will receive $129 million payable in cash.

headline: Ross Wins American Home Unit
abstract: Bankrupt American Home Mortgage Investment on Friday declared a Wilbur Ross investment fund the winner in the sale of its servicing unit after the auction was called off.

headline: Rather Marks One Year in High-Def
abstract: Somewhere in Havana, Dan Rather is smiling.

headline: H.B.O.S. Unit Takes Stake in Ainscough Crane
abstract: Bank of Scotland Integrated Finance, an arm of Halifax Bank of Scotland that focuses on investing in management-led midmarket buyouts, took a stake Wednesday in the 255 million pound ($521 million) acquisition of a British plant crane rental business, Ainscough Crane Hire.

headline: Unsolicited Tips for Time Warner’s C.E.O.-in-Waiting
abstract: Add another voice to the swelling chorus of free advice on what Time Warner should do with its long-ailing Internet unit, America Online.

headline: The Studios Make Their Case
abstract: Ahead of today’s negotiations with the Writers Guild of America, the alliance of television and film studios published “An Open Letter to the Entertainment Industry” in trade publications this morning.

headline: Buyout Lender Taps Public Markets in Search of Fresh Capital
abstract: a leveraged buyout lender, American Capital Strategies priced a $157 million share offering to raise more capital, as credit remains scarce and overall private equity mergers plummeted 72 percent in the third quarter.

headline: Baer Now Mulls I.P.O. for U.S. Unit
abstract: Swiss private bank Julius Baer Holding is eyeing an initial public offering or a management-led buyout of its U.S. asset management unit after talks to sell it stalled, according to Reuters.

headline: Hong Kong Exchange Sits Out the Dance, for Now
abstract: In the last year, amid a flurry of deals among stock exchanges to merge or take strategic stakes in one another, the Hong Kong exchange has deliberately sat on the sidelines.

headline: Lawyer/Filmmaker Buddies Share Two Jobs
abstract: Two friends share a career as lawyers and filmmakers.

headline: Sullivan & Cromwell Matches Cravath Bonuses
abstract: Sullivan & Cromwell on Monday became the latest firm to match the bonus range announced last week by Cravath, Swaine & Moore, which said it would pay both year-end and one-time “special” bonuses to associates totalling $45,000 for first-years and going up to $110,000 for senior associates.

headline: More ‘Lyrics’ to Remember
abstract: Add “Don’t Forget the Lyrics!” to the growing list of reality shows that may be benefiting from the writers’ strike.

headline: Strike News: Lay-Offs At ‘The Tonight Show’
abstract: As expected, NBC Universal laid off the non-writing staff of the “Tonight Show with Jay Leno” and “Late Night with Conan O’Brien” on Friday.

headline: Insert Pun Here: NBC Saves ‘Life’
abstract: On Friday, after TV Decoder noted that NBC was pre-empting the detective drama “Life” on Dec. 12, dozens of fans immediately wrote in to come to the show’s defense.

headline: What Now for Cadbury Schweppes?
abstract: Cadbury Schweppes faces an uncertain future now that the company has decided to spin off its North American drinks business instead of trying to sell the unit outright.

headline: Crunch Time for Tribune Buyout
abstract: Tribune executives were sweating out aggressive last-minute questioning Tuesday from bankers reluctant to fund the final portion of a debt-laden $8.2 billion deal to take the company private with Chicago billionaire Samuel Zell, The Chicago Tribune reported.

headline: CCMP Closes Latest Fund at $3.4 Billion
abstract: CCMP Capital Advisors said on Tuesday that it had closed its latest fund with total commitments of $3.4 billion. The private equity firm, based in New York, said that the closing increases its assets under management and committed capital to $10 billion.

headline: Bad Rumor: Blackstone’s ‘Bid’ for Rio Tinto
abstract: Update: The Blackstone Group in a statement (PDF) Monday denied the rumor.

headline: Investors Take Wind Out of Och-Ziff Debut
abstract: Shares of the $30 billion hedge fund Och-Ziff Capital Management Group fell 4.2 percent Wednesday during its first day as a public company. Och-Ziff, which raised $1.15 billion with its initial public offering of stock late on Tuesday, ended the day down $1.35 a share, closing at $30.65.

headline: More Deals Ahead for Software AG
abstract: After absorbing webMethods and seeing immediate returns from the deal, Software AG of Germany is shopping again.

headline: It’s Official: Merrill Says O’Neal Will Retire
abstract: After five years atop one of Wall Street’s best-known firms, E. Stanley O’Neal is gone.
